00:07:59.560 | And there was a paper circulated at GitHub.
00:08:02.560 | And a couple of other people, probably more than a couple of other people, ended up writing that paper.

00:08:15.560 | This is before the hype of ChatGPT and everything else that you know about.
00:08:20.560 | This is before the existence of being able to actually have this conference.
00:08:25.560 | And one of the things, in my opinion, that that paper had was what I call polarity.
00:08:30.560 | And polarity, for me, is not a choice.
00:08:33.560 | Because you can choose A and B. Polarity, for me, is those choices are interconnected and related as well.
00:08:39.560 | So there were a lot of people that said that it was fiction.
00:08:43.560 | For example, is this fact or fiction?
00:08:45.560 | You probably will say it's fiction.
00:08:47.560 | If you ask my, you know, four-year-old or three-year-old, they'll tell you it's fact.
00:08:50.560 | They love this thing.

00:08:57.560 | So it kind of had this thing of like, is it a fact or is it fiction?
00:09:02.560 | And we went through a lot of conversations about what is this product really going to be like?
00:09:09.560 | And the product kind of failed at the beginning.
00:09:12.560 | We were trying it first in the PR flow, as an example, and it was not good in there.
00:09:17.560 | But then something happened, and we started kind of seeing traction.
00:09:21.560 | And that traction ended up with us shipping the product in 2021.
00:09:26.560 | And that was the first AI at-scale AI programmer in the world.
00:09:32.560 | And it has continued to grow since then.
00:09:34.560 | We were the first co-pilot before everything happened.

00:11:36.560 | So, like I said, you know, we're building Copilot for the sake of developer happiness.
00:11:41.560 | You know, for me, the definition of success of Copilot is this.
00:11:46.560 | It's not lines of code accepted, although that's a pretty good metric overall.
00:11:51.560 | It is fundamentally we are erasing all the boilerplate that you're creating, all the things that kind of don't keep you in the flow.
00:11:59.560 | And what I want you to experience of Copilot is the feeling of flow at the end.
00:12:04.560 | It's not only about conversational.
00:12:05.560 | Now we have inline chat.

00:12:10.560 | The chat box is not all.
00:12:12.560 | You know, and in code completion kind of we have proven that as well.
00:12:15.560 | But, you know, this is what generates happy developers from -- in my end is kind of that flow.
00:12:20.560 | And happy developers write better software.
00:12:22.560 | You know, Milton doesn't write a lot of good software overall.
00:12:25.560 | All right.
00:12:26.560 | Let's keep it going.
00:12:27.560 | So, more insider information.
00:12:29.560 | Like, what made it successful?
00:12:30.560 | If you ask me, what made Copilot V1 successful?
00:12:34.560 | And that is, I would say, the code completion product that you use today.
00:12:37.560 | And there's four key components on it.
00:12:40.560 | Number one, it was the ghost text.
00:12:42.560 | Believe it or not, that completely changed the game when we were trying the codex model.
00:12:47.560 | And codex was the first model that shipped with Copilot.
00:12:51.560 | When we were trying that model, having the ability to actually generate either from natural language,
00:12:57.560 | you know, you could just put a comment and have it generate, or just normal as you're typing,
00:13:02.560 | having something in there to remind you, is this what you want or not?
00:13:05.560 | Having that in the UX was one of the key elements.
00:13:10.560 | The second thing is, it had to be fast.
00:13:12.560 | It's not like, you know, people don't like, if I want to keep you in the flow and you're waiting seconds for that,
00:13:17.560 | that's not a good experience, right?
00:13:19.560 | So, what do we want?
00:13:20.560 | We want to make it fast.
00:13:21.560 | So, we worked a lot, you know, just recently, by the way, we switched to GPT 3.5 Turbo behind,
00:13:27.560 | so we're no longer using codex.
00:13:29.560 | But, you know, codex is a very fast model, so you end up with less than 100 milliseconds in latency many of the times.
00:13:35.560 | Then, the other thing is, you know, the codex model was like anything we have seen before.
00:13:40.560 | You know, hats off to open AI on that, but that model really changed the experience that we were having.
00:13:46.560 | We were always tinkering with AI at GitHub, but once we actually pair ghost text with low latency with an amazing model,
00:13:54.560 | then that's when the magic happened.
00:13:56.560 | And then, at the end, you know, there's people that say prompt engineering is not a true thing.
00:14:01.560 | At least from where I'm standing, prompt engineering is a very true thing.
00:14:04.560 | So, if you're really gifted at that, I have a job offer for you at the end of this.
00:14:08.560 | Because, like, it takes a long -- I could create a demo for you all probably within 30 seconds.
00:14:15.560 | Make an AI product that actually gets used by millions of people that you could sell out there to companies.
00:14:21.560 | That takes a lot of hard work, and it takes a lot of engineering.
00:14:25.560 | It takes a lot of people like you continuing and innovating as well.
00:14:29.560 | All right.
00:14:30.560 | So, let's go to the next one.
00:14:32.560 | The main point that I really want to make at the end over here is UX matters in what we're doing.
00:14:36.560 | Don't think that you're just going to get something out there.
00:14:39.560 | The UX that you end up choosing, the modality you end up choosing with that AI application can either make or break it.
00:14:45.560 | And we have seen that a lot as well.
00:14:47.560 | All right.
00:14:48.560 | So, what are your things?
00:14:49.560 | The other thing that I want to tell you is once you actually hit a little bit of that product-market fit, get used to a very fast pace.
00:14:56.560 | If you think right now you're fast-paced, things go kind of to the other side once you're having success with the business in AI.
00:15:02.560 | There's a lot of questions coming at you.
00:15:04.560 | A lot of things that you have to handle both internally and then externally.
00:15:07.560 | So, some things that are also learnings from inside.
00:15:10.560 | Number one is, and you probably know this, syntax is not software.
00:15:13.560 | Just because you can read Java doesn't make you a Java developer.
00:15:16.560 | So, on that end, same thing for AI.
00:15:19.560 | Just because AI can actually understand some of the syntax, it does not make it a developer.
00:15:24.560 | You have to do a lot of work from a semantic perspective for that AI to end up generating the right code.
00:15:29.560 | So, just remember that.
00:15:31.560 | Syntax is not software if you're going to be in this space.
00:15:34.560 | The other stuff is you need a global presence if you're going to have a global product.
00:15:38.560 | We have deployments all around the world in order to keep that 150 milliseconds many times.
00:15:44.560 | So, we are in Japan.
00:15:45.560 | We are in Europe.
00:15:46.560 | We are in North America in multiple data centers.
00:15:50.560 | In order to guarantee that first time to buy it overall, it's very, very fast.
00:15:55.560 | The other stuff is set up scorecards for quality.
00:15:58.560 | You could mess up your deployment very quickly.
00:16:01.560 | Like you think you actually have something that it works.
00:16:05.560 | And then you go to production, meaning your offline evaluations.
00:16:08.560 | Right?
00:16:09.560 | So, in your offline evals, everything is working.
00:16:11.560 | You go to prod and your online evals kind of tank.
00:16:14.560 | So, be ready for that.
00:16:16.560 | Scorecards are very, very helpful.
00:16:18.560 | Because what sometimes works in offline is not really going to work in online.
00:16:22.560 | So, if I have one thing to tell you at scale is set up your offline and online evaluations.
00:16:28.560 | So, you could actually end up iterating quickly.
00:16:30.560 | Because you're going to have to increase the ability for you to ship.
00:16:34.560 | So, what else?
00:16:36.560 | The other thing that we have learned, and there's a saying that says thrust grows at the speed of coconut but falls at the speed of a coconut.
00:16:45.560 | And really what I want to tell you on that is, once you go into companies, so if you're going to take your product and go to B2B overall, you're going to have to care about three things.
00:16:54.560 | Number one is security.
00:16:55.560 | Please don't store anything at rest.
00:16:57.560 | Usually that's not going to be a good thing for you or any of your prompts or any of the customer data.
00:17:01.560 | Please don't train on their data or file their, you know, their approval and all of those type of things.
00:17:06.560 | You're not going to get far.
00:17:08.560 | The second thing, there's a lot of legal things that you have to care about.
00:17:11.560 | You know, for example, for us, we provide indemnification to our customers just in case there's anything happening.
00:17:17.560 | So, you know, and as you could probably imagine from the legal perspective today, there's a lot of, you know, regulations and things that we're talking about with many of the countries.
00:17:25.560 | And the last thing is what we call responsible AI.
00:17:28.560 | You could see, I think yesterday's, and someone told me this, but I think yesterday's open AI demo failed, but it mainly failed on that.
00:17:37.560 | It failed on their ability to actually have, you know, not security, but trust and trustworthiness into what they're doing and the responsible AI aspect of it.
00:17:48.560 | So, the same for us, we invest a fair amount in making sure that the AI is doing the right thing for the user and it's not harming the user.
00:17:57.560 | So, I encourage you to continue to think from that ethics perspective because it's really important.
00:18:02.560 | We're creating this to advance, you know, human progress forward, not really taking it back.
00:18:07.560 | All right.
00:18:08.560 | So, now I want to kind of explore, I'm going to shift it from, okay, some lessons learned into a little bit more about the future.
00:18:17.560 | So, from a future, what gets me out of bed?
00:18:20.560 | Well, fundamentally transforming how the world builds software together, but what does that kind of mean?
00:18:25.560 | Like where's Copilot going?
00:18:27.560 | There's a talk by Brett Victor that is called The Future of Programming, and I want you to watch it because I think, you know, it happened a long time ago,
00:18:37.560 | but really talks about the struggles that we have in software going forward that are still present there.
00:18:43.560 | And the first prompt, actually, we'll put it like this.
00:18:47.560 | The first prompt that I want to give you is the following.
00:18:50.560 | What does it look like to move from procedures to goals and constraints?
00:18:53.560 | So, what does that mean?
00:18:55.560 | Well, coding today is procedures, text files, and sequential programming.
00:19:00.560 | This is how you do things.
00:19:01.560 | You know, our CEO went and programmed an OctoRK demo, a snake demo, so if a CEO can actually program, that's always great, right?
00:19:08.560 | Although in a technology company, hopefully all of them can.
00:19:11.560 | But it's this, right?
00:19:14.560 | Like he did it in JavaScript.
00:19:15.560 | I was kind of throwing him a little bit on, hey, can you just do it in TypeScript and can we have Copilot do that for you?
00:19:21.560 | But it's just procedures, text file, and sequential.
00:19:27.560 | And is that really what AI should help you with, should be doing going forward?
00:19:32.560 | I think no.
00:19:33.560 | I think a future of Copilot really goes on operating on goals and constraints.
00:19:40.560 | And then the REPL, the actual programming environment that you have will need to change.
00:19:46.560 | This is what we want to do.
00:19:47.560 | We just don't want to play to the status quo of what it is today.
00:19:50.560 | We want to have AI actually change it and kind of do a step up going forward.
00:19:55.560 | So what do I want the future to be?
00:19:58.560 | I want the future to be create me an app, use Remix, Redis and Postgres, have it match the state machine, go and use for this UI library, and then host it in my cloud.
00:20:10.560 | And then once we get there, I think you're going to kind of be unstoppable.
00:20:14.560 | You're going to be able to go and say, you know what, I'm going to go in and evaluate all of the vector databases, all of the embedding kind of models, and everything else that I have to do to actually make this AI product work.
00:20:25.560 | But that's what the future looks like for me.
00:20:27.560 | It's kind of the semantic workspace at the end.
00:20:30.560 | So two, what it is to have reasoning on code.
00:20:34.560 | So what would be for the AI to reason on code?
00:20:37.560 | Well, our brain has the ability to actually do reasoning very well, by the way, and it does that through summarization many times.
00:20:44.560 | So here's an example.
00:20:46.560 | Let's try this.
00:20:47.560 | So imagine you need to add a feature flag in a code base you're not familiar with.
00:20:51.560 | What would you search for?
00:20:52.560 | Like, just ask yourself that right now and try to see what your brain gives you back.
00:20:57.560 | Okay.
00:20:58.560 | Congratulations, you just did rag on your brain.
00:21:01.560 | That's what you did.
00:21:03.560 | You went and you ended up putting a bunch of things together and into a query string.
00:21:08.560 | And let me tell you, your brain is freaking phenomenal at that.
00:21:12.560 | The AI that we have today, not even close.
00:21:15.560 | If not, I could retire probably.
00:21:17.560 | So, but your brain is really good.
00:21:19.560 | So we're going to have to think about what it actually means to actually do summarization that fast with high quality to advance this going forward.
00:21:27.560 | So here's another one, another test.
00:21:29.560 | So this, many of you, if not all of you, are going to see a blue car.
00:21:33.560 | There's actually not a shade of blue in there.
00:21:35.560 | There is -- the car is gray.
00:21:37.560 | But your brain putting blue there because it knows that it needs to -- you know, it thinks that it's overexposed and it adds a little bit of that for you.
00:21:44.560 | You're used to strawberries being, you know, red, et cetera, et cetera.
00:21:48.560 | So it adds that.
00:21:49.560 | So this is what it might look like in the future as you reason through code.
00:21:54.560 | And Amelia, who is a speaker that is coming, I think, two after this, did this project while she was at GitHub.
00:22:00.560 | But think about a little bit more about what does it mean to actually have these broken down into many parts and then be able to reason and summarize them very quickly.
00:22:10.560 | So I'm very excited.
00:22:11.560 | We're doing a lot of -- I would say the GitHub Next team is doing a lot of innovation in that space as well.
00:22:16.560 | So think about, you know, a model, architectural, advancing in rags, and then visualizations to help you with reasoning on code.
00:22:26.560 | What's problem number three?
00:22:27.560 | So what does it look like to create software together with a copilot and others?
00:22:32.560 | A lot of the UX that you have today was not meant to have an AI collaborator.
00:22:39.560 | That's why we're all trying to put a sidebar with a chat thing on it.
00:22:44.560 | It's because, like, the paradigms today, that's kind of what they could afford.
00:22:47.560 | But that's not what the future should be if AI is really going to be with you, helping you get something done.

00:23:00.560 | So what I want to get to at the end is something like this.

00:25:22.560 | Our next speaker is the co-founder and CPO of Codium.
00:25:37.560 | Please welcome to the stage, Daddy Credo.
00:25:50.560 | Hey, good morning, everyone.
00:25:54.560 | Let's take a step.
00:25:55.560 | Let's start by taking a step back.
00:25:57.560 | Now, remember GANs, Generative Adversarial Networks.
00:26:02.560 | They represented a very compelling architecture, in my opinion.
00:26:06.560 | Two neural networks working hand-in-hand, one generating and one is the critic in order to
00:26:12.560 | generate high-quality outcomes.
00:26:14.560 | Then came transformers that changed everything.
00:26:19.560 | We dropped the adversarial, and the focus became solely on the generative.
00:26:26.560 | And they became the state-of-the-art for a variety of use cases.
00:26:32.560 | But code is very, very nuanced.
00:26:36.560 | We believe that in order to generate code that actually works as intended, the right
00:26:42.560 | architecture is actually GAN-like architecture.
00:26:47.560 | And what I mean by that is not the actual neural network.
00:26:50.560 | It's the system.
00:26:52.560 | It's the concept of having two different components.
00:26:56.560 | One focused on the code generation piece, and one that serves as the critic.
00:27:02.560 | We call it the code integrity component.
00:27:05.560 | It actually analyzes the outcomes, the generation of the code gen component.
00:27:10.560 | And it reviews it.
00:27:12.560 | It analyzes it.
00:27:13.560 | It tries to figure out all the different edge cases in order to generate high-quality code
00:27:19.560 | that works as intended, based on the developer's actual intent.
00:27:24.560 | This is our focus at Codium AI.
00:27:27.560 | On the critic piece.
00:27:29.560 | We help developers understand the behaviors of their code.
00:27:33.560 | We believe that behavior coverage is a more useful metric than actual code coverage.
00:27:42.560 | We help them generate tests for these behaviors.
00:27:45.560 | Enhance their code and review their code.
00:27:48.560 | And we do that throughout the developer lifecycle.
00:27:51.560 | leveraging our IDE extensions for both JetBrains and VS Code.
00:27:57.560 | And our Git plugin.
00:28:00.560 | And then soon in the future, in the near future, we will also offer APIs for this.
00:28:05.560 | To be able to be embedded in various agents.
00:28:08.560 | So, we're going to focus the majority of the time in a live demo.
00:28:14.560 | Which is a risky thing to do in this situation here.
00:28:19.560 | but let's go for it.
00:28:34.560 | Okay, I'm here in my VS Code.
00:28:36.560 | I have the Codium AI extension installed.
00:28:38.560 | We now have around 200,000 installs across both JetBrains and VS Code.
00:28:42.560 | I have here an open source project that's called Autoscraper.
00:28:49.560 | It's basically a scraping class that automates the process of generating the rules for scraping information from websites.
00:28:58.560 | It's a very cool project.
00:29:00.560 | It has more than 5,000 GitHub stars.
00:29:04.560 | But the problem is that it doesn't have any tests.
00:29:07.560 | So, it's very hard to make changes to a project where it doesn't have any tests.
00:29:13.560 | Because there's nothing that protects you from making changes.
00:29:17.560 | So, I'm going to go ahead here and trigger Codium AI on this class.
00:29:21.560 | This is a 600-line class.
00:29:23.560 | Complex code.
00:29:25.560 | And you can see that I can trigger Codium AI either on the class level or at the method level.
00:29:29.560 | So, I'm starting on the class.
00:29:32.560 | I'm actually going to re-trigger it.
00:29:36.560 | The first thing that happens is that Codium analyzes the class.
00:29:41.560 | It basically maps out different behaviors.
00:29:44.560 | And it starts generating tests.
00:29:46.560 | You can see it starts streaming the tests.
00:29:49.560 | I already have one, two.
00:29:51.560 | I'm getting more tests.
00:29:52.560 | You can see some of them are quite complex.
00:29:54.560 | It also generates a code explanation.
00:29:57.560 | Detailed code explanation.
00:29:58.560 | That shows me how this class actually works.
00:30:00.560 | The example usage.
00:30:02.560 | The different components.
00:30:04.560 | The methods.
00:30:05.560 | Very detailed.
00:30:07.560 | And then I have all my tests.
00:30:10.560 | As you can see, we look at different examples.
00:30:17.560 | both happy path, edge cases, variety of cases.
00:30:30.560 | Okay.
00:30:31.560 | So, here I have the different behaviors that were generated.
00:30:35.560 | Now, this is crucial.
00:30:36.560 | We're basically mapping the different behaviors of this class.
00:30:40.560 | Doing both happy path, edge cases.
00:30:42.560 | And for each one of them, we can drill deeper down.
00:30:45.560 | And see the sub behaviors below them.
00:30:47.560 | And we can generate tests for anyone that is important for us.
00:30:50.560 | So, let's pick a few and add additional tests.
00:30:55.560 | Let's pick some edge cases as well.
00:30:58.560 | Let's generate a test here.
00:30:59.560 | Maybe here we'll generate another one for an edge case.
00:31:05.560 | And you can see it's very simple.
00:31:07.560 | A few clicks.
00:31:08.560 | And I have a test suite that is built out.
00:31:11.560 | I already have nine tests here.
00:31:13.560 | The next step would be to run these tests.
00:31:15.560 | So, let's go ahead and do that.
00:31:20.560 | So, I'm hitting run and auto fix.
00:31:24.560 | You can see some of these very complex tests are actually passing.
00:31:28.560 | And here I have a test that actually failed.
00:31:31.560 | What happens in a failure is that the model actually analyzes, reflects on the failure,
00:31:37.560 | and then it tries to generate a fix in an automated manner.
00:31:41.560 | So, we have a fix generated.
00:31:45.560 | And now it's going to be run.
00:31:50.560 | And it passed in a second try.
00:31:52.560 | So, this is this chain of thought.
00:31:55.560 | This reflection process in order to get to a high-quality test suite.
00:31:59.560 | Okay.
00:32:00.560 | So, I'm going to start with these eight tests.
00:32:04.560 | Let's open them as a file.
00:32:06.560 | I'm going to save them.
00:32:10.560 | I'm going to save them in my project.
00:32:25.560 | And done.
00:32:26.560 | I have a test suite that now protects me.
00:32:29.560 | So, now I'm going to go ahead and take the next step.
00:32:33.560 | Let's use Codium AI to actually enhance this code.
00:32:36.560 | Now that I have a test suite that protects me.
00:32:39.560 | So, I'm going to choose a method here.
00:32:42.560 | The build method.
00:32:43.560 | That has a lot of the main functionality of the class.
00:32:46.560 | I'm going to trigger Codium AI on that.
00:32:50.560 | And now let's focus on the code suggestions component of Codium AI.
00:32:59.560 | So, Codium analyzes this code.
00:33:01.560 | And it basically recommends different improvements, enhancements.
00:33:06.560 | And these are deep enhancements.
00:33:08.560 | We're not talking about linting or things like that.
