00:38:53.560 | Ladies and gentlemen, our next speaker is the chief architect and co-founder of Fixie.ai.
00:39:02.560 | Please welcome, Matt Welsh.
00:39:05.560 | How's everybody doing this morning?
00:39:11.560 | All right?
00:39:12.560 | Yeah?
00:39:13.560 | I can't see anybody past the first two rows.
00:39:15.560 | So, I assume you're all there.
00:39:17.560 | Now, I know what you're all thinking.
00:39:18.560 | I look way better in person than that AI-generated headshot, right?
00:39:22.560 | Well, we're going to work on that.
00:39:25.560 | We're going to, you know, the AI models are not perfect yet, but we'll get there.
00:39:28.560 | I need the clicker.
00:39:29.560 | Did that?
00:39:30.560 | Oh, it's up here.
00:39:31.560 | Awesome.
00:39:32.560 | All right.
00:39:33.560 | Well, today I'm super excited to talk to you about what we've been working on at Fixie for
00:39:37.560 | a while, which is an open source framework for building what we call reactive AI applications,
00:39:43.560 | called AI.jsx.
00:39:46.560 | So, let's get into it.
00:39:48.560 | First of all, what's the problem we're trying to solve?
00:39:50.560 | Well, I think most of us here know this already, but building and deploying high-quality LLM apps is still super hard.
00:39:58.560 | It's a lot of pieces you've got to worry about.
00:40:01.560 | You've got your vector databases, your context window limits, your rag stack, your tool sets, all that stuff.
00:40:07.560 | Now, most of us in this room enjoy solving those problems.
00:40:11.560 | That's why we're here.
00:40:12.560 | But we think most developers probably would rather not have to solve these problems themselves, so we want to do this for them.
00:40:20.560 | So, at Fixie, we are aiming to solve this problem by inventing the future of AI application development.
00:40:31.560 | Today, I'm going to be announcing something that I think everyone here will agree is the most revolutionary technology in the AI development landscape.
00:40:42.560 | It is going to change the way we all think about building AI-powered applications.
00:40:47.560 | It's going to blow you all away.
00:40:49.560 | And so, ladies and gentlemen, may I introduce to you the future of AI application development.
00:40:58.560 | Imagine the 2001 theme playing, dun-dun-dun-dun-dun-dun.
00:41:03.560 | Angle brackets.
00:41:05.560 | This is the future.
00:41:06.560 | Yes.
00:41:08.560 | There was supposed to be sound with that.
00:41:11.560 | That's all right.
00:41:12.560 | Okay.
00:41:13.560 | It was better with the sound.
00:41:15.560 | All right.
00:41:16.560 | So, this is AI JSX, and I'm going to talk about this a bit.
00:41:20.560 | Think about this as elegant LLM development for, you know, a more civilized age in TypeScript.
00:41:27.560 | Okay.
00:41:28.560 | So, before I get into what AI JSX is, you might be wondering why TypeScript, right?
00:41:32.560 | Well, we believe that there are many front-end and full-stack devs that are just -- they don't have good tools for building AI-powered applications today.
00:41:41.560 | There's some stuff, right?
00:41:44.560 | But we also think that the AI devs -- the front-end devs are the ones building the AI experiences of the future.
00:41:51.560 | But today, they're kind of like that bear staring in the window, right?
00:41:55.560 | They're saying, "Hey, we want a piece of the action.
00:41:57.560 | We want to get involved in AI development."
00:41:59.560 | But it's all the Python devs that are in the back-end that are having all the fun here, right?
00:42:03.560 | So, why should the Python devs have all the fun?
00:42:06.560 | There's also a lot more JavaScript developers in the world than there are Python developers.
00:42:10.560 | So, we think that helping this community that hasn't been well-served so far makes a lot of sense.
00:42:16.560 | So, without AI JSX, this is what an AI engineer looks like today.
00:42:22.560 | I think I met that guy out in the hall yesterday.
00:42:25.560 | But with AI JSX, we can all be Hacker Man or Hacker Woman.
00:42:30.560 | Yes.
00:42:31.560 | All right.
00:42:32.560 | So, get ready.
00:42:34.560 | I'm going to rock you with this whole presentation on this.
00:42:37.560 | Okay.
00:42:38.560 | So, let's just show a hello world of AI JSX.
00:42:41.560 | It's a very simple example.
00:42:42.560 | What we're doing here is defining a complete application that uses a chat completion component.
00:42:50.560 | That's the foundation of anything that might call into an LLM.
00:42:54.560 | And we're providing it a user message prompt in the form of, you know, write a Shakespearean sonnet about large language models.
00:43:03.560 | You might get a result something like this.
00:43:05.560 | It's actually pretty good.
00:43:07.560 | That's a hello world though.
00:43:09.560 | That's very simple.
00:43:10.560 | But let's talk a little bit about what AI JSX is.
00:43:14.560 | Think about it like React, but for building LLM apps.
00:43:18.560 | My colleague at Fixie pointed out to me that we actually have a page on our documentation site that says that AI JSX is not React.
00:43:28.560 | But clearly that's wrong because here I am telling you it is.
00:43:30.560 | Anyway, so AI JSX, it's built in TypeScript, which means you get all the safety and performance of JavaScript with the exciting adventure of fucking around with your dev tooling.
00:43:43.560 | Any model, any provider, we can support both Anthropic and OpenAI.
00:43:53.560 | Full React integration.
00:43:54.560 | This is great for building full stack applications where you just want to drop your AI powered stuff into your React app.
00:44:00.560 | AI JSX supports RAG, out of the box, uses multiple vector DBs behind the scenes.
00:44:07.560 | You can plug in your own as well.
00:44:09.560 | You can use it to invoke custom tools and APIs.
00:44:13.560 | So you can use AI JSX in situations where you want to invoke an external service or an API.
00:44:20.560 | One of the cool features of AI JSX is the ability to have the AI generate UI components for you.
00:44:27.560 | Because the AI JSX program is operating on effectively the DOM, if you will, as React components, you can use it to generate UI components.
00:44:37.560 | And, of course, it's fully programmable and extensible, so you can basically build whatever you want.
00:44:43.560 | I'm going to give you a whirlwind tour of all this, show you what's possible.
00:44:47.560 | Basic idea is you build components, just like you do in React.
00:44:53.560 | Here I'm defining a component called makeSetting.
00:44:56.560 | I could define a setting for a story that we might want to write.
00:44:59.560 | And this component takes in its children elements as a parameter.
00:45:05.560 | And we basically say write a one-paragraph description of this setting and put the children components right there.
00:45:13.560 | Those children components can be anything.
00:45:15.560 | They can be a string, or they can be the result of a different tree of JSX nodes that have been rendered.
00:45:22.560 | And placed in line in that prompt.
00:45:25.560 | So to call it, all I need to do is say, take the makeSetting component, instantiate it, and give it the prompt that I want.
00:45:33.560 | Okay, it's pretty cool, very easy to use.
00:45:37.560 | But you might be saying to yourself, come on, this is basically writing Python code with different syntax, right?
00:45:45.560 | This is -- the angle brackets are a little bit overplayed here.
00:45:50.560 | But it's not just about syntax, right?
00:45:53.560 | JSX defines an entire tree of nodes that are rendered as a stream asynchronously and in parallel.
00:46:02.560 | So instead of rendering to the DOM like React does, we're rendering effectively to the LLM, if you will.
00:46:11.560 | So this allows us to do extremely powerful forms of composition.
00:46:15.560 | So here's a simple example of writing a story where I have a makeStory component with three child components.
00:46:23.560 | One is defining the character, another is defining the setting, and a third is defining the plot.
00:46:30.560 | So, when we render this application, all three of those components are going to run in parallel.
00:46:38.560 | And they're all streaming in parallel.
00:46:40.560 | There's three concurrent LLM calls going on, and they're streaming their tokens back to the makeStory component in real time.
00:46:51.560 | And so, as this is being rendered, all the tokens are streaming through, the makeStory component is then streaming its output out to the result of that render, which might result in a story that looks like this.
00:47:03.560 | So far, I'm just showing you some basic things with text to give you some intuition around the ideas.
00:47:10.560 | But, of course, you can take this a lot further.
00:47:12.560 | One thing you might say about this tree-based structure in AIJSX is that it allows you to break free of your chains.
00:47:22.560 | Sorry, I know that was a groaner.
00:47:24.560 | Okay, sorry.
00:47:25.560 | Okay, so here's another example of what you might be able to do.
00:47:31.560 | Let's wrap one component in another in order to constrain the latter component's output.
00:47:38.560 | So we're going to define a kid-safe component.
00:47:40.560 | This component takes in a system message that says rewrite the following text so it's safe for kids.
00:47:46.560 | And the child components of that component are placed into the user message of that prompt.
00:47:53.560 | Then when we just wrap any component we want in a kid-safe component, it automatically will rewrite the output to be kid-safe.
00:48:02.560 | So very, very powerful composition.
00:48:07.560 | Let me show you a quick example of how you use AIJSX to call out to tools and third-party APIs.
00:48:13.560 | In this case, we're going to define a record which is a set of tools that we want to give the LLM access to.
00:48:19.560 | We're just going to define one tool here.
00:48:22.560 | It's a tool that calls the GitHub GraphQL API.
00:48:26.560 | And we're going to give it an English description of the tool.
00:48:30.560 | And there's a JavaScript function there.
00:48:32.560 | I've taken out the code for the JavaScript function because that's not interesting for this talk.
00:48:37.560 | So that's just calling using the Fetch API to call the GraphQL endpoint at GitHub.
00:48:41.560 | To use the tool in an application then, all I have to do is instantiate a useTools component, give it that set of tools, and then anything that might need to use those tools as part of the rendering process can now invoke them.
00:48:58.560 | And so I can build very powerful applications in this way.
00:49:01.560 | This is RAG, retrieval augmented generation, in something like 10 lines of code.
00:49:09.560 | In AIJSX, we have a chat completion.
00:49:12.560 | There's two children of that, the system message and the user message.
00:49:16.560 | The system message says, use the following information to answer the user's query.
00:49:20.560 | And it gets that information by using a DocsQA component.
00:49:25.560 | The DocsQA component is configured with a corpus of documents that you've crawled and indexed and placed in a vector database.
00:49:32.560 | You provide the user's query.
00:49:35.560 | The DocsQA component returns the chunks that are relevant to that query.
00:49:40.560 | Places them right there in the system message.
00:49:45.560 | And then the user message contains the query again.
00:49:47.560 | And the final result is you effectively have retrieval augmented generation.
00:49:52.560 | I think this is a lot easier to understand, it's a lot easier to manipulate, it's a lot easier to integrate with other applications when expressed this way, rather than have a whole lot of different libraries that you have to invoke.
00:50:09.560 | And then finally, when you're done building an AIJSX application and you want to place it into your website or your web app or your mobile app or whatever it is, you can just drop it right in as a React component.
00:50:21.560 | So in this case we're showing you use the floating fixie embed component that when you instantiate this gives you a fully rendered UI for your AIJSX application with a chat window, with session management, markdown, rendering, custom UI, all the things that you might want out of such a thing in effectively one line of code.
00:50:44.560 | I've been talking a lot about AIJSX as an open source project, of course, I'm standing in front of you as a founder of a startup, so we've got to make money somehow.
00:50:57.560 | And so we're talking about the fixie platform as a really effective way to take AIJSX applications and host them and run them and manage them in the cloud.
00:51:09.560 | So we make it really easy to build and deploy these things.
00:51:12.560 | The fixie cloud service has a fully managed RAG pipeline that does document ingestion, chunking, embedding, vector database, document storage and all of the things that you need there.
00:51:24.560 | It fully manages the conversational state between the end user and the agent that you've built so that you can have full context as part of that interaction with the user.
00:51:36.560 | We provide interfaces to all the popular LLMs and those are really tuned for high performance and low latency so that we get really good performance out of this.
00:51:45.560 | You can build your applications either in a no code way completely in the web UI here or you can use AIJSX to build a completely custom thing.
00:51:57.560 | And as I showed earlier, embedding it on your website is super easy.
00:52:01.560 | So that's the fixie platform.
00:52:04.560 | Right.
00:52:05.560 | So with that, you know, I'd encourage you all to try it out.
00:52:08.560 | Just go to fixie.ai.
00:52:09.560 | You can sign up.
00:52:10.560 | It's free to start out.
00:52:12.560 | Start building.
00:52:13.560 | AIJSX is open source.
00:52:15.560 | You can use that without using fixie if you want.
00:52:17.560 | So go check that out.
00:52:19.560 | I'd really, really love to get your feedback and hear more about what you want to build and what kind of things you want to do.
00:52:25.560 | But one more thing.
00:52:30.560 | This is invoking, of course, Steve.
00:52:35.560 | Another thing we built with AIJSX is the ability to support real-time voice interaction.
00:52:40.560 | That means bi-directional.
00:52:42.560 | You can speak to the agent and it can speak back to you.
00:52:46.560 | And we've done a ton of work to make the performance as just incredible, just amazing as possible.
00:52:52.560 | If you've seen the ChatGPT voice demos that they did last week or so, there's something like a four- or five-second gap after you talk to it and it talks back to you.
00:53:02.560 | I'm going to show you a demo in a moment that I think will be fairly impressive.
00:53:09.560 | So we get state-of-the-art performance, real-time, bi-directional conversations.
00:53:13.560 | And, of course, it's all grounded on your docs and your data.
00:53:16.560 | So I'm not foolish enough with the Wi-Fi that's here to do a live demo.
00:53:21.560 | So, fortunately, our CTO, Justin, recorded a video of this.
00:53:25.560 | But I want to assure you that nothing in this video is staged.
00:53:29.560 | Nothing has been trimmed out.
00:53:30.560 | Nothing has been sped up.
00:53:32.560 | This is real-time, you know, live video recording from yesterday.
00:53:36.560 | And you can try it out yourself at voice.fixie.ai.
00:53:39.560 | If you don't believe me, just go try it on your own machine.
00:53:42.560 | Not now.
00:53:43.560 | Not here, please.
00:53:45.560 | But the idea of this demo is we have a fictional donut restaurant called Dr. Donut.
00:53:53.560 | And you're at the drive-thru.
00:53:54.560 | You drive up in your Tesla or whatever you're driving.
00:53:57.560 | Roll down the window and you're talking to the drive-thru window at the Dr. Donut.
00:54:01.560 | And the AI is acting to take your order.
00:54:05.560 | And so with that, I'm going to see if this works.
00:54:07.560 | Hopefully, we have sound on the video.
00:54:09.560 | And let's take it away.
00:54:11.560 | Welcome to Dr. Donut, home of the best donuts in town.
00:54:15.560 | How can I help you?
00:54:17.560 | Yeah.
00:54:18.560 | Can I get two of the pumpkin spice ice donuts?
00:54:21.560 | Sure.
00:54:24.560 | I've added two pumpkin spice ice donuts to your order.
00:54:27.560 | Can I assist you with anything else?
00:54:29.560 | Uh, what's your best coffee?
00:54:31.560 | Our pumpkin spice coffee is a popular choice this season.
00:54:38.560 | Our caramel macchiato is a favorite all year round.
00:54:41.560 | Which one would you prefer?
00:54:43.560 | Yeah, let's go with two of the macchiatos.
00:54:45.560 | Great.
00:54:48.560 | I've added two caramel macchiatos to your order.
00:54:51.560 | Can I get you anything else?
00:54:53.560 | Yeah.
00:54:55.560 | What are your thoughts on large language models?
00:54:57.560 | Sir, this is a Dr. Donut.
00:55:02.560 | Uh, okay.
00:55:04.560 | Just the donuts and the coffee, then.
00:55:06.560 | Sure.
00:55:07.560 | Sure.
00:55:10.560 | Your order is two pumpkin spice ice donuts and two caramel macchiatos.
00:55:14.560 | The total is $9.56.
00:55:17.560 | Please pull up to the next window.
00:55:19.560 | And that was all, like, you can go try it yourself.
00:55:22.560 | Um, we've done a ton of work to make the latency really low, to make the quality really high.
00:55:26.560 | It's using the full FIXI platform as a back end.
00:55:29.560 | And, of course, if you're building with FIXI and AI JSX, you can build the same thing for yourself.
00:55:33.560 | Uh, donuts or not, right?
00:55:35.560 | Okay.
00:55:36.560 | So, that's basically all I have.
00:55:38.560 | I'd really love to get you all to check it out.
00:55:41.560 | We are, of course, hiring.
00:55:42.560 | And so, there's our careers page.
00:55:44.560 | And, uh, please, uh, you know, don't forget to smash that like button.
00:55:47.560 | Thank you very much.
00:55:48.560 | Please welcome to the stage our next speaker.
00:56:10.560 | She designs AI at ADEPT.
00:56:13.560 | Amelia Wattenberger.
00:56:16.560 | Alright, hey everybody.
00:56:31.560 | I want to start with a question.
00:56:33.560 | Does anybody remember what accounting looked like in the early 1900s?
00:56:38.560 | Yeah, me neither.
00:56:40.560 | But, from what I gather, it was super frustrating.
00:56:43.560 | I'm having some trouble with the connection.
00:56:44.560 | And tedious.
00:56:45.560 | And it involved a lot of, like, writing letters and numbers, uh, annotating in margins, performing calculations by hand.
00:56:53.560 | Um, you can probably look at these pages and sense how frustrating it is by looking at how many things are crossed out and all the inkblots on the page.
00:57:01.560 | So, thankfully, this isn't how the job's done these days.
00:57:05.560 | So, in 1979, PhysiCalc totally changed the game.
00:57:08.560 | And this was the first spreadsheet for personal computers.
00:57:12.560 | It became an essential tool for accountants, at least until Lotus 1-2-3 was launched, uh, four years later.
00:57:19.560 | And the innovation here wasn't performing the calculations automatically.
00:57:23.560 | We already had calculators and computers to do that for us.
00:57:27.560 | But instead, the innovation was having the structured interface that stacked those automatic calculations together into formulas, so that when you change the value of a cell or you add a row to your spreadsheet, uh, all of the spreadsheet numbers would be updated live.
00:57:43.560 | So instead of spending all day doing calculations or manually updating the rows and columns, accountants could now spend more time, uh, worrying about the actual numbers.
00:57:54.560 | Okay.
00:57:55.560 | Okay.
00:57:56.560 | Fortunately or unfortunately, this isn't a spreadsheet conference, so let's get back to talking about AI.
00:58:01.560 | So, one of the things I'm most interested in is what are the best ways to combine our new AI superpowers with the interfaces that we use today?
00:58:11.560 | Or more importantly, the interfaces that we want to use tomorrow?
00:58:16.560 | So often when people talk about building interfaces with AI, they refer to these two distinct poles, whether it's automation or augmentation.
00:58:26.560 | In essence, automation takes rote tests and does them for the user, which is really great for anything that's super tedious or boring, like copy and pasting data into a table or doing calculations by hand.
00:58:38.560 | And in contrast, augmentation gives the user a new ability or improves their existing abilities, which is awesome for things that are creative or nuanced, things we don't really trust models with yet, uh, like analyzing data.
00:58:51.560 | And I think this contrast often ignores how related these two concepts really are.
00:58:58.560 | Um, automation has become a bit of a buzzword, um, or a trigger word where people are worried about their jobs being automated.
00:59:07.560 | And I think this is a very valid concern, and I kind of want to reframe this dichotomy.
00:59:15.560 | So, uh, instead, I think augmentation is composed of smaller automations.
00:59:21.560 | If our end goal is to augment tasks or jobs, we'll still need to automate parts of them.
00:59:26.560 | So, for example, if the end goal is analyzing data, automating the smaller tasks like aggregating the data into a table or generating visualizations from that table are going to help focus on your end goal.
00:59:36.560 | which is answering the question that motivated the data collection in the first place.
00:59:43.560 | So if we go back to our spreadsheet example, we can think of each cell, the calculations that, uh, that create them as having been automated away.
00:59:54.560 | And no one really thinks of spreadsheets as taking people's jobs.
00:59:57.560 | Instead, uh, Excel, what I'm showing here, which is kind of like the current king of spreadsheets, uh, is an essential tool for people who interact with things like financial data.
01:00:09.560 | If we automate these parts behind the scenes, uh, that's the first step towards achieving the goal of augmenting, uh, working with data.
01:00:18.560 | So in the future, we can easily imagine having this table aggregated automatically or writing the formulas for us.
01:00:24.560 | And having all of this work done helps augment us in our greater goal of analyzing and understanding the data.
01:00:31.560 | Um, this is one of the reasons why you might hear me say some things like chatbots aren't necessarily the future.
01:00:37.560 | Um, I think that these flexible general tools like calculators and chatbots are wonderful, but then adding the structured interface around them makes them so much more powerful for a ton of different use cases.
01:00:50.560 | What we want is something where the technology behind chatbots is embedded into the interfaces where we're still driving, but the models automating away the smaller tests that we find so frustrating.
01:01:01.560 | So what might these interfaces look like?
01:01:04.560 | Before answering that question, I want to introduce one more concept, the ladder of abstraction.
01:01:10.560 | So that basic idea here is that the exact same object can be represented at many different levels of detail.
01:01:17.560 | So I think maps are a good example of this.
01:01:19.560 | Um, we take this interface for granted, but Google Maps and other digital maps are incredibly compelling interfaces.
01:01:26.560 | They're so well designed, um, and they help represent different tasks involving navigation and localization at different scales.
01:01:34.560 | So here we are at the most zoomed in scale, and we can see all of the different structures within the Monterey Bay Aquarium.
01:01:40.560 | We can see individual buildings, the names, the icons for them, maybe routes between the buildings.
01:01:46.560 | And this is great for navigating around the aquarium, but maybe not so great for getting to the aquarium.
01:01:52.560 | As we zoom out, all of these buildings get smaller because they're further away, but that's not the only thing that happens.
01:02:01.560 | So at these more zoomed out levels, Google Maps actually starts hiding information.
01:02:07.560 | So I can't see the buildings inside of the aquarium anymore, or their icons or names, but instead I can see city streets and different restaurants.
01:02:17.560 | And this will support a different set of tasks, like finding a restaurant or destination and getting to that place.
01:02:24.560 | So zooming out even further, we lose those city streets and stores, and instead we look at highways and terrain.
01:02:30.560 | And again, we have a different task here.
01:02:32.560 | This level supports longer range travel, getting to and from Monterey.
01:02:37.560 | And then if we go all the way out, we're mostly looking at the shape of states or countries.
01:02:43.560 | So if we tried to keep all of that information at higher zoom levels, it would be completely incomprehensible.
01:02:49.560 | There's really only so much information we can fit in our brains and so many pixels on a screen.
01:02:56.560 | And most of that detail isn't relevant for the task we're trying to do anyway.
01:03:00.560 | So you could wonder, can we use AI to bring these kinds of principles to other types of interfaces?
01:03:08.560 | For example, what would happen if I zoomed out on a book?
01:03:13.560 | What would that even look like?
01:03:15.560 | Typically when we read a book, we're looking at every single word, but that's not the only level we think about.
01:03:23.560 | When remembering books we've read in the past or summarizing a book for a friend, we're more concerned with overall topics and plots than specific wording.
01:03:31.560 | And now that we have access to language models, which are amazing at summarizing and transforming text,
01:03:37.560 | how can we use them to change the way we read and write?
01:03:40.560 | So here's a quick demo I put together of the first five chapters of Peter Pan.
01:03:47.560 | And there's no tricks here.
01:03:50.560 | I'm just scrolling through the first chapter.
01:03:52.560 | So if we take this and we use an LLM to zoom out, we can see each paragraph change to a one-sentence summary.
01:03:59.560 | And we have a mini-map to the right and you can kind of see how much fewer words there are in the page and how much more quickly I could read this.
01:04:09.560 | If we zoom out another level, we can see summaries of, say, ten paragraphs at once.
01:04:14.560 | And again, you can see on the mini-map, we have way less text to read.
01:04:20.560 | And then finally, at that highest zoom level, we've reduced each chapter in one sentence.
01:04:26.560 | And here, we can fit five chapters on one page.
01:04:29.560 | So if I were writing Peter Pan and I wanted to do something like tweak the pacing or modify the plot structure, viewing the text at this highest zoom level, editing it, and then zooming back in to see how that changed the raw text would be a much nicer workflow than keeping all the parts in your head as you change it word by word.
01:04:49.560 | So another way to think about a book at a high level is with a story arc.
01:04:54.560 | And this describes the mood mapped over an entire story.
01:04:59.560 | You might be familiar with Kurt Vonnegut's graphical representation of the most common story arcs.
01:05:04.560 | For example, we have Man in a Hole, where the main character gets in trouble, gets out of it, and ends up better for the experience, which you'll see in stories like The Hobbit or The Wizard of Oz or Alice in Wonderland.
01:05:18.560 | What if we could take the semantic value of all the sections in a book and plot that on a graph?
01:05:28.560 | And then if we wanted to edit the story, we could go ahead and tweak parts of that graph and see how the raw text change.
01:05:37.560 | I mainly highlight this because I'm super excited to see how we use AI to innovate on writing tools within the next few years.
01:05:45.560 | But first, let's combine the two concepts.
01:05:52.560 | So the first concept is augmentation as stacked automations, and the second concept is traversing the ladder of abstraction for different tasks.
01:05:59.560 | How might this look in a more general product?
01:06:02.560 | So I'm on the design team of a startup here in SF named Adept.
01:06:06.560 | And at Adept, we're focused on training AI to use software, read screens, and take actions the way humans do.
01:06:14.560 | And our end goal is to make knowledge work easier, so any work on a computer.
01:06:18.560 | So after speaking with a lot of people about what they do day to day at their jobs, we found that much of knowledge work involves getting information, transforming our reasoning about it, and then acting on that information.
01:06:31.560 | So given this really common workflow, one of the things we've been thinking about is, what might it mean to zoom out on any piece of information?
01:06:39.560 | So we have some sketches where we're exploring what that might feel like or what it might enable us to do.
01:06:44.560 | I thought it would be really fun to share one of those with you all today.
01:06:47.560 | All right, so completely hypothetical situation.
01:06:51.560 | Let's say I was going to an awesome conference in San Francisco.
01:06:56.560 | What I would do first is I would go to Airbnb, I'd find listings near the venue, I'd click into the detail page of one of the listings, and there's all this generic information that should work for everybody.
01:07:07.560 | But I have specific criteria that will help me decide whether or not it's the right thing to book.
01:07:12.560 | So I'm going to be digging through this page looking for things like how close is it to the venue, is there a coffee maker, does it have good Wi-Fi, that kind of thing.
01:07:23.560 | This kind of decision would be much easier if I could zoom out just a little.
01:07:27.560 | Get rid of all the branding and standard information that isn't really important to me right now, and focus on my deciding factors.
01:07:34.560 | So to start, I can see the name of the listing, maybe the rating, a quick summary, and the total price.
01:07:41.560 | And this is all pretty generic so far, but I know this conference is at the esteemed Hotel Nico, and I'm typically going to be looking at a map to find places near that venue.
01:07:52.560 | But if I could just extract the walking minutes to the hotel, and put that right on the page, that would be really helpful.
01:07:59.560 | And maybe if that's a little bit far, I can figure out what is the closest BART station to the listing, and then add the walk to BART there as well as a backup way to get to the hotel.
01:08:11.560 | Another thing that's really important to me is the Wi-Fi speed.
01:08:15.560 | I know I'm going to be working on my talk the night before, true story, so I'm going to need really fast internet.
01:08:23.560 | So I can use AI to pull out the relevant reviews and summarize them as positive or negative to really quickly judge whether the Wi-Fi is going to work or not.
01:08:30.560 | Additionally, usually, Airbnb has like 50 vanity photos for any given listing, and I really just want one photo of the bedroom or living room or kitchen.
01:08:43.560 | So if I could just pull those out and put them on the page, that would help me a lot.
01:08:47.560 | And then most importantly, at this higher Zoom level, preserving the ability to act on this information.
01:08:54.560 | So directly from this page, I can go ahead and reserve this listing or send a message to the host without going back to Airbnb.
01:09:02.560 | That would be really helpful and keep me in control.
01:09:05.560 | And I never really know whether staying at an Airbnb or a hotel is going to be a better deal, so typically I'll also look at hotel listings.
01:09:13.560 | And it's pretty great to be able to see that same elevated view no matter which site I'm looking at.
01:09:20.560 | Additionally, if I'm going to compare the hotel with the Airbnb listing, having these similar views side-by-side is going to give me a really easy comparison
01:09:31.560 | between the two of them.
01:09:33.560 | But what if I wanted to look at 50 listings?
01:09:36.560 | Comparing 50 of these individual views would still be a lot of work.
01:09:40.560 | Zooming out a level, I can look at a spreadsheet for all 50 listings with my deciding factors all laid out for easy comparison.
01:09:50.560 | So I can quickly eyeball the distribution for total price, get a sense of how quick the walks are for each of the listings,
01:09:58.560 | how many positive Wi-Fi reviews there are.
01:10:00.560 | Importantly, I can still take action on this level.
01:10:03.560 | So if I see a listing that's a clear winner, I can go ahead and book it right here instead of going back to Airbnb or Hotels.com.
01:10:11.560 | But sometimes the decision isn't so clear cut or it's more multifaceted than having the cheapest or the closest listing.
01:10:21.560 | So if I zoom out another level, each listing has been abstracted into a circle on a scatter plot, and these are colored by the Wi-Fi reviews.
01:10:32.560 | You can see the cheapest listings on the left of this plot with the most expensive ones on the right, and the closest ones to the hotel near the bottom.
01:10:41.560 | And I can pretty quickly see that there's this cluster of listings that are the cheapest and the closest, and they also have good Wi-Fi.
01:10:51.560 | But I just realized my flight gets in at 9:00 a.m., but thankfully, I can still initiate actions from this view.
01:10:57.560 | So I can circle these, send a message to all the listings within this cluster, ask them about their policy on early check-ins, and whichever one responds first that I can check in at 11:00 a.m., I'm going to go ahead and book.
01:11:11.560 | All right, so as we saw, there's so many tasks that are best suited by a specific Zoom level.
01:11:17.560 | And what we're currently doing is we're manually abstracting that information in our heads.
01:11:22.560 | So in this example, digging through 50 different Airbnb or hotel listings, we're keeping all of the previous ones in our heads to try to find the best one.
01:11:32.560 | And this takes a lot of mental energy.
01:11:36.560 | I know I titled my talk Climbing the Ladder of Abstraction.
01:11:39.560 | That was partially to not rip off Brett Victor, who has a talk titled Up and Down the Ladder of Abstraction.
01:11:45.560 | It's a great talk.
01:11:47.560 | But I'm not trying to argue that higher levels are better.
01:11:50.560 | Instead, what I'm trying to argue is that we can use AI to generate these different levels, glue them together, and make it easy to move between them.
01:11:59.560 | And I think this could completely change the way that we work with information.
01:12:05.560 | So this is one of the many great explorations we're doing at Adept to make all computer work easier.
01:12:10.560 | We're going to have a lot more to share in the near future.
01:12:13.560 | Stay tuned.
01:12:14.560 | And then to sum up, there's three things that I would love for you to take away from this talk.
01:12:19.560 | The first is augmenting tasks are going to look a lot like automating smaller tedious parts.
01:12:24.560 | No one's thinking of spreadsheets as taking people's jobs, and digital spreadsheets is exactly the kind of innovation that I want to see in the next few years.
01:12:33.560 | Secondly, we often think about information at different levels of abstraction, and let's make this easier by using AI to generate and act on these different levels.
01:12:41.560 | And then lastly, this is the kind of thinking we're doing at Adept.
01:12:45.560 | Feel free to follow us, or follow along, check in, and we're at Adept.ai.
01:12:54.560 | All right.
01:12:55.560 | Thanks for listening.
01:12:56.560 | applause
01:12:57.560 | Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome our next two speakers who co-founded New Computer.
01:13:14.560 | Jason Yuen and Sam Whitmore.
01:13:18.560 | Jason is also the CDO, and Sam is both CEO and CTO.
01:13:22.560 | Hey.
01:13:32.560 | Can you hear us?
01:13:33.560 | Hello.
01:13:34.560 | Hi, everybody.
01:13:35.560 | Thanks for having us here today.
01:13:36.560 | We're super excited to be here.
01:13:38.560 | I'm Sam, and I'm one of the co-founders of New Computer.
01:13:41.560 | And I'm Jason, the other co-founder, and we're really excited that we are starting today by letting you all see our pores up close, which is amazing.
01:13:52.560 | So, you know, when Sam and I started New Computer, we did so because we believed that for so long we've taken certain metaphors and abstractions and tools for granted.
01:14:04.560 | And for the first time in what feels like 40 years, we can finally change all of that, and we can start thinking from first principles what our relationship, not only with computing, but with intelligence, period, should look like in the future.
01:14:19.560 | So, what do we mean by intelligence?
01:14:22.560 | Because, you know, sometimes I'm on the internet and I wonder if it even exists.
01:14:27.560 | Well, one way to think about intelligence is the ability to sort of take in lots of information, different types, different volumes from different sources, visualized as dots here, and sort of find ways to make sense of it all, find ways to reason, find ways to find meaning.
01:14:47.560 | And as human beings, as carbon-based life forms, we do this through a process where, at first, we use our senses to sort of perceive the world around us.
01:14:56.560 | Then we, you know, process that information in our heads, and then, given what we think, we then choose a reaction.
01:15:05.560 | So, if we're lucky, we are blessed with at least five senses, six when I've had four margaritas.
01:15:14.560 | But, as humans, we sort of are inherently capable of just processing all of this at the same time, and that actually is how our short-term memory gets to work.
01:15:27.560 | And taking all of this context and information, we then get to form what's called a theory of mind.
01:15:32.560 | What is going on?
01:15:33.560 | What is, you know, how is the world relating to me right now?
01:15:36.560 | What should I be doing about it?
01:15:37.560 | So, we sense, we think, and then we react.
01:15:42.560 | And how do we react?
01:15:44.560 | Well, there's a lot of things right now.
01:15:47.560 | But if we take it all the way back to the Stone Age, and we think real simple, a lot of how people used to react and communicate is just unintelligible grunts.
01:15:59.560 | And then, one day, that sort of evolved into a language, as we know it.
01:16:04.560 | And, to this day, that's still something that we rely on to communicate and react to the world around us.
01:16:10.560 | And that's also how a lot of us think.
01:16:12.560 | So, we have language.
01:16:15.560 | But the language of communication is so much broader than just language.
01:16:22.560 | We're standing here on stage right now, I'm making eye contact with some of you.
01:16:25.560 | Nice shirt.
01:16:27.560 | And I'm making gestures, I'm wearing these ridiculous gloves, I'm looking at Sam, I'm looking at things, I'm pointing at things.
01:16:32.560 | And I can hear, sort of, laughter, or I can hear people, you know, thinking.
01:16:38.560 | I'm taking lots of information at once.
01:16:40.560 | And, right now, I'm sensing, thinking, and reacting.
01:16:44.560 | So, this year, well, last year, technically, we saw a really amazing thing happen.
01:16:53.560 | I've been to chat GPT, I would say, where we saw the beginnings of a computer start to approximate that same loop, where input was coming in in the form of language.
01:17:03.560 | There was some reasoning process, however that actually works.
01:17:09.560 | And then, the output felt, also, like language coming back to us.
01:17:13.560 | And this was very inspiring to me and Jason.
01:17:15.560 | And we've been spending a lot of time this past year thinking about what's next.
01:17:19.560 | And how this gets to feel even more natural for people to interact with computers, specifically.
01:17:28.560 | And so, today, we wanted to take you on a tour of a few demos.
01:17:32.560 | One, which you can do with the computer right now.
01:17:36.560 | And then, a few, which are kind of with futuristic or next generation hardware, which may be available soon.
01:17:42.560 | And, knowing that you're all engineers, we know that this will kind of get the sparks flowing, the ideas flowing, for seeing how, like, you might use some of these things that are coming out soon, or things that exist today, to build things that feel more natural.
01:17:57.560 | So, I'll start by getting to a demo.
01:18:02.560 | And I will say, this is a live audio-visual demo.
01:18:06.560 | So, I am foolish enough to make that choice.
01:18:09.560 | So, we will see how it goes.
01:18:11.560 | Before we show any demos, it's prudent to point out that none of these represent the product we are building.
01:18:19.560 | They are simply pieces, stories, inspiration.
01:18:25.560 | So, the point of this first demo is to imagine we have a lot of things where we're saying, like, okay, is text the right input?
01:18:32.560 | Is audio the right input?
01:18:34.560 | And we've been thinking about, it's not if those are the right things, but when.
01:18:42.560 | So, in this case, you'll see some measurements happening on the left here.
01:18:45.560 | What's actually happening is that this has access to my camera, and it's taking real-time pose measurements of where I am relative to the screen.
01:18:55.560 | I just, it knows I'm at the keyboard, basically, because it's making that assessment.
01:18:58.560 | And you can see the reasoning in the side here, where it's saying, user is close to screen, we'll use keyboard input.
01:19:03.560 | User is facing screen, we'll use text output.
01:19:06.560 | And so, this, we're using an LLM to actually make that choice as it goes to the response.
01:19:10.560 | So, let's try something else.
01:19:12.560 | And again, demo gods be nice, because this may not work at all.
01:19:16.560 | But, if I now walk away, and it doesn't detect me anymore, it should now actually start listening to me.
01:19:23.560 | Hello?
01:19:24.560 | Can you hear me?
01:19:26.560 | Are you going to respond?
01:19:27.560 | I think that's a no.
01:19:30.560 | It might not respond.
01:19:31.560 | But, basically, what we are attempting to build here is, like, if I want to actually talk to the computer in a really natural way,
01:19:41.560 | like, if I'm there, next to the keyboard, I should not, it should not be paying attention to my voice or any sounds, ambient sounds.
01:19:49.560 | And if I walk away from the keyboard, I might want to have a conversation with it, like, walk around the room.
01:19:54.560 | It is listening.
01:19:56.560 | It seems to not, to be decided not to actually talk back.
01:19:59.560 | But, oh, it's talking.
01:20:08.560 | Is there something you need help for?
01:20:09.560 | That sounds like an interesting project, Samantha.
01:20:11.560 | How is your talk going so far?
01:20:12.560 | Yay!
01:20:13.560 | Yes, you can see it paid attention, and it decided to ignore me for a while.
01:20:25.560 | But, anyway, this is just like a toy demo.
01:20:31.560 | As you can see here, we have, this is how it's working kind of behind the scenes.
01:20:35.560 | It's like trying to decide if I'm close to the keyboard, facing the screen, not facing the screen.
01:20:41.560 | And use that all as inputs to decide whether it should talk to me or just display the text as on the interface.
01:20:49.560 | Cool.
01:20:52.560 | The reason why we think this is interesting is because we think, you know, people are naturally sensitive to other people.
01:21:00.560 | And we think computers, instead of asking people to adapt to computers, to be like, come up to me and type and whatever, should find ways to try to adapt to circumstances and context of people.
01:21:16.560 | Exactly.
01:21:17.560 | So, again, here, it's like, in this case, it's adapting to where I am by using the pose detection, whether or not I'm actually in the process of talking to it to decide to update its own world state, use an LLM to actually do that, and then use the LLM to respond using the knowledge of that world state.
01:21:34.560 | And so, this is a really simple and, as you can see, kind of hacky demo that is something you could build today.
01:21:41.560 | In theory, you could imagine how this could be, like, a really cool native way to interact with an LLM on your computer where you don't have to worry about the input monality at all.
01:21:49.560 | So, again, takeaways are consider, like, explicit inputs, what I'm typing, what I'm saying, along with implicit, where I am.
01:21:57.560 | There's other things you could do with that, like tone and emotion detection.
01:22:02.560 | You could plug in a whole bunch of different signals that you want to extract from that.
01:22:06.560 | So, you can even imagine if I'm in the frame with Sam, and the agent knows Sam, and she had recently been complaining about me, I should probably not bring that up until I leave the frame.
01:22:16.560 | Yeah.
01:22:17.560 | And, as we mentioned that, using it as a reasoning engine, and then, next one, cool.
01:22:23.560 | And, yeah, and then we're adapting.
01:22:25.560 | So, we want to get to the futuristic stuff.
01:22:27.560 | Jason has been spending a lot of time imagining this, so he's going to walk you through a few things that might exist shortly in the near future when new hardware comes out.
01:22:36.560 | So, when we think future, we still think the sensing-thinking-react loop will take place.
01:22:42.560 | To preface all of this, these are my personal speculative fictions, not representative of anything that I think might actually happen.
01:22:52.560 | And this is a very conservative view of the next one to twelve months, maybe.
01:22:57.560 | So, it's not a true future-future AGI god-worshipping type situation.
01:23:02.560 | So, let's start with what I call, like, a social interface.
01:23:06.560 | We're all really excited about, you know, certain headsets being released at certain points.
01:23:11.560 | And, one thing that I think is interesting about some headsets is they have sensors, and they have hand-tracking and eye-tracking.
01:23:19.560 | And, just like how I'm being expressive right now, maybe there comes a day where I can be such with a computer that sort of lives with me.
01:23:28.560 | So, here I am in my apartment minding my own business, and my ex decides to FaceTime me, and now I've declined the call.
01:23:42.560 | You know, historically, with deterministic interfaces, I would have had to, like, find the hang-up button, or go, like, "Hey Alexa, decline call," like, thinking commands, thinking computer-speak.
01:23:55.560 | But, like, as a person, I can be like, "Fuck off." You know, I can be like, "I'm busy." I can be like, "I'm sick." You know, like, all of this stuff, the computer should be able to interpret for me and, you know, send, send, what's his name again, toxic trashiest, whatever, on his merry way.
01:24:11.560 | So, explicit social gestures can be a great way to determine user intent, like the way I just showed now.
01:24:17.560 | But we should also consider interpreting implicit gestures. If I give a really fast gesture with a slow gesture, my mood, my tone, how far away I am.
01:24:26.560 | But we should also be conscious of social-cultural norms, different gestures mean different things in different societies.
01:24:31.560 | And it might mean, you know, as you scale your application or hardware to different locales, this is something that you should pay attention to.
01:24:37.560 | Now, I want to move on to talk about what I call new physics, and this part is super fun.
01:24:44.560 | This demo is based on a little, I think, on an iPad, which, you know, has over five daily active users in the world. It's very popular.
01:24:53.560 | And here, I'm imagining, like, okay, Midjourney, if I was the founder of Midjourney, I would be putting all my resources and making some sort of Midjourney Canvas app for iPads.
01:25:04.560 | So, in this one, I've asked Midjourney to create Balenciaga Naruto, which now I'm realizing kind of looks like me.
01:25:13.560 | So, let's think about the iPad. It's like this big slab that you can, like, touch and fiddle with, right?
01:25:18.560 | So, what do I want to do? Okay, I want to, like, edit this photo. But first, I need to make space. How do I do that?
01:25:24.560 | Well, very easy. You just, you know, you can just zoom out, and now you have extra space. Very obvious. We do this all the time.
01:25:31.560 | I kind of think my cat would look really good in that outfit. So, I kind of want to find a way to do that here. Let me just ask AI real quick.
01:25:42.560 | Hey, random AI sent me pictures of my cat. And, you know, the AI knows me and has contacts and gives me pictures of my cat. And then, what do I do here?
01:25:52.560 | Well, why can't we just take one of the photos and sort of just blend them with the other?
01:26:02.560 | And the metaphor you're seeing here as you sort of work with these photos, they start glowing when you pick them up. And what does light...
01:26:09.560 | You guys know the Pink Floyd Dark Side of the Moon album cover? Like, we're really familiar with the idea that light can sort of provide different colors and sort of concentrate back into one form.
01:26:21.560 | We're leaning into that metaphor here, implicitly. And so, it's now created something that looks 50% human, 50% cat, 100% cringe.
01:26:29.560 | I don't really like this. How do we remix this? What is the gesture? What is the thing we do in real life that's remixing?
01:26:36.560 | For me, it's a margarita, and for Sam, it's her morning huell. We shake a blender bottle.
01:26:40.560 | So, why can't we work with intelligent materials the same way that we work with real materials and just blend it up?
01:26:50.560 | This is totally doable right now. David, why aren't you building this? If you don't build this, I'm going to build this. It's fine.
01:26:56.560 | And so, you know, here the metaphor is like, what we're trying to say is, you know, think about familiar universal metaphors, like physics, like light, like metaballs, like squishy, like fog, whatever.
01:27:06.560 | Because, you know, if you're designing an iPhone, you have to be very cognizant of the qualities of aluminum and titanium to make an iPhone.
01:27:13.560 | But generative intelligence is a probabilistic material that's sort of more fluid. Maybe it's fog, maybe it's mercury.
01:27:22.560 | And, you know, for this reason, maybe metaphors that are really rigid, like wood or paper or metal, aren't the right metaphors to use for some of these experiences.
01:27:33.560 | So, finally, I want to walk you through an experience that's inherently mixed modal, slash mixed reality.
01:27:40.560 | Let's imagine for a second there's a piece of hardware coming out that's a wearable that has a camera on it and has a microphone and it can maybe project things.
01:27:51.560 | I don't know if such a thing will ever exist. But let's imagine for a second it does.
01:27:54.560 | I'm sort of browsing this book, this Beyonce tour book, and I see these images that I find really inspiring.
01:28:03.560 | What I'm trying to do here is what if I could just point at something on my desk and say, like, this is cool, and have the sort of device pick up on that and indicate that it's heard me and it's going to do something by sort of projection mapping the sort of feedback.
01:28:20.560 | This is, you know, this demo doesn't really have sound, but the way this would work is ideally a combination of voice and gesture at the same time.
01:28:27.560 | And, obviously, this gesture is really easy to make mistakes with.
01:28:32.560 | So, any time you work with probabilistic materials, you want to provide a graceful way out.
01:28:37.560 | So, in this case, I've accidentally tapped this photo. Why can't I just flick it away like dust and be like, that's wrong. I don't want to press an undo button, I don't want to press command Z, I just want to flick it away.
01:28:49.560 | So, really leaning to the physics of it. So, now that I've found two pieces, I'm kind of like, okay, I want to send this to two of my friends who -- there was a friend who I said I would do Halloween with, but I can't remember their name.
01:29:04.560 | So, what do I do here? I should ask AI. I should be like, who is that friend I said I'd spend Halloween with?
01:29:11.560 | And, you notice here that, like, we're imagining sort of projection mapped UI pieces that can work with the context of the world you're in right now, such that you don't have to go fish out a phone or use cumbersome voice commands.
01:29:25.560 | It just all sorts of naturally melding with the world. And, you know, crucially, I think one point we want to make is voice in doesn't need to mean voice out.
01:29:36.560 | Gesture in doesn't need to mean gesture out. And visual UI in does not need to mean visual UI out. We can mix these modalities in real time for whatever makes sense in whatever context you're in.
01:29:46.560 | So, given that interactions that require multiple simultaneous inputs are now possible, it's our job as designers and developers to sort of think on behalf of the user and think, what's the appropriate output given the current context, and be smart about it.
01:30:01.560 | Yeah.
01:30:02.560 | Yeah, so again, the takeaways, as we mentioned, it's this idea of -- we have a lot of sensors and contextual modalities available to us as ingredients, even today.
01:30:12.560 | There will be more tomorrow, as you kind of saw with these upcoming potential hardware releases. But even now, with a laptop, with things like typing speed, with things like the tone of voice, there's a lot of ways that you could gather context and extract signals from it.
01:30:27.560 | You could choose to process it in a variety of different ways. And so all of that can now be passed to an LLM and used in a reasoning layer which decides how both to respond in words and also how to present that information.
01:30:41.560 | And so basically, everything can now be an input and your output could be everywhere and have every format. At the same time, one might say, everything everywhere, all at once.
01:30:56.560 | Well, you want to be intentional with it. If someone wants to generate a photo on their Apple watch, you're like, why, why? No, use your freaking phone, Jesus.
01:31:04.560 | Anyway, and the last thing we'll say is, probabilistic interfaces are hard because they have lots of different outputs. So a really great way to sort of ground these interfaces is to lean into familiar metaphors, whether they are from nature, from physics, or even from human-made tools and materials, like buttons, for now.
01:31:21.560 | For now. And, you know, social norms is also a material that we work with, right? So your banking AI agent probably shouldn't be able to have a deep philosophical chat with you. That just socially doesn't make sense.
01:31:36.560 | Absolutely. Exactly. But on the same note, we've related all of these interfaces to what humans perceive and experience now. But what might a truly intelligent interface look like in the future, where if we think -- where we are right now, skeuomorphism, what is the abstraction layer above that? And that's kind of for us to figure out.
01:31:58.560 | So, with that, I think that's all. Thank you.
01:32:05.560 | All right. How are we feeling about those morning talks?
01:32:22.560 | So, I have one more thing I'd like to announce today. So, this summit is the start of something special. It's a landmark movement in the future of software engineering and how we build and interact with machines that have evolved as a part of our society for over a century.
01:32:51.560 | Over a century, or however you're defining it, more than that.
01:32:56.560 | But it's not just a movement. It's a community.
01:33:00.560 | And for this first event, we sold out an invite-only event with over 500 people at this beautiful hotel venue.
01:33:09.560 | But going forward, as more and more engineers realize the power of these technologies, we want to be more inclusive.
01:33:17.560 | more people, more intro tracks, more beginner workshops, in addition to the, you know, very advanced stuff that you've all come to expect at this summit.
01:33:27.560 | That's why I'm pleased to announce one more.
01:33:38.560 | Should have added music to this track, actually.
