01:41:10.560 | .
01:41:10.560 | .
01:41:10.560 | .
01:41:20.560 | .
01:41:20.560 | Okay, moving forward. Section 2: prompt engineering. So on its face, prompt engineering feels like a bunch of voodoo mumbo jumbo. It feels absurd, really, because we're used to working with symbolic architectures based on code logic. So it's strange to imagine getting higher quality output by prompting an AI model politely. But the language models are neural architectures. They're inspired by our brains. So different techniques are required. The bottom line is that prompt engineering objectively increases the quality of the AI model.
01:41:50.540 | of neural architectures output, such as language models. So now you might be tempted to say, all right, I'm going to skip all this prompt engineering stuff and get straight to fine tuning models. But fine tuning quality is often increased by starting with the best performing prompts and using those prompts in your fine tuning training data. Lastly, it's important to really sink your hands into the prompt engineering clay to see what language models are capable of and also to probe their limitations. So regarding course materials, start out by watching the
01:42:20.520 | overview video from prompt engineering guide founder Elvis Cerevia. Then dive directly into the guide itself. Read it cover to cover and pay special attention to the graduate job classification case study that shows how layering on prompt engineering techniques iteratively increases quality of output in aggregate. Next, read the learn prompting org docs favored by open AI cover to cover. The redundant concepts in this second guide are useful to review to really lock in these critical concepts. And also this guide
01:42:50.500 | does cover additional concepts as well.
01:42:53.500 | All right, moving on. Section three, open AI. Open AI does two things incredibly well. One, they provide state of the art AI models and two, they make them incredibly accessible. By learning open AI, you can understand the art of what's possible today. You can also start building and experimenting with AI engineering quickly. However, there are some practical limitations to consider that we will address further on. So regarding course material, we're going to read the
01:43:20.480 | open AI docs and API reference cover to cover cover. Then I would encourage you to quickly review the practical hands-on examples in their cookbook. Don't spend too much time there. You can come back later and we want to keep marching.
01:43:27.480 | Okay, moving on. Section four, Langchain. Langchain is the applications framework that allows you to put AI tech together in an organized and well-architected way. So it is highly maintainable, modular, and scalable. So Langchain integrates all the different parts and pieces required for a modern AI system. Models, prompts, long and short-term memory for retrieval, augmented generation, and conversation.
01:43:32.480 | So, practically everything.
01:43:33.480 | Furthermore, for any components that aren't supported yet, Langchain can be supported by the AI system.
01:43:37.480 | Langchain is flexible enough to allow straightforward integration of these new components.
01:43:42.480 | Including your proprietary needs.
01:43:43.480 | Lastly, and this is very important in the context of this syllabus, because it is very important in the context of this syllabus.
01:43:47.480 | So, it is highly maintainable, modular, and scalable.
01:43:49.480 | So, Langchain integrates all the different parts and pieces required for a modern AI system.
01:43:52.480 | Models, prompts, long and short-term memory for retrieval, augmented generation, and conversations.
01:43:57.480 | Langchain uses practically everything.
01:43:58.480 | Furthermore, for any components that aren't supported yet, Langchain is flexible enough to allow straightforward
01:44:04.480 | integration of these new components, including your proprietary needs.
01:44:08.480 | Lastly, and this is very important in the context of this syllabus, because Langchain is the glue layer for most everything else in the AI ecosystem,
01:44:16.480 | you will learn a lot about the comprehensive practice of AI engineering by building a comprehensive understanding of Langchain.
01:44:23.480 | Now, onto the course materials.
01:44:25.480 | So, building AI apps is a new paradigm.
01:44:28.480 | There's a lot to absorb.
01:44:29.480 | So, we're going to prime you with a non-technical comprehensive executive summary by command bar first,
01:44:36.480 | then we'll follow up with a simple, plain English technical guide that covers only some basic Langchain building blocks,
01:44:42.480 | so you can begin to quickly grok how a more complex AI system can be built up modularly with this framework.
01:44:48.480 | So, as you might imagine, the meat and potatoes of this section will be the Langchain docs and codebase.
01:44:53.480 | Langchain's documentation is highly thorough, so take full advantage of it.
01:44:58.480 | I encourage reading both the Python and the JavaScript/TyScript docs cover to cover, as the review helps lock in your knowledge,
01:45:05.480 | and there are important concepts in each version that aren't yet any other.
01:45:10.480 | As you read through the docs, pop over to GitHub and stick your head under the codebase hood to see how Langchain implements the features and functionality that the documentation covers.
01:45:20.480 | This will give you in-depth, practical knowledge on how to build AI tech the right way.
01:45:25.480 | Lastly, for real-world Langchain app tutorials, Mayo Ocean has great video walkthroughs.
01:45:30.480 | Specifically, I would encourage reviewing his Langchain beginners tutorial, as it covers the fundamentals.
01:45:36.480 | His other videos take these fundamentals and apply them towards more complex tasks.
01:45:41.480 | Alright, moving on.
01:45:43.480 | Section 5: Evaluating AI Models.
01:45:46.480 | Coming from a full-stack background, evals are basically your software tests.
01:45:50.480 | Before we start fine-tuning black-box AI models, we need a scientific process that can evaluate our changes iteratively.
01:45:57.480 | Otherwise, how do we know we're making improvements and not regressions, right?
01:46:01.480 | So, regarding the course materials, OpenAI has a great cookbook that walks you through writing some example evals.
01:46:07.480 | Note that the nature of AI output often means you're going to have to be a little bit creative when writing effective evals.
01:46:14.480 | Furthermore, OpenAI also provides a framework that includes a robust eval suite and allows for writing your custom evals as well.
01:46:22.480 | Review these materials quickly.
01:46:25.480 | Alright, moving on.
01:46:27.480 | Section 6: Fine-Tuning.
01:46:29.480 | By this point, you've already gained some exposure into fine-tuning OpenAI's models.
01:46:33.480 | We're going to take that further by going step-by-step through their fine-tuning cookbook.
01:46:37.480 | So, knowledge of how to fine-tune OpenAI models will take you a long way.
01:46:41.480 | However, there are practical limitations to relying on OpenAI alone.
01:46:44.480 | For example, it can be cost-prohibitive and you can run into latency or rate-limiting issues in production.
01:46:49.480 | This is in addition to standard privacy and control concerns.
01:46:53.480 | Because of this, an efficient pattern is to prototype and ship a solution quickly using OpenAI's models, start gathering usage and training data.
01:47:02.480 | Then, if the solution needs to start scaling, see if you can fine-tune a smaller and cheaper open-source model to match or out-compete OpenAI's model on your target use case.
01:47:12.480 | So, regarding course materials, first, completely go through the OpenAI Fine-Tuning Hands-On Cookbook.
01:47:18.480 | After that, we'll walk through AniScale's tutorial that demonstrates how to fine-tune an open-source model, Meta's Llama 2, such that it can match or even beat OpenAI's models and target tasks.
01:47:30.480 | Finally, we're going to skim OpenAI's cost-savings case study that shows how on our example task, and it's not cherry-picked, a smaller fine-tuned Llama 2 model at a cost of $19 can match results from OpenAI's state-of-the-art model, which would cost around $24,000 for the same task.
01:47:50.480 | Final section, Advanced Study.
01:47:54.480 | So, by this point, you've completed the Bootcamp section of the syllabus.
01:47:57.480 | I'd encourage you to start deploying your AI engineering skills in the real world before moving on to these advanced studies.
01:48:02.480 | However, once you're ready to take your skills well beyond the basics, FastAI's Practical Deep Learning course and Hugging Face's NLP course and their docs will give you a rich understanding of deep learning theory.
01:48:14.480 | In addition to learning fine-tuning further, you will also be able to train models from scratch.
01:48:19.480 | Alright, so we've reached the end.
01:48:21.480 | So, the syllabus is linked to my left.
01:48:23.480 | Thanks for joining me today.
01:48:24.480 | And for any questions, please reach out to me on LinkedIn.
01:48:27.480 | Bye.
01:48:28.480 | Hello, and welcome to my talk on how we're thinking about the levels of CodeAI.
01:48:34.480 | My name is Otto Kukic, and I am the Director of DevRel at Sourcegraph.
01:48:39.480 | At Sourcegraph, we're building Kodi, the only AI coding assistant that knows your entire codebase.
01:48:48.480 | To help educate our customers and users, as well as shape our thinking of CodeAI, we've been using a concept that we call Levels of CodeAI Internally.
01:48:58.480 | These levels have really resonated with our community, so we wanted to publicize them and start a conversation with the broader developer community, and we're better to do it than at the AI Engineer Summit.
01:49:11.480 | When we talk about CodeAI, we refer to software that builds software.
01:49:17.480 | Today, 92% of developers are using CodeAI tools, whereas this number was just 1% a year ago.
01:49:26.480 | Our founder and CEO, Quinn Slack, has shared a bold prediction that in five years, 99% of code will be written by AI.
01:49:36.480 | While we await that future, let's talk about how we see the levels of CodeAI today.
01:49:42.480 | We see six distinct levels across three different categories.
01:49:46.480 | Human-initiated, where humans are the primary coders.
01:49:50.480 | AI-initiated, where AI starts to take a proactive role in software development.
01:49:56.480 | And AI-led code, where AI has full autonomy over a codebase.
01:50:01.480 | We'll contrast these levels of code with the SAE levels of autonomy for vehicles.
01:50:07.480 | Let's dive in.
01:50:09.480 | At level zero, the developer writes all code manually without any AI assistance.
01:50:16.480 | The developer is responsible for writing, testing, and debugging a codebase.
01:50:21.480 | AI does not generate or modify any part of the codebase, but IDE features like symbol name, completion, can provide a bit of assistance.
01:50:30.480 | This level reflects the traditional software development process before introducing any AI assistance into the development workflow.
01:50:39.480 | A vehicle operating at level zero is fully reliant on the human driver for acceleration, steering, braking, and everything in between.
01:50:48.480 | At level one, the developer begins to use AI that can generate single lines or whole blocks of code based on developer intent.
01:50:57.480 | For example, a developer might write the signature of a function, and the AI will infer the context and generate the implementation details for said function.
01:51:07.480 | At level one, the AI assistant has been trained on millions of lines of open source code and can leverage this to provide superior completions based on the developer's guidance.
01:51:19.480 | SAE level one vehicles still require the full attention of the human driver, but offer features such as cruise control or lane centering that make driving an easier, safer, and more comfortable experience.
01:51:34.480 | At level two, the AI coding assistant has superior understanding and context of the code base it is interacting with.
01:51:42.480 | Where at level one, the context is broad and general, a level two AI coding assistant has specific context about the code base that it is working in.
01:51:52.480 | This allows the AI assistant to make better suggestions for code completions.
01:51:57.480 | For example, if you are working in a Node.js code base and were using the Axiom library to handle HTTP requests, a level two AI assistant would provide autocomplete suggestions based on the Axiom library as opposed to a different node HTTP library like fetch or super agent.
01:52:15.480 | At SAE level two, we get partial automation.
01:52:22.480 | The human driver is still in control and can override anything the car does at any time, but features such as traffic aware cruise control or automatic lane changes can make driving a much smoother experience.
01:52:33.480 | At level three, the developer provides high level requirements and the AI assistant delivers a code based solution.
01:52:41.480 | The AI coding assistant goes beyond generating singular snippets of code to building out full components and even integrations with other pieces of software.
01:52:51.480 | Rather than writing the code themselves, a developer could instruct a level three code AI assistant to add a user authentication to an application that they are building, and the coding assistant would generate all of the code required.
01:53:04.480 | The coding assistant could then explain to the developer the code it wrote, how it works, and how it integrates with the rest of the application.
01:53:11.480 | SAE level three is also the first level where the vehicle itself takes on the primary role of driving, with the human driver being a fallback in case the vehicle cannot drive itself safely.
01:53:23.480 | The vehicle can perform most of the driving tasks, but may encounter situations where it cannot adequately perform these tasks, so it's forced to give control back to the human driver.
01:53:35.480 | At level four, the code AI assistant can proactively handle coding tasks without developer oversight.
01:53:42.480 | Let's imagine a few scenarios where a level four code AI assistant would play a role.
01:53:47.480 | A level four capable code AI assistant could continuously monitor your code changes and autonomously submit PRs to ensure your documentation stays up to date.
01:53:59.480 | Even better, the coding assistant could monitor bug reports from customers and submit PRs to fix the issues.
01:54:06.480 | The human developer could then simply review the pull requests and merge them.
01:54:11.480 | Level four SAE vehicles can perform virtually all driving tasks under specific conditions.
01:54:18.480 | For example, Waymo operates a fleet of fully automated self-driving taxis in cities where they have high quality mapping data and can provide a safe driving experience for passengers without human drivers.
01:54:32.480 | A customer simply hails a Waymo taxi using a mobile app, provides a destination, and the vehicle is responsible for taking the passenger to their final destination without any additional human input.
01:54:45.480 | At level five, the AI assistant requires minimal human guidance on cogeneration and is capable of handling the entire software development lifecycle.
01:54:55.480 | The developer provides high level requirements and specifications.
01:55:00.480 | The AI then designs the architecture, writes production quality code, handles deployment, and continuously improves the code base.
01:55:09.480 | The developer's role is to validate that the end product meets the stated requirements, but the developer does not necessarily look at the generated code.
01:55:18.480 | The code AI assistant has complete autonomy to take code from concept to production.
01:55:27.480 | A self-driving car capable of level five driving automation can perform all driving tasks under all conditions, humans optional.
01:55:36.480 | The car is responsible for making all the decisions.
01:55:39.480 | At this level, a steering wheel or any ability for a human to override the car is unnecessary.
01:55:45.480 | So there you have it, the six levels of code AI, or at least how we're thinking about them at Sourcegraph.
01:55:52.480 | Do you agree?
01:55:53.480 | Disagree?
01:55:54.480 | We'd love to hear your thoughts.
01:55:55.480 | Find us at booth G5 and let's chat.
01:55:58.480 | And if you'd like to try Kodi for yourself, get it for your IDE of choice at Kodi.dev.
01:56:04.480 | Thank you, and I'll see you on the show floor.
01:56:06.480 | Hello, AI Engineer Summit.
01:56:08.480 | I'm Alex.
01:56:09.480 | I'm from Microsoft representing the office of the CTO.
01:56:12.480 | I'm going to be talking about cooking with the semantic kernel.
01:56:15.480 | Recipes for building chatbots, agents, and more with large language models.
01:56:19.480 | I'm sure everyone in the audience has probably heard Microsoft is pushing Copilot.
01:56:23.480 | Copilot is your everyday AI companion.
01:56:26.480 | And it's reflected actually in many of Microsoft's existing products and meant to be an assistant to help you do your work more productively.
01:56:35.480 | So whether you're in Word, whether you're in Paint, or even in a future Windows device, you'll definitely start seeing Copilot everywhere.
01:56:42.480 | But the natural question that I'm sure everyone's asking is, how do you build Copilots?
01:56:47.480 | Well, Microsoft has been asking this sort of question much early on.
01:56:51.480 | So I'm actually going to let our CEO, Satya Nadella, talk more about this.
01:56:56.480 | The Copilot stack, right?
01:56:58.480 | After all, we've built all these Copilots with one common architectural stack.
01:57:02.480 | We want to make that available so that everyone here can build their own Copilot for their applications.
01:57:08.480 | We will have everything from the AI infrastructure to the foundation models to the AI orchestration.
01:57:17.480 | So one of the things that we did that greatly affected our ability to get these Copilots out to market at scale and to do more ambitious things was to decide that inside of Microsoft,
01:57:27.480 | we are going to have one orchestration mechanism that we will use to help build our apps.
01:57:32.480 | That is called semantic kernel, which we've open sourced.
01:57:35.480 | So hopefully you all caught that.
01:57:38.480 | Both Satya Nadella and Kevin Scott have emphasized this idea of having a common AI orchestration framework across all of Microsoft to build their internal Copilots.
01:57:48.480 | And Kevin Scott even named it, and it is the semantic kernel.
01:57:53.480 | So what is semantic kernel?
01:57:54.480 | Well, semantic kernel is a lightweight open source orchestration SDK that lets you integrate large language models with native code in languages like C#, Python, and Java.
01:58:03.480 | In short, it's really just a open source library that you as an AI engineer can bring into your applications to really add these sort of capabilities to build Copilots for yourself.
01:58:18.480 | So if you were to take this high-level overview of what the semantic kernel is and what it includes, well, at the very left side, right, we have just the actual user experience, the actual application you're delivering to the end user.
01:58:33.480 | So this is all about providing a new sort of user experience that is AI-first, AI-driven, and really enables a bunch of new interaction patterns that you can have with your customers, your users, and all that.
01:58:48.480 | So in the middle is really where all this comes to be.
01:58:51.480 | And if you remember from that picture that Satya and Kevin both presented, AI orchestration is right in the middle of the Copilot stack, right, built on the foundation of large language models, other foundation models by providers like OpenAI, Hugging Face, Anthropical here, wherever you want to pull them in.
01:59:13.480 | But these foundation models, right, they're great at being able to give you some capabilities outside the box and by easily calling them through an API.
01:59:24.480 | But for us inside of the office of CTO, as we were experimenting with GPT-4, as we were kind of considering what are the new sort of paradigms that these AI coding, AI engineering would enable,
01:59:38.480 | we found that encapsulating all that inside of a common SDK, a common repository of knowledge and patterns, just made sense.
01:59:47.480 | It made sense for us to build internally across all these Microsoft Copilots.
01:59:51.480 | But by open sourcing it, right, we want to do that with the community.
01:59:55.480 | So part of the abilities that the future of AI applications must include, we believe, is this idea of being able to hold state or memories.
02:00:07.480 | And this is enabled by technologies like vector databases that I'm sure you'll hear all about inside of the AI engineer summit.
02:00:14.480 | In addition to that, right, we have this notion of connectors or plugins, right, being able to hook into external APIs that give your AI assistants, AI chatbots, AI co-pilots, the ability to interact with the outside world and external services.
02:00:32.480 | So the combination of these two memories and connectors and plugins, super powerful, but kind of under rooting all this in the middle, and which is really the huge unlock that we've seen is this idea of being able to use planning or have the large language model be able to use more of its reasoning capabilities to do more of the AI orchestration for you on your behalf.
02:00:54.480 | Now we've all been in situations where we've manually defined workflows or particular chaining of functions together manually.
02:01:03.480 | Well, the huge beauty of this, and I'll talk about this in a bit, is being able to use AI to do this planning for you.
02:01:09.480 | And all this is part of the full package of semantic kernel and what we expose to end developers.
02:01:17.480 | And especially if you're looking to bring this to the enterprise, right, we have a lot of different components there that you can dive deeper into the repo and what we have, especially in terms of our VS code extension, telemetry tooling that I'll reserve for a future discussion.
02:01:37.480 | So let's just talk about what the semantic kernel is at the high level.
02:01:43.480 | So it all really begins with the user ask that ask comes into the kernel where the kernel has to decide, okay, how am I going to fulfill or, or accomplish this ask or goal that I, the user has provided.
02:01:55.480 | So it does that by either manually, as you define in a kind of deterministic workflow, or you can make use of this notion of planner, which I talked about where you import to the kernel, several skills and plugins and have the planner be able to orchestrate reason about which set of functions, which set of skills should I be using to ultimately accomplish that user ask.
02:02:21.480 | Now that planner has two steps.
02:02:23.480 | Now that planner has two steps.
02:02:25.480 | It's plan creation.
02:02:26.480 | Um, and also then plan execution.
02:02:28.480 | Um, and we like to distinguish these two because, uh, planning with, especially AI planning, um, gets into really a realm of, I would consider magic where, wow, the AI is able to do this sort of thing for you.
02:02:45.480 | Um, but we are certainly huge believers in this human in the loop, uh, concept where, yeah, and you want to be able to verify plans.
02:02:53.480 | You want to be able to inspect them, edit them, maybe modify them as you see fit.
02:02:58.480 | So the planner is meant to be able to create a plan.
02:03:02.480 | And then you as a user will verify that and ultimately execute it.
02:03:06.480 | Uh, a big piece of all this is we want to build together with the community.
02:03:11.480 | Uh, that's a reason why semantic kernels open source.
02:03:13.480 | We want to learn from you all.
02:03:14.480 | We want to engage with a fellow AI engineers and, uh, really try to crack this, uh, um, space, uh, together.
02:03:25.480 | So with that, right, I invite you all to check out our discord.
02:03:29.480 | Uh, we have, um, great conversations happening there and we'd love to, to continue that, um, in that space.
02:03:37.480 | And obviously if you want to find me personally, uh, you can connect with me on, uh, Twitter or X, uh, LinkedIn, YouTube, uh, and feel free to also subscribe to my newsletter, uh, if you like.
02:03:50.480 | Um, but with that, right, thank you everybody at the AI engineer summit for, uh, listening, for checking this out and certainly hope you all have a great conference.
02:04:03.480 | Hi everyone.
02:04:04.480 | I'm Emmanuel, CEO of Sematic, the company behind Airtrain.
02:04:09.480 | Today, I want to talk about a difficult problem in the language modeling space.
02:04:13.480 | And that is evaluation.
02:04:15.480 | Unlike in other areas of machine learning, it is not so straightforward to evaluate language models for a specific use case.
02:04:23.480 | There are metrics and benchmarks, but they mostly apply to generic tasks.
02:04:28.480 | And there is no one size fits all process to evaluate the performance of a model for a particular use case.
02:04:35.480 | So first let's get the basics out of the way.
02:04:38.480 | What is model evaluation?
02:04:40.480 | Model evaluation is the statistical measurement of the performance of a machine learning model.
02:04:45.480 | How well does a model perform on a particular use case measured on a large dataset independent from the training dataset?
02:04:54.480 | Model evaluation usually comes right after training or fine tuning and is a crucial part of model development.
02:05:00.480 | All ML teams dedicate large resources to establish rigorous evaluation procedures.
02:05:05.480 | You need to set up a solid evaluation process as part of your development workflow to guarantee performance and safety.
02:05:14.480 | You can compare evaluation to running a test suite in your continuous integration pipeline.
02:05:19.480 | In traditional supervised machine learning, there is a whole host of well-defined metrics to clearly grade a model's performance.
02:05:27.480 | For example, for regressions, we have the root mean squared error or the mean absolute error.
02:05:34.480 | For classifiers, people usually use precision, recall, or F1 score, and so on.
02:05:42.480 | In computer vision, a popular metric is the intersection over union.
02:05:47.480 | So what metrics are available to score language models?
02:05:51.480 | Well, unlike other types of models returning structured outputs such as a number, a class, or a bounding box,
02:05:58.480 | language models generate text which is very unstructured.
02:06:02.480 | An inference that is different from the ground truth reference is not necessarily incorrect.
02:06:07.480 | Depending on whether you have access to labeled references, there are a number of metrics you can use.
02:06:13.480 | For example, BLUE is a precision-based metric.
02:06:17.480 | It measures the overlap between n-grams, that is sequences of tokens, between the generated text and the inference.
02:06:25.480 | It's a common metric to evaluate translation between two languages and can also be used to score summarization.
02:06:32.480 | It can definitely serve as a good benchmark, but it is not a safe indicator of how a model will perform on your particular task.
02:06:39.480 | For example, it does not take into account intelligibility or grammatical correctness.
02:06:44.480 | Rouge is a set of evaluation metrics that focuses on measuring the recall of sequences of tokens between references and the inference.
02:06:54.480 | It is mostly useful to evaluate for summarization.
02:06:58.480 | If you don't have access to labeled references, you can use other standalone metrics.
02:07:03.480 | For example, density quantifies how well the summary represents pull fragments from the text,
02:07:10.480 | and coverage quantifies the extent to which a summary is derivative of a text.
02:07:15.480 | As you can see, these metrics are only useful to score certain high-level tasks, such as translation and summarization.
02:07:24.480 | There are also a number of benchmarks and leaderboards that rank various models.
02:07:29.480 | Benchmarks are standardized tests that score model performance for certain tasks.
02:07:34.480 | For example, GLUE, or General Language Understanding Evaluation, is a common benchmark to evaluate how well a model understands language
02:07:44.480 | through a series of nine tasks.
02:07:47.480 | For example, paraphrase detection and sentiment analysis.
02:07:52.480 | Helleswag measures natural language inference, which is the ability for a model to have common sense and find the most plausible end to a sentence.
02:08:02.480 | In this case, answer C is the most reasonable choice.
02:08:05.480 | There are other benchmarks, such as Trivia QA, which asks almost a million trivia questions from Wikipedia and other sources,
02:08:13.480 | and tests the knowledge of the model.
02:08:16.480 | Also, ARC tests models' ability to reason about high-school-level science questions.
02:08:21.480 | And there are dozens more benchmarks out there.
02:08:24.480 | All these metrics and benchmarks are very useful to draw a landscape of how LLMs compare to one another.
02:08:31.480 | But they do not tell you how they perform for your particular task on the type of input data that will be fed by your application.
02:08:39.480 | For example, if you're trying to extract symptoms from a doctor's notes, or extract ingredients from a recipe, or form a JSON payload to query an API,
02:08:50.480 | these metrics will not tell you how each model performs.
02:08:54.480 | So each application needs to come up with its own evaluation procedure, which is a lot of work.
02:09:00.480 | There is one magic trick, though.
02:09:02.480 | You can use another model to grade the output of your model.
02:09:07.480 | You can describe to an LLM what you're trying to accomplish and what are the grading criteria, and ask it to grade the output of another LLM on a numerical scale.
02:09:17.480 | Essentially, you are crafting your own specialized metrics for your own application.
02:09:24.480 | Here's an example of how it works.
02:09:26.480 | You can feed your evaluation data set to the model that you want to evaluate, which is going to generate the inferences that you want to score.
02:09:33.480 | Then, you can include those inferences inside a broader scoring prompt in which you've described the task you're trying to accomplish and the properties you're trying to grade.
02:09:43.480 | And also, you describe the scale across which it should be graded, for example, from 1 to 10.
02:09:49.480 | Then, you pass this scoring prompt to a scoring model, which is going to generate a number, a score, to score the actual inference.
02:09:58.480 | If you do this on all the inferences generated from your evaluation data set, you can draw a distribution of that particular metric.
02:10:05.480 | For example, here is a small set of closing words generated for professional emails.
02:10:10.480 | We want to evaluate their politeness.
02:10:12.480 | We can prompt a model to score the politeness of each statement from 1 to 10.
02:10:17.480 | For example, please let us know at your earliest convenience scores highly, while tell me ASAP will score poorly.
02:10:26.480 | We found that the best grading model at this time is still GPT-4, but can be quite costly to use to score large data sets.
02:10:33.480 | We have found that Flanti 5 offers a good trade-off of speed and correctness.
02:10:38.480 | Airtrain was designed specifically for this purpose.
02:10:42.480 | With Airtrain, you can upload your data set, select the models you want to compare, describe the properties you want to measure, and visualize metric distribution across your entire data set.
02:10:53.480 | You can compare LAMA 2 with Falcon, Flanti 5, or even your own model.
02:10:58.480 | Then, you can make an educated decision based on statistical evidence.
02:11:02.480 | Sign up today for early access at Airtrain.ai and start making data-driven decisions about your choice of LLM.
02:11:10.480 | Thanks, goodbye.
02:11:11.480 | Hi everyone.
02:11:22.480 | I'm Jesse, founder and CEO of Morph Labs.
02:11:26.480 | I'll be telling you today about how we're enabling the rise of the AI software engineer.
02:11:34.480 | Programming is evolving.
02:11:36.480 | Programming was once called automatic programming.
02:11:39.480 | Logarithms used to be considered human knowledge work.
02:11:42.480 | One day, we'll think about how engineering was once called AI engineering,
02:11:47.480 | and how intelligence used to be called artificial general intelligence.
02:11:51.480 | And along the way, we will command legions of AI software engineers to write the code for us.
02:12:00.480 | Here at Morph Labs, our mission is to bring the personal AI software engineer to everyone.
02:12:06.480 | The personal AI software engineer will understand you, the best practices for your software, your favorite idioms.
02:12:13.480 | The personal AI software engineer will understand your code base better than you do.
02:12:18.480 | Its capabilities will evolve with you and your code, and it will always stay up to date.
02:12:24.480 | The personal AI software engineer will augment you at every stage of the software development lifecycle,
02:12:29.480 | from ideation and specification to implementation testing and deployment.
02:12:36.480 | I'm proud to announce the Morph Code Index, a major milestone towards the personal AI software engineer.
02:12:43.480 | The Morph Code Index is a neuro-symbolic code database for you and your coding assistant.
02:12:49.480 | With it, you can run semantic searches with natural language over your code base,
02:12:54.480 | make your entire code base and Git history visible to your coding assistant,
02:12:58.480 | and transmute your code base into training data for your personal AI software engineer.
02:13:04.480 | So let's dive into what it does.
02:13:09.480 | The Morph Code Index helps you find relevant code faster.
02:13:13.480 | We use static analysis, vector embeddings, and graph algorithms to create a state-of-the-art code search index.
02:13:20.480 | The Morph Code Index also ships with a neuro-symbolic query language, which can be used to guarantee precise results.
02:13:27.480 | The code index is the only AI-native code search engine.
02:13:33.480 | It will make your coding assistant smarter.
02:13:35.480 | With our Python bindings, it will be easy to attach a Morph Code Index to any coding assistant to give it code base-wide context via retrieval.
02:13:44.480 | Finally, the Morph Code Index can traverse your code base to generate vast quantities of training data.
02:13:52.480 | We've already used this exact pipeline to train our newly released Riff Coder 7b model, which is the only open-source model for code editing that can run on your laptop and in your IDE.
02:14:03.480 | All you have to do is index your code, run the generation script, and you can start training your personal AI software engineer.
02:14:15.480 | Here at Morph Labs, we believe the future of software should belong to everyone.
02:14:19.480 | That's why the Morph Code Index is open-source, transparent, and free.
02:14:23.480 | Your code, your data, your model.
02:14:27.480 | Finally, just for AI engineer attendees, we will soon be announcing a platform for building, managing, and deploying your personal AI software engineer.

02:18:29.480 | And to set the stage with some context, I've been building side projects pretty consistently
02:18:33.680 | for about two years now.

02:18:41.480 | So not too shabby.

02:18:47.480 | And happy to announce that I did hit that goal and slightly exceeded it as well.
02:18:52.480 | Thank you.
02:18:55.480 | And basically here today to talk about how this happened.
02:18:59.480 | And, you know, I'm very thankful and very lucky that I managed to hit such a good number.
02:19:05.480 | Over 8 million unique visitors across all of my projects.
02:19:08.480 | 20,000 GitHub stars and about 2.8 million people that signed up.
02:19:13.480 | And fun fact, every single one of these projects that I launched was built on the weekend.
02:19:18.480 | So I'm going to pick through some of these projects and we're going to go through them and talk about some lessons learned.
02:19:24.480 | I also want to mention that everything I do is open source.
02:19:28.480 | So you can check out all of my projects at github.com/nutloop.
02:19:32.480 | Embarrassing gamer username from like 10 years ago that I can't get rid of.
02:19:36.480 | But, yeah, no, I love building an open source and it makes me so happy to see people use my projects.
02:19:42.480 | But it's also a very good growth lever when you launch.
02:19:45.480 | And I get a lot of genuinely helpful PRs from a lot of people that are better at prompt engineering than I am.
02:19:53.480 | So that's always helpful.
02:19:55.480 | Disclaimer, I do have a bit of an audience on Twitter, which is very helpful.
02:19:59.480 | But honestly, I don't think it's as important as people make it out to be.
02:20:03.480 | A lot of people can kind of attribute having a lot of followers to having successful projects.
02:20:09.480 | But I've seen plenty of people have very successful side projects with little to no Twitter following.
02:20:15.480 | And, in fact, less than 5% of the traffic of those 8.5 million people that have visited all of my projects,
02:20:21.480 | less than 5% of that traffic actually comes from my Twitter account.
02:20:24.480 | So you may be thinking, where does this traffic come from?
02:20:27.480 | And, honestly, it's a lot of word of mouth and Google and SEO and other influencers sharing it.
02:20:32.480 | So I'm going to get to that in a bit as well.
02:20:35.480 | So today I want to talk to you all like friends.
02:20:38.480 | And when I talk to my friends about my projects, I kind of just share my laptop and go through a bunch of things.
02:20:44.480 | So I'm going to switch over to my laptop here and go through a bunch of my side projects.
02:20:50.480 | So let's do that.
02:20:53.480 | Wonderful.
02:20:54.480 | So this is kind of my first AI project, how I got into AI last December.
02:20:59.480 | And really it stemmed from this problem that we had where we had just run a conference last year
02:21:04.480 | and we had several hundred photos out there in an image gallery.
02:21:08.480 | And right before we published it, my CEO came up to me and was like,
02:21:12.480 | hey, we probably need to add alt tags for a lot of these images.
02:21:15.480 | And that would have been a very painful process going through several hundred images.
02:21:18.480 | So I looked stuff up and I found a nice image to text API that ended up working really well.
02:21:24.480 | You know, I went and I checked a lot of these -- a lot of the alt tags and maybe fixed like two of them and published.
02:21:30.480 | But this was really my big light bulb moment of like, oh, my God.
02:21:34.480 | AI can really, really help you save a ton of time.
02:21:38.480 | Like this isn't some Web3 hype from last year.
02:21:41.480 | You know, this is real.
02:21:43.480 | No, I'm kidding.
02:21:44.480 | Web3 has its place for sure.
02:21:45.480 | But this is really the big thing when it came out.
02:21:48.480 | So I built this little open source project.
02:21:50.480 | I put it out there.
02:21:51.480 | And then I just started having fun and building other stuff.
02:21:53.480 | So I built another project called QRGBT with my friend Kevin at a hackathon.
02:21:58.480 | And so the idea is that you just generate just pretty nice QR codes.
02:22:01.480 | So we can actually go and generate a QR code for AI.engineer.
02:22:07.480 | I forgot the domain name.
02:22:09.480 | And we can select a prompt here.
02:22:11.480 | I'm going to just click one of the pre-generated ones, a forest overlooking a mountain.
02:22:15.480 | And hopefully in like five or six seconds it should generate a QR code that links to the conference
02:22:19.480 | that just looks a little bit better than the black and white QR codes.
02:22:22.480 | And so we built this and we weren't expecting way too much because people really don't have
02:22:28.480 | to generate QR codes every single minute.
02:22:30.480 | So, yeah, we put it out there.
02:22:32.480 | We got about 8,000 visitors, about 8,000 QR codes generated.
02:22:35.480 | And so we were like, okay, cool.
02:22:37.480 | And I was like, all right, I want to try to build something that has more like daily active users
02:22:42.480 | or people that will use it consistently.
02:22:44.480 | So I built this little tool that summarizes TechCrunch articles.
02:22:48.480 | So the idea is that you go to TechCrunch.com, you can click any article that you want,
02:22:53.480 | and all you have to do is add summary to the end of the URL over there,
02:22:56.480 | and it will redirect you to my website and kind of summarize the whole article
02:23:00.480 | using GPT 3.5 in a couple of bullet points.
02:23:03.480 | And so the reason I'm showing you a video here and not a live demo
02:23:07.480 | is because I got a very nice e-mail from the TechCrunch lawyers
02:23:11.480 | when I launched this telling me to take it down.
02:23:14.480 | So that was a lot of fun.
02:23:16.480 | But yeah, anyway, I took it down and I moved on.
02:23:19.480 | That one -- it did pretty good when I launched it,
02:23:21.480 | and then they made me take it down, and it kind of died off from there.
02:23:25.480 | And then I started just like replying to random people on Twitter.
02:23:28.480 | So Samina here asked, like, can someone help me build an AI to help me take classes?
02:23:33.480 | So I was like, all right, bet. I got you.
02:23:35.480 | And built this little thing in, like, a couple hours where it takes some information about yourself,
02:23:40.480 | your face shape and your gender, and you can add some relevant context,
02:23:44.480 | and it uses a combination of LLMs and the Amazon API to find the ideal glasses for you
02:23:49.480 | and actually links them on there so that you can buy them.
02:23:52.480 | So yeah, I just started replying to a bunch of tweets.
02:23:54.480 | Another one was by my friend Theo, who said someone should make an app that kind of auto-generates commit messages for you.
02:24:00.480 | And then my CTO tagged me and was like, C.C., I love that idea,
02:24:05.480 | which translates to build this as soon as possible.
02:24:08.480 | So I was like, all right, I got you.
02:24:10.480 | And I built a little -- I built a little tool.
02:24:14.480 | So essentially you could run git add, you run the CLI tool that I built, AI commit,
02:24:18.480 | and it analyzes your git diff and produces a little commit message for you
02:24:21.480 | that you can then use to commit.
02:24:23.480 | And these are, like, very small hacky solutions.
02:24:27.480 | You know, my CTO tagged me at 7:53 p.m. on February 11th,
02:24:32.480 | and then less than two hours later I replied with that little script.
02:24:37.480 | Thank you.
02:24:41.480 | And after I saw it get some attention, I was like, okay, I need to clean this up.
02:24:44.480 | I need to figure out how to bundle it into an NPM package.
02:24:47.480 | And so that's what I spent my Monday morning on.
02:24:50.480 | I hope my manager isn't watching, but that was a fun Monday.
02:24:54.480 | And, yeah, kind of bundled it out there and posted it as an NPM package.
02:24:59.480 | And now I think over 30,000 developers are now using it to commit their messages,
02:25:05.480 | and it's one of my more popular open source repos.
02:25:07.480 | There's some PRs that I need to take a look at.
02:25:09.480 | But, yeah, a bunch of 6,000 stars and about 25 contributors.
02:25:14.480 | And so this was kind of my exploration with LLMs.
02:25:17.480 | And so actually I have one more project called the Twitter bio generator.
02:25:21.480 | And essentially also open source like most of my other projects.
02:25:24.480 | But you just put in some context about you so we can do, like, engineer at Microsoft.
02:25:29.480 | And we can say loves volleyball.
02:25:31.480 | And pick a vibe and it will make your Twitter bio for you.
02:25:36.480 | And kind of stream in text from GPT 3.5.
02:25:40.480 | Spiking code bugs and volleyball balls.
02:25:43.480 | You can't get any better than that.
02:25:45.480 | But you might take a look at some of these projects and think, like, this is so simple.
02:25:50.480 | Like, nobody's going to use this.
02:25:51.480 | This is just like this little chat GPT wrapper.
02:25:54.480 | Like, everybody in this room can build this thing.
02:25:56.480 | But I think we constantly underestimate, like, that the majority of the world are not AI engineers.
02:26:04.480 | Nobody can build this.
02:26:05.480 | A lot of people haven't even used chat GPT yet.
02:26:06.480 | Like, it's crazy.
02:26:07.480 | So even the simplest apps can do really, really well.
02:26:10.480 | And so that's a common theme that you might see is, like, all of these are very, very simple apps.
02:26:15.480 | So I launched it and I got about 200,000 visitors that used it.
02:26:19.480 | I got about 100,000 people in a single weekend.
02:26:21.480 | And then I hit my open AI bill and had to shut it down for a little bit.
02:26:26.480 | So it's always a good sign.
02:26:28.480 | And so after this, I kind of switched into image-to-image models.
02:26:31.480 | So I built this photo restore website that basically unblurs old photos.
02:26:36.480 | And the motivation behind this actually was my parents sending me these old photos.
02:26:40.480 | So I'm actually going to put in a picture of my dad doing karate when he was, like, 18.
02:26:44.480 | And he sent me this photo, and his face is really blurry.
02:26:47.480 | And you'll see -- yeah, he's flexible.
02:26:51.480 | I do not -- I did not inherit that.
02:26:53.480 | But you see his face is a little bit blurry.
02:26:55.480 | You can't see it too well.
02:26:56.480 | But hopefully in the space of a few seconds we should see --
02:26:59.480 | And so this uses just a GAN model.
02:27:02.480 | It's called GFPGAN.
02:27:03.480 | It sends it to that model, and it will basically scan, like, all the faces in a picture and restore it.
02:27:12.480 | So we'll see if the Internet is working out.
02:27:15.480 | We'll hopefully see the image come in in a few seconds.
02:27:18.480 | And if not, I can move on and come back to it.
02:27:21.480 | All right.
02:27:23.480 | I'll come back to it.
02:27:25.480 | So, again, open source repo.
02:27:27.480 | And this one, like, really, really did well.
02:27:30.480 | And it kind of is my most consistent project.
02:27:33.480 | It still has about 250,000 people that use it every month.
02:27:37.480 | Mostly, actually, in India and Indonesia, which makes a lot of sense because the phone cameras there are a lot lower quality.
02:27:44.480 | So it makes sense that they would use it.
02:27:46.480 | But shortly after it went viral, I got a lot of inappropriate images being uploaded.
02:27:50.480 | And so I had to -- I used, actually, TensorFlow.js, and I published this as a library as well.
02:27:56.480 | But, yeah, I just ended up using this to scan the image and make sure it was safe before I processed it.
02:28:01.480 | So let's go back.
02:28:02.480 | Okay.
02:28:03.480 | So it looks like it was restored.
02:28:04.480 | We'll actually put them side by side and zoom in a little bit so you can see his face before a little bit blurry.
02:28:07.480 | And then after the transformation, you can see it really, really clears up.
02:28:11.480 | And really another thing I want to stress here is that this is one single API call to this GFPGAN model.
02:28:22.480 | And that's it.
02:28:23.480 | And he's really getting that and displaying it back to the user.
02:28:26.480 | So it's such an exciting time to be an AI engineer and to build this stuff because it's so easy and it's so impressive to other people as well.
02:28:34.480 | So I'm going to talk about one more project and then I'm going to start to talk about some takeaways.
02:28:39.480 | But before that, actually, this is like the architecture for most of my apps.
02:28:42.480 | Really, I use Next.js on the front end and the back end.
02:28:45.480 | And you saw for restore photos, there's this little upload component that I use.
02:28:48.480 | And so the user uploads an image, it gets sent to cloud storage, and then I send that image URL to my Next.js API route.
02:28:56.480 | Or you can think of it as just like a Lambda function.
02:28:58.480 | And then that sends it to my machine learning model to GFPGAN to get restored.
02:29:03.480 | It gets back the image, sends it back to the client, and display it to the user.
02:29:07.480 | So this is kind of the architecture I use for a lot of my image-to-image side projects.
02:29:11.480 | But my last one, which I'll restart, but my last one that did the best is actually called Room GPT.
02:29:20.480 | And it's that idea of if you give it a room, I'm just going to give it a random living room from the Internet, and we're going to select a couple themes.
02:29:27.480 | But if you give it a room and some themes, the idea is that it'll use this, and it'll help you redesign your room.
02:29:36.480 | It'll give you different variations of that specific room, different color themes, different couch styles and stuff like that.
02:29:42.480 | So we can see it just finished.
02:29:43.480 | And you can see it really respects the structure of the room.
02:29:46.480 | So it looks the same, but it gives you different ideas for these tables and backgrounds and tiles and everything like that.
02:29:51.480 | So really the motivation behind this project was that I saw somebody else built this before, but they used Stable Diffusion.
02:29:58.480 | And Stable Diffusion actually does a notoriously bad job at maintaining the original structure of a room.
02:30:05.480 | Like, you can give it a room, you can tell it, okay, redesign this in this theme, and the image it produces looks nothing like the original room.
02:30:12.480 | Like, the dimensions are messed up, the depth is messed up.
02:30:15.480 | And then I saw this new model called ControlNet that came out.
02:30:18.480 | And ControlNet does really well at maintaining that structure of the room.
02:30:22.480 | So I saw that, and I was like, oh, this could be cool to build.
02:30:25.480 | So I put it out there, and I launched it on Twitter.
02:30:30.480 | And obviously it's also open source, but I launched it on Twitter, and it did pretty well on there.
02:30:36.480 | And kind of kept tweeting about it.
02:30:38.480 | Because the thing about Twitter, when you tweet about something 24 hours later, it's kind of dead.
02:30:43.480 | So what I like to do is I like to kind of post updates over and over again.
02:30:47.480 | So we had about 10,000 people that used it in the first 12 hours, and then 30,000 in the first day.
02:30:54.480 | And then I added some testimonials.
02:30:56.480 | May or may not have paid these people.
02:30:59.480 | And then, yeah, two days later it had like 90,000 people.
02:31:03.480 | And then three days, 270,000 people.
02:31:05.480 | And so it kind of just blew up.
02:31:06.480 | And I feel like it was just -- it was mostly because I was one of the first people to kind of productionize this ControlNet model that had just come out.
02:31:14.480 | So a lot of people were seeing it for the first time and using it.
02:31:18.480 | And most of these users -- again, I can show you the analytics chart.
02:31:21.480 | So I have about 6 million people that have visited the site, and about a little over 2 million that have registered and used it.
02:31:26.480 | And you can see the vast majority of the traffic is just Google.
02:31:30.480 | It's just straight up from Google.
02:31:32.480 | You know, a lot of people kept sharing it.
02:31:34.480 | And, you know, part of that, I think, is because it was open source, and a lot of developers liked it and re-shared it.
02:31:39.480 | But also the fact that I kept it free.
02:31:42.480 | So I'm going to talk about how I did that kind of when I transitioned back to slides.
02:31:47.480 | So those are some of my side projects.
02:31:50.480 | One thing I want to call out is it's a really good idea to use AI-enhancing tools when building a lot of this stuff.
02:31:55.480 | So use GPT-4 for your code.
02:31:57.480 | We have an AI SDK that you can use over at Vercel.
02:32:00.480 | And we also have this product called V0 at Vercel.
02:32:04.480 | And so it helps you kind of generate UIs.
02:32:06.480 | And what's really cool is you can kind of see other people generating UIs.
02:32:09.480 | So we can click on this one, for example, which looks like the Apple Notes UI.
02:32:14.480 | And we can actually fork -- we can look at the code, which is cool.
02:32:18.480 | So I can copy all this code.
02:32:19.480 | But what's also cool is I can look at these templates or look at other people's code and I can fork it.
02:32:24.480 | Similar to how I can fork a GitHub repo.
02:32:26.480 | So now this is mine.
02:32:27.480 | I can kind of add additional prompts to change it.
02:32:29.480 | Or I can click this button over here and actually select different elements within the page.
02:32:34.480 | So I can select this div and tell it, like, add three more notes and alternate their colors.
02:32:42.480 | And I can press enter and update.
02:32:43.480 | And what it will do is it will just re-render this specific div.
02:32:47.480 | And it will stream in the data using our Vercel AI SDK.
02:32:50.480 | It will stream in these React components.
02:32:53.480 | And, yeah, hopefully it will keep going and add all this stuff in.
02:32:57.480 | And, again, as it streams in these components, it adds them inside of this code box over here.
02:33:03.480 | So I think it's still generating.
02:33:08.480 | But eventually, you know, it will add all of the notes here.
02:33:11.480 | And we can go into the code and kind of copy and paste it.
02:33:14.480 | And we can also run a CLI command.
02:33:16.480 | You can see it scrolls down because it's still generating.
02:33:18.480 | Here's, yeah, note three, note four, note five.
02:33:19.480 | There you go.
02:33:20.480 | So added the five notes.
02:33:21.480 | I can go take all this code or run this command and get all the code and kind of iterate on UIs that way.
02:33:27.480 | So it's just a way to kind of prototype a very early UIs.
02:33:30.480 | So I'm going to go back to slides right now to talk about some takeaways.
02:33:35.480 | So use AI tools to move faster.
02:33:40.480 | I mentioned that.
02:33:41.480 | I mentioned the AI SDK.
02:33:42.480 | I mentioned V0.
02:33:43.480 | But there's a lot of really amazing libraries.
02:33:45.480 | I love using replicate and hugging face and modal and a lot of these other tools and brev.
02:33:51.480 | There's a lot of really cool stuff you can use to kind of train your models or move faster when you're coding.
02:33:57.480 | So this is a bit of a spicy one.
02:33:58.480 | I always tell people, don't do any fine tuning and don't build your own models.
02:34:03.480 | And this is specifically for launching MVPs.
02:34:05.480 | Because, again, the purpose of this talk and everything is like building projects very quickly on weekends.
02:34:12.480 | So you don't have time to fine tune.
02:34:13.480 | You want to keep things very, very simple.
02:34:15.480 | If you can't describe your idea to me in five words, like, it might not do great.
02:34:20.480 | You know?
02:34:21.480 | I have friends that come up to me that are like, oh, I want to build this platform for developers
02:34:25.480 | where they can connect them to clients and they can have their portfolios there
02:34:28.480 | and they can have a chat and they can have this.
02:34:30.480 | And I just, like, stare into them and I'm like, that's not going to happen.
02:34:34.480 | Like, that's not -- you can't build that in a weekend.
02:34:36.480 | You know, if you can't build a -- so what I tell them is just basically downscope to an MVP and then launch it.
02:34:42.480 | And even RoomGBT, when I launched that, I had so many machine learning engineers that DMed me on Twitter
02:34:47.480 | and were like, oh, my God, like, what models did you train?
02:34:49.480 | What parameters did you use?
02:34:50.480 | How did you get the data?
02:34:51.480 | How did you clean your data?
02:34:52.480 | I'm like, dude, I just used, like, an API off the shelf.
02:34:55.480 | You know?
02:34:56.480 | You don't need -- you can do so much with off-the-shelf APIs.
02:35:00.480 | Another one is use the latest models.
02:35:01.480 | I mentioned a big part of RoomGBT's success is using ControlNet, which had just come out
02:35:06.480 | a couple days before.
02:35:07.480 | Launching early and iterating is so, so important because you don't know what's going to do well.
02:35:12.480 | So if you can de-risk your projects, if you can get a project out in one or two weekends, and if it fails, so what?
02:35:19.480 | You can pivot, you can move on to a new idea, and you can just -- yeah.
02:35:23.480 | You can just move on to other things.
02:35:25.480 | And so -- and if it does well, then you can double down on it.
02:35:27.480 | Then you can add additional things to it.
02:35:29.480 | So I've found that to be great.
02:35:31.480 | Another one is making it free and open source.
02:35:33.480 | First, making things open source is always great because people learn from it and are
02:35:37.480 | incentivized to share it and will open PRs for your project.
02:35:40.480 | And it will also get you a bunch of followers.
02:35:42.480 | You know, I gained, like, 25,000 Twitter followers this year just from posting a bunch of these
02:35:46.480 | open source projects.
02:35:47.480 | And they're just all developers wanting to learn and help me out.
02:35:50.480 | So open source is amazing.
02:35:52.480 | Making things free is a little bit hard, right?
02:35:55.480 | Because as we know, AI workloads are really, really expensive.
02:35:59.480 | And so there's a few ways you can do this.
02:36:01.480 | I kind of play to my strengths.
02:36:02.480 | You know, I have a Twitter audience.
02:36:03.480 | So I can go to companies and be like, hey, I want to launch this project.
02:36:06.480 | I think it will get X amount of users.
02:36:08.480 | Please give me some credits.
02:36:10.480 | And I'll shout you out in the footer and put you in the read me and all this stuff.
02:36:13.480 | But I've seen a lot of other people replicate this with no followers.
02:36:16.480 | And the key is to just build a very high quality open source project, put it out there,
02:36:20.480 | put a $50 limit on it, and when you run out, you can reach out to the company and say, hey,
02:36:25.480 | my project went viral on Twitter and it's featuring you and the GitHub repo is open source.
02:36:30.480 | So when companies see this, they're kind of willing to give you some credits.
02:36:35.480 | So shout out to Replicate and Bytescale and Neon and a bunch of my other sponsors that help me keep a lot of my AI projects free.
02:36:42.480 | And the last lesson that I have for you is making sure your UI looks good.
02:36:46.480 | Nobody is going to use your product if it doesn't look good.
02:36:48.480 | That's just something that's been learned.
02:36:51.480 | And so I actually spend like 80% of my time on the UI.
02:36:55.480 | Even though these are like AI projects, most of the time it's on the UI because you need to make it look good.
02:37:01.480 | And if you're not a designer, you can just take inspiration from a bunch of different websites.
02:37:06.480 | And that's what I do.
02:37:08.480 | I'm not a designer, so I just look at like five other websites and I kind of steal a little bit of each site to make it look good.
02:37:14.480 | Because I don't know how to just come and make a website that looks good, but I know when something looks good when I see it.
02:37:21.480 | So that's kind of what I do.
02:37:23.480 | So very quick summary.
02:37:25.480 | If you do these five things, I think you can go very, very far.
02:37:28.480 | And lastly, I tell people to use whatever tech stack they want to use.
02:37:32.480 | I like the tech stack of like Next.js and TypeScript and Tailwind.
02:37:35.480 | It lets me move really quickly and then using Vercel for deploying my apps.
02:37:39.480 | Two final ideas and then I'm going to get off the stage so better speakers can come and tell you about their projects.
02:37:45.480 | But I don't work 24/7 despite what you might think with all of that.
02:37:49.480 | I actually spend most of my weekends relaxing.
02:37:52.480 | But what I do is I work in sprints.
02:37:54.480 | So I'll take a single weekend and I'll just drop everything and go and try to put out a project.
02:37:59.480 | And then for the next like two or three weekends, I'll just binge Netflix shows and hang out with friends and live my life.
02:38:06.480 | So this has worked out for me.
02:38:08.480 | But when I say like I work all weekend, I mean like 12 hours Saturday, 12 hours Sunday kind of deal.
02:38:13.480 | You know, I kind of drop everything and do that.
02:38:15.480 | And so if you have flexibility in your life to do that, you can go ahead and try it.
02:38:19.480 | If you're married or have kids or have other responsibilities, you can experiment with what works for you.
02:38:24.480 | You know, you can spend a couple hours every weekend here and there.
02:38:27.480 | But but that's what I do basically a weekend a month where I sit down and I put out a project and then relax for a little bit.
02:38:33.480 | So, yeah, moral of the story is I think like do what works for you.
02:38:37.480 | I'm just kind of sharing what what's worked for me.
02:38:39.480 | And the final thought I want to put out there is that you need to like put in the hours.
02:38:44.480 | I think a lot of people DM me and are like, hey, like I'm feeling really unmotivated because I'm trying to build these projects and they're taking me so much time.
02:38:52.480 | And like, you know, how do you do it?
02:38:54.480 | Like, what's your secret?
02:38:55.480 | And the first thing I ask them is like, oh, like, I'm sorry to hear that.
02:38:59.480 | How many projects have you built?
02:39:01.480 | And more often than not, they're like, oh, this is my second project.
02:39:05.480 | And I just stare at them and I'm like, you can't go to the gym for the second time ever and then look down and be like, where are my biceps?
02:39:14.480 | Like where?
02:39:15.480 | It doesn't work like that.
02:39:16.480 | You know, you have to go to the gym consistently over months to see progress.
02:39:19.480 | And so the same thing happens with with side projects and coding in general.
02:39:22.480 | And if you're an engineer, that's even better.
02:39:24.480 | I'm not an engineer, actually.
02:39:26.480 | I don't do -- I don't write code for most of my time at work.
02:39:30.480 | And I just learned to code a few years ago.
02:39:31.480 | So I think genuinely anybody can do it.
02:39:33.480 | You just have to kind of put out the -- put in the hours and build and good things will happen.
02:39:40.480 | So thank you so much for having me.
02:39:42.480 | Thank you.
02:39:43.480 | Thank you.
02:39:43.480 | Our next speaker is the co-founder and CEO of RoboFlow.
02:40:00.480 | Please welcome Joseph Nelson.
02:40:11.480 | Hey, everybody.
02:40:12.480 | Joseph.
02:40:13.480 | Today we're going to talk about Paint.WTF, a viral game that we built using OpenAI Clip.
02:40:20.480 | And in its first week, it had 120,000 players.
02:40:23.480 | It was doing seven requests per second.
02:40:25.480 | And I'm going to tell you all about the lessons we learned in multimodality.
02:40:28.480 | And even build a sample version of the app here in five minutes.
02:40:32.480 | So what is Paint.WTF?
02:40:34.480 | We challenged people all across the web to basically play AI Pictionary.
02:40:39.480 | It was like an AI sandwich.
02:40:41.480 | We had GPT-3 generate a bunch of prompts.
02:40:44.480 | Like we prompted it with saying a giraffe in the Arctic.
02:40:47.480 | Or an upside-down dinosaur.
02:40:49.480 | Or a bully that loves capitalism.
02:40:51.480 | And then users were given like a Microsoft Paint-like interface in the browser.
02:40:55.480 | They'd draw.
02:40:56.480 | They'd hit submit.
02:40:57.480 | And then we had clip, contrastive language image retraining, judge and say which image was
02:41:03.480 | most similar to the prompt that was provided.
02:41:06.480 | And people loved it.
02:41:08.480 | I mean, you can tell from these images alone that users had spent tons of thousands of hours
02:41:13.480 | in aggregate submitting and creating different drawings for Paint.
02:41:18.480 | And when I say Microsoft Paint-like interface, I mean literally like just drawing around.
02:41:21.480 | People pulled out their iPads and did such great detail.
02:41:24.480 | And I think as a part of this, I want to share with you the steps that we used to build this.
02:41:30.480 | We're actually going to build a small MVP version of it live together.
02:41:33.480 | To see how simple it is in less than 50 lines of Python and using an open source inference
02:41:38.480 | server.
02:41:39.480 | And then I'll share with you some lessons.
02:41:40.480 | And maybe some warnings about making something that strangers on the internet are allowed to
02:41:45.480 | send you images.
02:41:46.480 | So the premise here, we have GPT generate a prompt that users can draw.
02:41:52.480 | Users can draw on a Microsoft Paint-like interface.
02:41:55.480 | That was just a canvas that we found open source.
02:41:57.480 | And then the third is clip, which I'll describe here in greater depth, judges the vector similarity
02:42:02.480 | of the text embedding of the prompt and the image embedding.
02:42:05.480 | Whichever embeddings are most similar per clip's judgment are the ones that rank top on the leaderboard.
02:42:10.480 | And people love games and the internet.
02:42:12.480 | And so that went mini-viral across Reddit and Hacker News in its first week.
02:42:16.480 | Step four is profit.
02:42:18.480 | That's why you see three question marks.
02:42:19.480 | 120,000 players played it in its first week as mentioned.
02:42:22.480 | And at peak, we were processing seven requests per second.
02:42:25.480 | As a part of this, there's all sorts of fun lessons.
02:42:27.480 | For those that are unfamiliar, the site's still up, and I want to show you a sort of a quick
02:42:33.480 | demo.
02:42:34.480 | Users did incredible, incredible drawings.
02:42:37.480 | This was one of my favorite prompts.
02:42:38.480 | It was a raccoon driving a tractor.
02:42:40.480 | And so users would submit things like this red raccoon, which is probably a case IH, or
02:42:44.480 | a green one, which is a good John Deere.
02:42:46.480 | And notably, the John Deere score is higher, which is clip knows its tractors well.
02:42:50.480 | You'll also notice that the top scoring tractor or raccoon driving a tractor includes a word
02:42:55.480 | there, tractor, as a part of the drawing.
02:42:57.480 | And we'll talk about some learnings we had of what clip knows and doesn't know along the
02:43:01.480 | way.
02:43:02.480 | So a little bit of a clue.
02:43:04.480 | But you can see that this prompt alone had 10,000 submissions.
02:43:07.480 | The prompt for the world's most fabulous monster had 30,000 submissions.
02:43:10.480 | The internet loved this thing.
02:43:12.480 | And in fact, we reloaded it with new prompts just because of demand for folks wanting to do
02:43:16.480 | this.
02:43:17.480 | Another prompt that I just want to quickly show is a bumblebee that loves capitalism.
02:43:20.480 | I like this one because it's more abstract.
02:43:22.480 | And it challenges clip, which presumably -- you know, the data set's not open source from
02:43:26.480 | open AI, but presumably includes some digital art, which is likely how it has an understanding
02:43:31.480 | of relatively low fidelity drawings and concepts and things that it never understood.
02:43:35.480 | And this kind of represents a new primitive in building in AI.
02:43:38.480 | And that's like open form, open set understanding, as opposed to just very specific lists of classes
02:43:43.480 | and models.
02:43:44.480 | And it's this new paradigm of building that's now possible.
02:43:47.480 | So what's going to happen?
02:43:49.480 | We're going to build an app that a text embedding will be produced, and that text embedding will
02:43:55.480 | be the paint.wtf prompt.
02:43:56.480 | That's like the thing that we tell the user to draw.
02:43:58.480 | The user will draw, and we'll get an image embedding of that drawing.
02:44:02.480 | And then we'll do cosine similarity of whichever embedding of the image is most similar to clip's
02:44:10.480 | interpretation of the text is the one that's the winner.
02:44:12.480 | You see a little Superbase logo there?
02:44:14.480 | Superbase is next, so it's good to give a shout out that the leaderboard was powered here by
02:44:19.480 | Superbase.
02:44:20.480 | Woo!
02:44:21.480 | So winning paint.wtf is minimizing the distance between the prompt and the user drawing.
02:44:25.480 | All right, live coding alert.
02:44:26.480 | So let's dive in.
02:44:29.480 | I say let's be a thousand ex-engineers today.
02:44:35.480 | It's a true promise.
02:44:37.480 | We originally built this in 48 hours, and I'm going to try to do it in five minutes.
02:44:40.480 | So, first things first, I did have a little bit of a cheater of a starter code here.
02:44:44.480 | Let me explain to you what we're doing.
02:44:46.480 | We started with using OpenCV, CV2, and that's how we're going to interact with images as they
02:44:51.480 | come in.
02:44:52.480 | We're going to import inference, which is an open source inference server that Robofo builds
02:44:55.480 | and maintains that has powered hundreds of millions of API calls, tens of thousands of
02:45:00.480 | open source models.
02:45:01.480 | We'll also use Supervision for plotting the bounding boxes you'll see here in a second.
02:45:05.480 | I have my render function, which is just going to take the image and draw the bounding box
02:45:10.480 | on top of it.
02:45:11.480 | And then here I'm calling -- I'm starting an inference stream.
02:45:14.480 | Source here refers to the webcam, which for me input 2 is my webcam.
02:45:18.480 | Then I'm going to pull down an open source model called Rock, Paper, Scissors, which is from
02:45:23.480 | Robofo universe, where there's over 50,000 pre-trained, fine-tuned models to your use case.
02:45:28.480 | If you're listening to Hassan and you want an idea of what's a good weekend project I could
02:45:31.480 | build, there's a wealth of starting places on Robofo universe.
02:45:35.480 | So first things first, I'm just going to fire this up so you can see what we get from this.
02:45:45.480 | And this fires up the server, starts a stream, grabs my webcam, and great, here you go.
02:45:49.480 | And you can see me doing my rock, paper, and my scissors.
02:45:52.480 | And I'm not labeling my boxes beyond just the class ID numbers, but you can see that this
02:45:56.480 | runs in real time.
02:45:57.480 | And this is running fully locally on my M1, just from that amount of requirement.
02:46:02.480 | Now, the next thing that we're going to do is we're going to adapt this ever so slightly.
02:46:09.480 | And I'm actually going to -- instead of doing work with -- that was an object detection model,
02:46:14.480 | I'm going to now load Clip.
02:46:16.480 | So first I'm going to import Clip, which in inference is available.
02:46:22.480 | So from inference.models, import Clip.
02:46:25.480 | Then I'm going to instantiate an example of Clip, just that we're going to work with it here.
02:46:30.480 | So I'll create a Clip class.
02:46:33.480 | Great.
02:46:34.480 | So now I have the ability to interact with Clip.
02:46:36.480 | Now, I'm going to also create a prompt.
02:46:38.480 | And with that prompt, we're going to ask Clip to see how similar that prompt is.
02:46:43.480 | Now, for the sake of a fun prompt here, I'm actually going to do something quite of fun.
02:46:48.480 | I'm just going to say a very handsome man.
02:46:51.480 | This is risky.
02:46:52.480 | We're going to ask Clip how handsome I am.
02:46:53.480 | A very handsome man.
02:46:54.480 | And then with that, we're going to embed that in Clip's feature space.
02:46:59.480 | So we're going to do a text embedding.
02:47:01.480 | And that's going to be equal to Clip.embed text.
02:47:06.480 | And we're going to embed our prompt.
02:47:09.480 | Great.
02:47:10.480 | And then I'm just going to print that out.
02:47:12.480 | Print out the text embedding.
02:47:19.480 | All right.
02:47:21.480 | Cool.
02:47:22.480 | And then comment out my render.
02:47:26.480 | All right.
02:47:27.480 | And then let's just keep going from this example.
02:47:31.480 | We should print out our -- oops.
02:47:33.480 | Inference.model.
02:47:35.480 | Inference.models.
02:47:36.480 | Again, 50,000 models available, not just one.
02:47:40.480 | All right.
02:47:42.480 | Oh, I have render still defined.
02:47:45.480 | Let me jump ahead.
02:47:47.480 | All righty.
02:47:49.480 | I've got my ending point here.
02:47:54.480 | And then we'll grab Clip stream.
02:47:59.480 | Yeah.
02:48:00.480 | Cool.
02:48:01.480 | Define my model as Clip.
02:48:02.480 | Great.
02:48:03.480 | Oh.
02:48:04.480 | Oh.
02:48:05.480 | Thank you.
02:48:07.480 | I'll comment that out.
02:48:12.480 | Actually, I'll jump ahead for the sake of time.
02:48:14.480 | I'll just tell you what the render function we're going to do.
02:48:16.480 | With our render function, what we're going to do is we're going to --
02:48:20.480 | well, most of this is just visualization, where I'm going to create a --
02:48:24.480 | get my similarity.
02:48:26.480 | And with my similarity, I'm going to print it on top of the image.
02:48:29.480 | Now, notably, when Clip does similarity, even from the 200,000 submissions we had on paint.wtf,
02:48:35.480 | we only had similarities that were as low as like 13% and as high as like 45%.
02:48:41.480 | And so the first thing that I'm going to do above is I'm just going to scale that range up to 0 to 100.
02:48:48.480 | Then I'm going to print out those similarities, and I'm going to print out the prompt for the user,
02:48:52.480 | and then I'm going to display all those things.
02:48:54.480 | Now, I told you that I was going to display this here.
02:48:57.480 | At the same time, I'm actually going to call on two live volunteers that I think I have ready here.
02:49:03.480 | Natter.
