02:52:51.480 | All right.
02:52:54.480 | All right.
02:52:55.480 | Now let's jump back to the fun stuff.
02:52:56.480 | So I promised you that I'd share with you some lessons of the trials and tribulations of putting
02:53:01.480 | things on the Internet for strangers to submit images.
02:53:04.480 | And I will.
02:53:05.480 | So -- oh, yeah, cool.
02:53:07.480 | So this is all live from -- pip install inference is what we were using and building here.
02:53:11.480 | You start that repo.
02:53:12.480 | The code's all available there.
02:53:13.480 | Plus a series of other examples like SegmentAnything, YOLO models, lots of other sort of ready-to-use models
02:53:20.480 | and capabilities.
02:53:21.480 | All right.
02:53:22.480 | So some first things we learned.
02:53:24.480 | First is clip can read.
02:53:26.480 | People -- users were submitting things like you see this one ranks 586 out of 10,187.
02:53:32.480 | And someone else just wrote a raccoon driving a tractor and ranked 81.
02:53:36.480 | So that was the first learning is that clip can read.
02:53:39.480 | And so actually the way that we fixed this problem is we penalized submissions.
02:53:44.480 | We used clip to moderate clip.
02:53:45.480 | We said, hey, clip, if you think this image is more similar to a bunch of handwriting than
02:53:50.480 | it is to the prompt, then penalize it.
02:53:54.480 | Okay.
02:53:55.480 | All right.
02:53:56.480 | Joseph one, Internet zero.
02:53:58.480 | Clip similarities are very conservative.
02:54:02.480 | So we saw over 20,000 submissions.
02:54:04.480 | The lowest similarity value across all of them was like 8%.
02:54:07.480 | The highest was 48%.
02:54:08.480 | That's why I had that cheater function at the top of render that scaled the lowest value to
02:54:13.480 | zero and the highest value to 100.
02:54:15.480 | And it also provided a bit better of a clear demo with Natter winning the higher mark.
02:54:20.480 | Clip can moderate content.
02:54:22.480 | Huh.
02:54:23.480 | How did we learn this?
02:54:24.480 | We asked anonymous strangers on the Internet to draw things and submit things to us and we
02:54:29.480 | got what we asked for.
02:54:30.480 | So we could ask clip to tell us when things were, you know, more NSFW because sometimes
02:54:35.480 | people would ignore the prompt and just, you know, draw whatever they wanted.
02:54:38.480 | So one of the things we got was this.
02:54:41.480 | And we got a lot of things, unfortunately, like this.
02:54:46.480 | But the way we solved this problem was, hey, clip, if the image is more similar to something
02:54:51.480 | that's not safe for work than it is to something that is similar to the prompt, then block it.
02:54:56.480 | Worked pretty well.
02:54:57.480 | Not hotdog.
02:54:58.480 | Not hotdog.
02:54:59.480 | You could build not hotdog zero shot with clip and inference and probably maybe that's
02:55:03.480 | the next demo.
02:55:04.480 | Now, notably, strangers on the Internet were smart, so they'd like draw the prompt and like
02:55:09.480 | sneak some other stuff in and it's this cat and mouse game with folks online.
02:55:12.480 | The last thing is roll flow inference makes life easy.
02:55:15.480 | As you saw, we just used the inference stream function.
02:55:19.480 | And with that, we've included the learnings of serving hundreds of millions of API calls
02:55:24.480 | across thousands of hours of video as well.
02:55:26.480 | And the reason that's useful is maximize the throughput on our target hardware.
02:55:30.480 | like I was just running an M1 at like 15 FPS.
02:55:33.480 | Ready-to-go foundation models like some of the ones that are listed over here.
02:55:36.480 | And then you can pull in over 50,000 pre-trained models like the rock, paper, scissors one that
02:55:40.480 | I had shown briefly.
02:55:41.480 | So that's it.
02:55:42.480 | Let's make the world programmable.
02:55:43.480 | And thanks, Natter and Squicks.
02:55:44.480 | Give them a good hand.
02:55:45.480 | And they appreciate it for playing along.
02:55:49.480 | Our next speaker is the CEO and co-founder of Supabase.
02:56:08.480 | Please welcome to the stage, Paul Koppelstone.
02:56:11.480 | That's it.
02:56:12.480 | Good one.
02:56:13.480 | Hey, everyone.
02:56:25.480 | So, yeah, I'm Koppel, the CEO and co-founder of Supabase.
02:56:30.480 | Also, thank you for having me, especially to Swicks and Ben.
02:56:34.480 | Swicks asks you to come to a conference.
02:56:36.480 | You don't say yes.
02:56:37.480 | You say definitely.
02:56:39.480 | And this is the first time we've ever sponsored a conference at all.
02:56:43.480 | So, it's good to be here.
02:56:46.480 | So, first of all, very apt that apparently this section of talks is scale to millions in a weekend.
02:56:54.480 | It's very apt because it's actually our tagline.
02:56:57.480 | So, what is Supabase?
02:56:59.480 | We are a backend as a service.
02:57:02.480 | What does that mean?
02:57:04.480 | We give you a full Postgres database.
02:57:08.480 | Every time you launch a database, a project within Supabase, you get the database.
02:57:13.480 | And we also provide you with authentication.
02:57:18.480 | All of the users when you use our auth service are also stored inside that database.
02:57:23.480 | We give you edge functions for compute.
02:57:26.480 | These are powered by Deno.
02:57:27.480 | You can also trigger them from the database.
02:57:29.480 | So, hopefully you see where this is going.
02:57:32.480 | We give you large file storage.
02:57:35.480 | These do not get stored in your database.
02:57:37.480 | But the directory structure does get stored in your database.
02:57:40.480 | So, you can write access rooms, things like that.
02:57:45.480 | So, we have a real-time system.
02:57:47.480 | This is actually the genesis of Supabase.
02:57:50.480 | I won't talk about it in here.
02:57:51.480 | But you can use this to listen to changes coming out of your database, your Postgres database.
02:57:56.480 | You can also use it to build live, like, cursor movements, things like this.
02:58:01.480 | And then, most importantly, for this talk, we have a vector offering.
02:58:06.480 | This is for storing embeddings.
02:58:08.480 | This is powered by PG vector.
02:58:10.480 | And that's the topic of this talk.
02:58:13.480 | I want to sort of make the case for PG vector.
02:58:17.480 | So, first of all, I wanted to show...
02:58:20.480 | And, yeah, finally, we're open source.
02:58:22.480 | So, we've been operating since 2020.
02:58:24.480 | Everything we do is MIT-licensed Apache 2 or Postgres.
02:58:29.480 | We try to support existing communities wherever we can.
02:58:32.480 | And we try to co-exist with them.
02:58:34.480 | And that's largely why we support PG vector.
02:58:36.480 | It is an existing tool.
02:58:38.480 | We contribute to it.
02:58:41.480 | So, I wanted to show a little bit about how the sausage is made in an open source company.
02:58:46.480 | And for PG vector, this started with just an email from Greg.
02:58:52.480 | He said, "I'm sending this email to see what it would take for your team to accept a Postgres extension
02:58:58.480 | called PG vector."
02:58:59.480 | It's a simple yet powerful extension to support vector operations.
02:59:04.480 | I've already done the work.
02:59:05.480 | You can find my pull request on GitHub.
02:59:09.480 | So, I jumped on a call with Greg.
02:59:11.480 | And afterwards, I sent him an email the next day.
02:59:15.480 | "Hey, Greg, the extension has merged.
02:59:17.480 | It should be landing in Prod this week.
02:59:20.480 | By the way, our docs search is currently a bit broken.
02:59:24.480 | Is this something you would be interested in helping with?"
02:59:28.480 | Then, fast forward two weeks and we released Clippy, which is, of course, a throwback to Microsoft Clippy, the OG AI assistant.
02:59:38.480 | I think we were the first to do this within docs.
02:59:42.480 | We certainly didn't know of anyone else doing this as a docs search interface.
02:59:46.480 | So, we built an example, a template around it where you can do this within your own docs.
02:59:51.480 | And others followed suit.
02:59:52.480 | Notably, Mozilla released this for MDN, one of the most popular dev docs on the internet.
02:59:59.480 | Along with many other AI applications.
03:00:02.480 | So, this is a chart of all the new databases being launched on Superbase.com, our platform.
03:00:10.480 | It doesn't include the open source databases.
03:00:14.480 | So, you can see where PGE Vector was added.
03:00:16.480 | It is one of the tailwinds that accelerated the growth of new databases on our platform.
03:00:22.480 | And since then, we've kind of become part of the AI stack for a lot of builders, especially.
03:00:27.480 | We work very well with Vercel, Netlify, the Jamstack crowd.
03:00:32.480 | And now we're launching around 12,000 databases a week.
03:00:36.480 | And so, this, around maybe 10 to 15% of them are using PG Vector in one way or another.
03:00:43.480 | So, thousands of AI applications being launched every week.
03:00:46.480 | Also, some of these apps kind of fit that tagline, build in a weekend, scale to millions.
03:00:52.480 | We've literally had apps, we had one that scaled to a million users in 10 days.
03:00:57.480 | I know they built it in three days.
03:00:59.480 | So, a lot of really bizarre things that we've seen since PG Vector was launched.
03:01:05.480 | Also, the app you're using today, if you're using it, is powered by Superbase.
03:01:11.480 | So, thank you, Simon, for using that inside the application.
03:01:15.480 | And then finally, just to wrap up that story arc.
03:01:18.480 | Greg, who emailed us at the start of the year, now works at Superbase.
03:01:23.480 | If you attended the workshop yesterday, he actually was the one leading that.
03:01:30.480 | Nice.
03:01:31.480 | Thanks, Greg.
03:01:32.480 | Also, responsible for a lot of the growth in Superbase.
03:01:37.480 | So, we owe him a lot.
03:01:40.480 | But, every good story has a few speed bumps.
03:01:43.480 | And for PG Vector, that started with a tweet.
03:01:47.480 | This is one.
03:01:48.480 | It says, why you should never use PG Vector, Superbase Vector Store, for production.
03:01:54.480 | PG Vector is 20 times slower than a decent vector database, Quadrant.
03:01:59.480 | And it's a full 18% worse in finding relevant docs for you.
03:02:03.480 | So, in this chart, higher is better.
03:02:06.480 | It's the queries per second.
03:02:08.480 | Just making sure you all know.
03:02:10.480 | And Postgres, the IVF flat index is not doing well here.
03:02:15.480 | And first of all, we feel this is an unfair mischaracterization of Superbase because PG Vector
03:02:22.480 | is actually owned by Andrew Kane, a single sole contributor who developed this many years before
03:02:30.480 | Superbase came along.
03:02:31.480 | Nonetheless, we are contributors.
03:02:33.480 | And so, when Andrew saw the tweet, he decided, well, HNSW, let's just add it.
03:02:41.480 | And we got to work with the Aureole team and the AWS team.
03:02:45.480 | And it took about one month to build in HNSW.
03:02:49.480 | What were the results?
03:02:52.480 | This is the same chart, but we just use Postgres HNSW.
03:02:58.480 | First of all, I'm not a big fan of benchmarks because it seems like I'm ragging on Quadrant here.
03:03:10.480 | It's not.
03:03:11.480 | Unfortunately, they were used in the tweet, so we had to benchmark against them.
03:03:16.480 | Also, they're very isolated.
03:03:18.480 | But what you can see most importantly is that the queries per second increased and also the accuracy increase.
03:03:25.480 | They're both for Quadrant and HNSW 0.99.
03:03:31.480 | Also, you might be thinking, well, you can just throw compute at it.
03:03:35.480 | Maybe that's what they're doing.
03:03:37.480 | This one actually is a blog post we released today.
03:03:40.480 | You can read it.
03:03:41.480 | That's the QR code for it.
03:03:42.480 | This is an apples for apples comparison between Pinecone and Postgres for the same compute.
03:03:49.480 | We basically take the same dollar value.
03:03:52.480 | So, it's very hard to benchmark Pinecone and to find accuracy.
03:03:57.480 | But we're measuring the queries per second for Pinecone using six replicas, which cost $480,
03:04:05.480 | versus one of our database systems, which is $410.
03:04:09.480 | So, we give them a bit of extra compute and the queries per second and accuracy are obviously different on the chart.
03:04:20.480 | So, why am I bullish about Postgres and PG Vector for this particular thing?
03:04:25.480 | I was chatting to Joseph, actually the CEO of RoboFlow, a few months ago.
03:04:30.480 | And I like to tell this example.
03:04:32.480 | It's related actually to the Paint one, but a slightly different application.
03:04:36.480 | I like to tell it because it highlights the power of Postgres.
03:04:39.480 | So, he told me about this app where the users could take photos of trash within San Francisco
03:04:46.480 | and then they would upload it to an embedding store.
03:04:48.480 | And they would kind of measure the trends of trash throughout San Francisco.
03:04:54.480 | You could think of this the same as the Painter WTF, the example that he just used.
03:05:01.480 | The problem, of course, with all of these ones is not safe for work images.
03:05:07.480 | So, why is that a problem?
03:05:14.480 | First of all, it fills up your embedding store.
03:05:17.480 | You have to store the data.
03:05:18.480 | It's going to cost you more.
03:05:20.480 | Your indexes are going to slow down if you're indexing this content and users can see this data inside the app.
03:05:26.480 | So, I thought about this for an hour and I did a little proof of concept for him just using Postgres.
03:05:32.480 | The solution that I thought of was partitions.
03:05:35.480 | Now, trash is very boring, so I'm going to use cats in this example.
03:05:39.480 | We're going to segment good cats and bad cats.
03:05:42.480 | So, we'll start with a basic table where we're going to store all of our cats.
03:05:47.480 | We're going to store the embeddings inside them.
03:05:50.480 | Then, when an embedding is uploaded, we're going to call a function called isCats.
03:05:56.480 | Here, I'm going to compare it to a canonical cat.
03:06:00.480 | In this case, my space cat.
03:06:03.480 | Then, if the similarity is greater than 0.8, I'll store it in a good cats partition and everything else can just go into a bad cats partition.
03:06:13.480 | So, to do this, I just took my space cat and I generated a vector of that.
03:06:20.480 | And then, I literally just stuffed it inside a Postgres function called isCat.
03:06:24.480 | The way that this works, it takes in an embedding that's the line three.
03:06:29.480 | Then, it's going to return a float, a similarity, basically.
03:06:36.480 | And all it's going to do is compare the distance to this canonical cat.
03:06:41.480 | I'm going to create a table to store all of my embeddings.
03:06:45.480 | That's line five, the embeddings, the URL of the image.
03:06:48.480 | And then, finally, on line six, we're going to determine the similarity.
03:06:52.480 | if it is a good cat or a bad cat.
03:06:57.480 | Then, finally, Postgres has this thing called triggers, which are very cool.
03:07:01.480 | What we can do is attach a trigger to a table.
03:07:04.480 | So, first of all, line two, we're going to create the trigger.
03:07:07.480 | Line three, we're going to do it before the insert onto this table.
03:07:11.480 | And then, the most important one is line six.
03:07:14.480 | And this trigger, for every time you upload a cat,
03:07:18.480 | we're going to run that function that we just saw, compare it,
03:07:22.480 | and then store in the table the similarity.
03:07:26.480 | New here is actually kind of a special value for Postgres.
03:07:29.480 | Inside the trigger, it's for the values that you're about to insert.
03:07:33.480 | And then, finally, what does the data look like?
03:07:36.480 | After uploading a bunch of images,
03:07:38.480 | you can see here that we're storing all of our embeddings,
03:07:41.480 | the URLs for them, and then, on the right-hand side,
03:07:44.480 | that similarity.
03:07:45.480 | And now we can use that, essentially, to create a segment.
03:07:49.480 | So, we just need to split the data.
03:07:52.480 | And the nice thing about partitions in Postgres,
03:07:56.480 | they've got kind of all the properties of a regular table
03:07:59.480 | and each one individually.
03:08:00.480 | So, we can create an index only on the good cats.
03:08:03.480 | And then, to clean up, as our bad cats are getting uploaded,
03:08:07.480 | if we ever want to clean them up,
03:08:09.480 | we just drop the partition and recreate it.
03:08:11.480 | And the way that they work on disk
03:08:13.480 | is all the data is stored grouped together.
03:08:16.480 | So, good cats will be kept fast.
03:08:20.480 | Bad cats will be dropped.
03:08:24.480 | So, what does that look like in code?
03:08:26.480 | In Postgres code, it's really just 14,
03:08:28.480 | 13, 14 lines of code.
03:08:30.480 | Here, just adding on line 7.
03:08:33.480 | You can see the partition that I create.
03:08:35.480 | And I'm going to do it by a range.
03:08:37.480 | Here, is cat is the column that I'm going to partition by.
03:08:42.480 | Then, on line 9, I create good cats.
03:08:45.480 | And line 11 is where I actually determine the values.
03:08:49.480 | Between 0.8 and 1.
03:08:51.480 | And then, on line 13, everything else is going to fall into the default partition.
03:08:57.480 | So, honestly, I don't even know if this is the right way to solve the problem.
03:09:01.480 | But I just think it's cool that I could just do that.
03:09:03.480 | And it's all built into Postgres.
03:09:06.480 | So, that's really why I'm bullish on Postgres.
03:09:09.480 | I mean, it's so extensible.
03:09:11.480 | It's got 30 years of engineering.
03:09:13.480 | It's got pretty much everything that you --
03:09:15.480 | all the primitives that you might need to get out of your way
03:09:19.480 | while you are building an AI application.
03:09:21.480 | It's also extensible.
03:09:23.480 | PG vector itself is not built into Postgres.
03:09:26.480 | It's just an extension.
03:09:27.480 | So, for us to add it, we just scouted around the community,
03:09:30.480 | or Greg did in this case,
03:09:32.480 | and then we merged it in as an extension,
03:09:34.480 | and it was running basically within two days.
03:09:38.480 | Some other things worth highlighting,
03:09:41.480 | if you're doing RAG especially,
03:09:43.480 | Postgres has row-level security,
03:09:45.480 | which I think is very cool.
03:09:46.480 | This allows you to write declarative rules on your tables
03:09:50.480 | inside your Postgres database.
03:09:52.480 | And so, if you're storing user data
03:09:54.480 | and you want to split it up by different users,
03:09:57.480 | you can actually write those rules.
03:09:59.480 | It's also a defense at depth.
03:10:01.480 | So, if it gets through maybe your API security,
03:10:04.480 | you can go directly into your database.
03:10:07.480 | The security is still there.
03:10:10.480 | Something that's often not captured in benchmarks,
03:10:13.480 | a single round trip versus multiple round trips.
03:10:16.480 | So, if you store your embeddings next to your operational data,
03:10:20.480 | then you do a single fetch to your database.
03:10:23.480 | And then, finally, we're still early.
03:10:29.480 | PG vector is currently an extension.
03:10:32.480 | I can foresee it's probably going to get merged into PG core eventually.
03:10:37.480 | I'm not too sure.
03:10:38.480 | People often ask me, is there still space for a specialized vector database?
03:10:44.480 | Yes, I think there are.
03:10:45.480 | For many other things that databases won't do.
03:10:50.480 | Maybe a lot of putting models closer to the database could be one of those things.
03:10:55.480 | But for this particular use case where you're actually just storing embeddings,
03:10:59.480 | indexing them, fetching them out,
03:11:01.480 | I think then, yeah, Postgres is definitely going to be moving down that direction.
03:11:08.480 | What's next for super-based vector?
03:11:10.480 | Pretty simply, we have been really focused on more enterprise use cases.
03:11:16.480 | Or largely, how do you store billions of vectors?
03:11:20.480 | This is another area that needs development.
03:11:23.480 | So, we've been working on sharding with Citus, another Postgres extension.
03:11:27.480 | And it allows you to split your data between different nodes.
03:11:32.480 | And we've found that the transactions scale in a linear fashion as you add nodes.
03:11:38.480 | So, in this case, we're going to develop this.
03:11:41.480 | We've been chatting to the Citus team at Microsoft.
03:11:44.480 | If you want to be a design partner on this, then we'd love to work with you on it.
03:11:48.480 | And especially if you're already storing billions of embeddings.
03:11:52.480 | And if you want to get started, just go to database.new.
03:11:56.480 | And we also have, apparently now, our swag has finally arrived.
03:12:00.480 | So, if you want some free credits and swag, come see us at the booth.
03:12:03.480 | And happy building.
03:12:04.480 | Thank you so much.
03:12:14.480 | Thank you so much, Paul.
03:12:15.480 | And thank you to all of our speakers.

03:13:56.480 | Thank you.
03:13:56.480 | Thank you.
03:13:57.480 | Thank you.
03:14:01.480 | I'm a serial entrepreneur and I'm super excited to talk to you about fine tuning large language
03:14:26.660 | models today without any code.
03:14:29.400 | So let's begin.
03:14:30.980 | For our purposes today, fine tuning is training a foundation model for a specialized task.
03:14:37.320 | Some examples of these specialized tasks are writing any kind of copy emails, blog articles,
03:14:42.660 | product descriptions.
03:14:43.660 | It could be scrubbing fake emails from a list, extracting or normalizing data, translating,
03:14:49.020 | paraphrasing, rewriting, qualifying a sales lead, ranking priority of support issues, detecting
03:14:55.480 | fraud or flagging inappropriate content.
03:14:58.460 | These are very common tasks that businesses do every day.
03:15:01.800 | And something they have in common is that traditional programming or rule based approaches do not work
03:15:07.460 | well for them.
03:15:08.140 | But large language models are great at them.
03:15:11.140 | So they perform them easily and they can capture the nuance in the text that you're working with.
03:15:16.480 | So why should we fine tune?
03:15:17.480 | I mean, prompt engineering is great, right?
03:15:19.480 | You can do almost all of these things with a prompt.
03:15:21.820 | Well, I'll tell you fine tuning is awesome.
03:15:25.160 | It's faster and cheaper because you can train a lighter model to match the quality of what you are doing with a prompt.
03:15:32.160 | It reduces the size of your prompts, allowing for longer completions.
03:15:36.500 | Training examples allow you to cover edge cases and collaborate better as a team.
03:15:41.040 | And it's naturally resistant to prompt injection attacks.
03:15:45.680 | So let's dive into some of these.
03:15:47.380 | How much faster is it really?
03:15:49.380 | Well, if you take GPT-4 and its response time per token, it's about 196 milliseconds, give or take, from the OpenAI API.
03:15:58.380 | On the same API, GPT-3.5 is 73 milliseconds.
03:16:03.220 | That's three times faster.
03:16:06.220 | How much cheaper is it?
03:16:07.360 | Well, taking an example with GPT-4 versus GPT-3.5 fine-tuned, you can save 88.6%.
03:16:15.800 | Well, then how much shorter do the prompts actually get?
03:16:18.360 | Well, I'll give you one example because it's going to vary depending on your prompt.
03:16:22.040 | But here's what a typical engineered prompt might look like.
03:16:25.180 | It has some instructions saying to, you know, write a blog post on this topic, how to write it, what tone to use, what to do, what not to do.
03:16:34.960 | Well, with a fine-tuned model, it learns how we write.
03:16:38.460 | So we don't need all of those instructions.
03:16:40.520 | It learns from our training examples.
03:16:43.000 | So we're just giving it the one thing that's unique about this prompt versus another prompt, which is the topic that we want to write on.
03:16:50.340 | And in this very conservative example, it's 90% shorter.
03:16:56.340 | Now let's talk about collaborating as a team, right?
03:16:58.580 | Because none of us work in a vacuum.
03:17:00.120 | We work with other people.
03:17:02.120 | Imagine a GitHub repo.
03:17:03.760 | You have one file.
03:17:05.260 | Your whole code base is just one file.
03:17:07.160 | That's like your epic prompt.
03:17:08.660 | Well, with fine-tuning, now you can have multiple files like we're used to, where developers can work on this section of code or that section of code.
03:17:16.860 | But we're not talking about code, we're talking about training examples.
03:17:20.760 | So your training data is this layer that your team can work on and add to and edit and improve, and then that feeds into the fine-tuned model.
03:17:29.880 | So the main point is, if you can get equal or better output, why wouldn't you fine-tune a model?
03:17:36.340 | Now, fine-tuning is kind of a dev job right now, okay?
03:17:41.440 | Let's be real.
03:17:42.340 | If you go online and you look up how to do fine-tuning, you can find articles that talk about how to spin up GPU servers for training and inference, and you've got to format your data with these ad hoc Python scripts, and configure these parameters, and then make API calls.
03:17:56.020 | It just looks like a dev job, but if you really break it down, why can't we just automate all of that with a user interface?
03:18:04.360 | Is that possible?
03:18:05.860 | It is possible, and the bar is lower than most people think to get started doing this.
03:18:12.500 | If you can get 20 examples of what you want your fine-tuned model to do, you can fine-tune a model.
03:18:18.340 | This is not traditional machine learning where you need thousands of examples to get started, and the data set is this impossible barrier to get past.
03:18:27.240 | No, this is something that you could handwrite these if you want to.
03:18:31.220 | One way to think about this is as an extension to few-shot learning.
03:18:34.680 | Let's say you can have five examples of what you want a model to do in your prompt.
03:18:39.360 | Well, with fine-tuning, your training example data set can be as long as you want.
03:18:44.200 | So instead of five examples, you can now have 20 or 100.
03:18:47.400 | So it seems intuitive that with more examples, the model would be able to do closer to what we want it to do.
03:18:53.900 | So here's what I propose for a dev lifecycle for large language models.
03:18:59.020 | We start with prompt engineering.
03:19:01.020 | Prompt engineering is a powerful tool.
03:19:03.080 | It allows us to create a prototype to validate the concept,
03:19:06.320 | and we can also use it to create our initial data sets for fine-tuning.
03:19:11.160 | Once we have those data sets, we should fine-tune a model and we should evaluate it to make sure that it actually is better than the prompt engineered version.
03:19:19.740 | And then we can test which models we can get to perform at the same level.
03:19:24.100 | Then the fine-tuned model can go into production, and from production, we can capture feedback from our users and we can log the examples.
03:19:30.940 | And with those examples, we can continuously improve our fine-tuned model, because now all of a sudden we have the real examples that we can add back into our data set.
03:19:40.940 | So in terms of roles, I think that there's a huge opportunity for people to get into prompt engineering and fine-tuning who are not developers.
03:19:48.780 | Yes, if you're a developer, you can fine-tune.
03:19:51.280 | Absolutely.
03:19:52.280 | But you shouldn't have to be the only person that can fine-tune.
03:19:55.480 | I'm a co-founder at EntryPoint, and we have built the modern tooling to make this easy.
03:20:00.400 | Let's take a look at how it works.
03:20:01.900 | Here we are on the dashboard, and I'm going to open the PressReleaseWriter project.
03:20:06.240 | Let's take a look at my 20 examples.
03:20:10.000 | The way I created these 20 examples for a press release generator was I went online and I found 20 press releases that looked really good.
03:20:18.660 | They came from blog articles about the best press releases that you can write.
03:20:22.860 | However, I didn't have input data, so my data set was incomplete.
03:20:26.400 | But I used ChatGPT4 to take the press release and then write a list of facts that would be needed to actually have a professional writer write such a press release.
03:20:38.740 | You know, large language models aren't great at facts, so providing it the facts as the input makes sense to me that I want to give it a list of facts and then have it write something that's really polished that would be a really good first draft of a press release.
03:20:51.160 | With this user interface, I have a lot of visibility into the data that I'm actually putting into my fine tune model, which I think is really important.
03:20:58.660 | And the way this works is that we have a structured data approach.
03:21:02.500 | So when you import like a CSV into EntryPoint, each column becomes a field.
03:21:08.380 | Here I have the facts and here I have the press release.
03:21:11.320 | And these fields you can use in a template, just like you were writing a mass email and you want to insert somebody's first name or personalize the emails with information about a contact record.
03:21:21.160 | You can use references to these fields with the handlebars templating language.
03:21:26.660 | It provides a really intuitive way to easily format your output, your input and GPT 3.5 turbo.
03:21:35.500 | When you fine tune it, you can actually use the system prompt, which is where you can include instructions as well, which creates this really interesting hybrid between prompt engineering and fine tuning where you can have a small data set for fine tuning.
03:21:46.880 | But you can also give it some instructions to help.
03:21:49.940 | Once we have a data set like this, we can go and we can go to our fine tunes, press the add button, select the model, the platform, because this is cross platform, and then we count your tokens and estimate your cost for you.
03:22:03.140 | This is going to be a whole dollar, so hold on tight, press start, and that will get started.
03:22:11.240 | But I have some here that are already trained, so let's go into one and use entry point playground and see if we can actually generate a press release with our fine tune model.
03:22:20.100 | The list of facts here, I actually wrote about the AI engineer summit, and we'll see if we can make a press release for the AI engineer summit.
03:22:27.860 | Let's go.
03:22:29.960 | All right, so this fine tune model created a title here, and it made it look like a press release.
03:22:37.100 | What I found to be a really cool workflow is to actually create a list of facts and then generate an article, read the article, and then get ideas from it and go back to my list of facts and refine those, and then that actually becomes an iterative process to get really cool results.
03:22:51.860 | So I really enjoy fine tuning, it takes a lot of the boilerplate out of the prompt, and you can just focus on what's important for the results you want, and the rest is taken care of by your training data.
03:23:03.440 | Entry point has a lot of other cool features like data synthesis and tools to compare the performance of your fine tune models.
03:23:09.920 | Unfortunately, we don't have time to go into all of that today, but I hope you will check it out.
03:23:14.240 | It's entrypointai.com, and it was a pleasure speaking to you.
03:23:23.240 | Hi, this is Niklas, I'm the CTO and co-founder of Log10, and we want to talk about how you can scale reliability of LLM applications using a new tool that we've built.
03:23:36.020 | During this year, I think we all can agree that there's been like this kind of craze in the industry, and we've been rolling out a ton of intelligence features based on GPT.
03:23:46.020 | And we're now kind of finding ourselves in a "now what" moment, because without knowing what good means in a generative setting, it's really hard and risky to evolve your applications by changing your prompts, configurations, let alone considering going from one model provider to another, to more advanced use cases like self-hosting or fine tuning.
03:24:09.020 | We want to introduce a new tool today called LLM eval, that enables teams to ship reliable LLM products.
03:24:21.020 | It is a command line tool that you can run locally, and with these four lines of code, you should be good to go.
03:24:32.020 | The initialization creates a folder structure, and best practices for storing prompts and tests.
03:24:41.020 | And then this is based on a super configurable system from Meta called Hydra.
03:24:48.020 | So you can basically extend it to your heart's desire and the metrics that we have wired up are in Python.
03:24:56.020 | So they could be any logic, could be called out to all the LLMs, whatever you want.
03:25:01.020 | And after these evaluations have been run, you can generate some reports that basically gives you like a brief overview of how the entire app and all the tests are looking, but still supports flexible test criteria.
03:25:17.020 | Because like these models are very fuzzy.
03:25:19.020 | It's very hard to say with a guarantee that it's going to be one or the other, but it's fairly safe to say that the majority cases or say three out of five should pass.
03:25:30.020 | And we're going to jump into command line and taking a look.
03:25:36.020 | We're just going to create a directory for today.
03:25:43.020 | And go into this directory and create ourselves a virtual environment.
03:25:50.020 | So from here, we're going to install LIM eval and initialize the folder structure.
03:26:01.020 | What we should be able to see here is a directory structure where we have our prompts.
03:26:11.020 | And see, a simple case could be this, where we have this message template saying like, what is A plus B?
03:26:17.020 | Only return the answer without any explanation.
03:26:19.020 | So in this case, we know that we have to prompt engineer further, you know, to get an exact output.
03:26:26.020 | Because let's take a look at how the test looks like.
03:26:29.020 | In this case, we're taking like the actual output from the LNM and comparing it with the expected.
03:26:37.020 | And this is like a strict comparison.
03:26:39.020 | What we have taken the liberty to do is to strip any spaces that might come from the left.
03:26:46.020 | And that's because some models, in this case Claude, tends to prepend spaces.
03:26:51.020 | And so it's things like that that you have to watch out for.
03:26:55.020 | And then we have the metric, which could be any metric that you want to surface in the report.
03:27:00.020 | And then the result, which is then pass or fail.
03:27:03.020 | And in this case, we want to add four and five, and we expect it to be nine.
03:27:08.020 | And I'm just going to try to run this test here and try to revert some of the prompt engineering that we did earlier.
03:27:16.020 | So I'm going to remove only return the answer without any explanation.
03:27:27.020 | And the way you get started is the LNM email run.
03:27:31.020 | But if you want to override anything, if you just do LNM email run, it runs everything.
03:27:36.020 | But if you do like prompts equals math, then it's only going to run the math example.
03:27:42.020 | If you do N tries one, then it's just going to do one sample.
03:27:49.020 | By default, we do five samples.
03:27:53.020 | So we get like a better read on the stability of each test, but it might be too much for you.
03:27:58.020 | But you can override anything.
03:28:00.020 | You can find these default settings here in the LMEval YAML.
03:28:06.020 | But let's try to run this and see what happens.
03:28:09.020 | And so this ran across Claude, GPT-4, and GPT-3.5 once.
03:28:15.020 | So we can go in and generate a report.
03:28:18.020 | And see that actually something failed.
03:28:22.020 | What was it that failed?
03:28:23.020 | Let's take a look at the output here.
03:28:25.020 | And in this case, because we've removed our problem engineering, GPT-3.5 starts being a bit chatty.
03:28:33.020 | It says like 4.5 equals 9.
03:28:35.020 | Claude does something similar.
03:28:37.020 | So it kind of writes out the equation.
03:28:40.020 | And now I'm going to try to revert.
03:28:44.020 | And see, let's get this in.
03:28:47.020 | And we try to run one more time.
03:28:53.020 | Great.
03:28:54.020 | Now when we change the report, it could say some tests failed, but the most recent tests that ran passed.
03:29:00.020 | So when you do the report, it's going to generate a summary.
03:29:03.020 | You can generate a report per run.
03:29:06.020 | But then also say overall, was there anything that failed out of these reports?
03:29:12.020 | If you want to go a bit more advanced, let's say you want to use tools.
03:29:17.020 | We have an example here where we are generating some Python code.
03:29:21.020 | And again, we had to add a number of different clauses to make sure that it only outputs Python.
03:29:27.020 | It tends to be very happy generating surrounding explanations.
03:29:32.020 | So in this case, we are going to see whether or not it returns an actual Python program that could be parsed.
03:29:41.020 | So let's try to run that.
03:29:45.020 | If you go in and take a look at this report, you can see that these tests actually end up passing our tool use.
03:29:54.020 | And to round up, we have model-based evaluation as well, where you can test using other models.
03:30:03.020 | And so in this case, say with grading, we can go in and define like a full set of criteria.
03:30:10.020 | Here, we're evaluating mermaid diagrams, giving a score between one and five and the reason.
03:30:17.020 | And that is also supported in L11Eval.
03:30:20.020 | One thing about the previous approach is that it takes quite an amount of work to set up these tests and gather your test cases.
03:30:29.020 | And one really compelling answer to evaluation has been model-based evaluation.
03:30:34.020 | And it's a setting where you have typically a larger model discriminate or grade or be a judge over the output from another LLM.
03:30:44.020 | And that makes it so you can get more nuanced output like pass/fail or a grade from one to five or preferences between different options and its reasoning behind it.
03:30:55.020 | There's a number of pitfalls, unfortunately, around this approach, around biases towards the output from the model itself.
03:31:04.020 | If you're sweeping different models, they tend to prefer their own output.
03:31:07.020 | They're not very good at giving point scores, saying anything between 0 and 1, or larger scores between 0 and 100.
03:31:16.020 | But there are different ways where you can start increasing the accuracy of the kind of feedback that's been generated.
03:31:24.020 | And we've been working on this where you basically start bridging between model-based and human feedback.
03:31:33.020 | So instead of removing the human completely from the feedback, you start taking in all the feedback that might have been given prior and start modeling it.
03:31:42.020 | And say, like, if you have all the feedback from John, then we create an auto-John that will start generating feedback for review for any incoming completions.
03:31:52.020 | So in this case here, we have two pieces of feedback that's been already given by a human.
03:31:56.020 | So here it was all just like a score of five or here it was like a bit more nuanced.
03:32:03.020 | But here we are kind of pending feedback.
03:32:06.020 | And if you click this, we have AI suggested an answer to this.
03:32:11.020 | And that's all I have today.
03:32:15.020 | If you want to get started on LLM email, we have our documentation at our usual documentation site.
03:32:23.020 | And you can find me at Nicholas Coifford on X or formerly known as Twitter, or it should be an email at nick@log10.io.
03:32:32.020 | Thank you.
03:32:38.020 | Hi, my name is Flo and I'm excited to do this talk for the AI.engineer conference.
03:32:43.020 | I'm very passionate about the AI space, especially generative AI and language models.
03:32:48.020 | I've dropped almost everything I was doing to focus on this space for the past year or so.
03:32:54.020 | And I've played around with every generative AI tool I could get my hands on using my home setup.
03:32:59.020 | I've taken a few courses, but I could be described as a junior AI engineer at best.
03:33:03.020 | So no credentials, just vibes.
03:33:07.020 | So take anything I say with a grain of salt.
03:33:09.020 | With that being said, I want to show you guys some visualized data sets.
03:33:14.020 | These are the data sets that were used to fine tune some of the most performant open language models.
03:33:20.020 | The resulting fine tune models are not popular just because they did well on some benchmark, but because they're actually useful.
03:33:27.020 | Okay, this first data set is Puffin.
03:33:30.020 | It is only 3000 records long.
03:33:32.020 | It's a very small but potent and was really touted as one of the best data sets to fine tune a base model with despite its size.
03:33:39.020 | If you're not familiar, this is a scatter plot.
03:33:42.020 | And here, if we hover over any of the plots, we can see the sentences that fall within the topic cluster.
03:33:49.020 | The process we use also outputs word scores.
03:33:53.020 | So you can look into the biggest topics and see what words occur the most.
03:33:57.020 | Moving on to the second data set, this is the Skunkworks MOE data set.
03:34:01.020 | If you've been under a rock, GPT-4 is in the lead.
03:34:04.020 | But the open source community, which seems to include Zuckerberg and his AI team at Meta, are frantically trying to catch up to the quality of GPT-4.
03:34:12.020 | This data set represents one of those efforts to catch up.
03:34:16.020 | The official Skunkworks MOE data set is 1.5 million rows of data.
03:34:21.020 | And this is one of the caveats I'll go over later, but not all 1.5 million rows of data is in this graph.
03:34:28.020 | This is about 10% of that that's represented here.
03:34:31.020 | But with this tool, you can actually break down the data however you want.
03:34:34.020 | You can include all 1.5 million rows if you would like.
03:34:37.020 | Here we can see some of the words that were mentioned the most in the biggest topic clusters.
03:34:43.020 | Okay, so using this tool, we actually output two different kinds of scatterplots using two different plugins.
03:34:49.020 | So you have the option to explore clusters in a couple different ways.
03:34:53.020 | Moving on to the last data set, this one is open Hermes or Hermes.
03:34:58.020 | But this is another one of the data sets that's used to fine tune some of the top models.
03:35:02.020 | Now I'm quickly going over these just to showcase how different these data sets can look.
03:35:07.020 | And it really just shows a wide range of vocabulary topics, plot shapes and spread.
03:35:12.020 | Okay, so who should visualize their data?
03:35:15.020 | Visualizing a data set that you have created may be very useful to you.
03:35:19.020 | I have some things in the notebook that we're going to go over later that can reveal some conversations that may be surprising to you.
03:35:25.020 | Let's say you work for a company or an organization and you want to fine tune a model on company data, you're curating data sets.
03:35:32.020 | Or maybe you want to combine company data with one of these top performing open source data sets.
03:35:37.020 | Or lane chain agents.
03:35:39.020 | Let's say you're using an agent to not only query your docs, but also collect data for you over time, you can visualize that data.
03:35:45.020 | Or let's say you're doing retrieval RAG.
03:35:48.020 | You can compile a list of all the documents you've embedded and visualize the topics of the documents.
03:35:53.020 | This can be useful in a lot of different agent scenarios.
03:35:56.020 | This talk is also for someone like myself.
03:35:58.020 | I initially started learning this process because I wanted to understand what's so special about what's in these data sets.
03:36:04.020 | I want to build my own data for fine tuning.
03:36:06.020 | I just think there's something powerful about being able to easily visualize what's in a large set of data.
03:36:12.020 | You know, I alluded to some of these earlier, but being able to get a glimpse at how the data is clustered in your data set is important.
03:36:18.020 | You know, maybe you're heavy on the math side or maybe your data set could use some more logic and reasoning.
03:36:23.020 | But seeing what you need more or less of can help.
03:36:26.020 | You know, I love learning about SQL and databases, you know, CSVs and Excel.
03:36:30.020 | But I think looking at this stuff visually unlocks a different perspective.
03:36:33.020 | The fact that you can keep your data local is also helpful.
03:36:36.020 | This method does not require any open AI models because maybe it's not just private company data, but personal data that you're collecting.
03:36:43.020 | You know, something I actually find really intriguing is these role playing models.
03:36:47.020 | So this method may be great for taking a peek at those NSFW data sets.
03:36:52.020 | There are some caveats that come with this process and I'll speak on this more later in the tutorial.
03:36:56.020 | But sometimes you can't fit the whole data set into an interactive graph, especially if we're talking about 500,000, a million, 50 million rows of data.
03:37:05.020 | It becomes very difficult to plot that using HTML.
03:37:07.020 | The other thing is that these models are non-deterministic.
03:37:10.020 | You could use the same settings over multiple runs and still end up with slightly different topics and labels.
03:37:15.020 | Okay, so how do we actually do this?
03:37:18.020 | If you're on a gaming PC, I recommend that you have a 30, 60 or better.
03:37:22.020 | I think AMD and Intel GPUs can work, but there will be no CUDA cores to take advantage of.
03:37:28.020 | So the process will be a little slower.
03:37:30.020 | If you're on an Apple computer, having an M1 or an M2 should allow you to get through this process.
03:37:34.020 | You'll just have to do it using CPU, at least until the GGML guys work their magic.
03:37:38.020 | As far as operating systems go, if you're on Windows, please just use WSL.
03:37:42.020 | I struggled to get this to work on Windows natively.
03:37:45.020 | If you're on Mac OS or Linux, any Unix based operating system, you should be good to go.
03:37:49.020 | If all else fails, you can still use Google Colab.
03:37:52.020 | Maybe I'm a little superstitious, it's just not as private.
03:37:55.020 | All of the steps that I'm going to take in this tutorial is already uploaded to a repo on my GitHub.
03:38:00.020 | I'll try and have the link somewhere here on the screen, as well as in the description of this video.
03:38:04.020 | In that repo, you'll find the notebook and any snippets of code that I use to make this happen.
03:38:09.020 | In going through that process over the last few weeks, I've learned a bunch, but I think these are the highlights.
03:38:14.020 | When I work closely with creators, there's always something in the dataset that they did not consider.
03:38:19.020 | I think that's one of the easiest things to pull from visualizing a dataset.
03:38:22.020 | Another thing is if you have to present this information to a manager or a board or an investor, this is a way to do it so everyone can easily understand.
03:38:31.020 | And for everyone else that's curious about the data like myself, these are some of the other tools on my radar.
03:38:37.020 | Bulk, Galactic, Lilac have gotten a lot of attention over the last few weeks.

03:39:12.020 | I actually enjoy those comments because I learned a lot from them, but seriously, please comment.
03:39:17.020 | I'll be monitoring and answering any questions.
03:39:19.020 | And in closing, please use this process and send me visualizations.
03:39:23.020 | Like I'm a visual person and I want to see, you know, nice, pretty graphs of your datasets.
03:39:28.020 | Thanks.
03:39:29.020 | Hey, hey, hey.
03:39:35.020 | How's everyone?
03:39:36.020 | This is Simrit Hanspal, technical evangelist at Hasura.
03:39:40.020 | And today I'm going to talk to you about building efficient hybrid rack queries.
03:39:45.020 | Let us understand this with the use case of product search in e-commerce domain.
03:39:51.020 | Present day product search is mostly keyword based.
03:39:55.020 | Keywords are not great at capturing the complete intent of the user search query.
03:39:59.020 | So you want to move to using natural language.
03:40:01.020 | But product search can be either contextual where you're looking for, where you're searching for product based on the descriptive nature.
03:40:08.020 | Or, or it can be completely structured where you're querying based on the structured fields.
03:40:13.020 | Or it can be both.
03:40:15.020 | Large language models are great, but they're frozen in time and they cannot solve tasks on data they have not seen before.
03:40:22.020 | One of the ways to expose the unseen data to large language model is by providing context to the question alongside the question.
03:40:29.020 | This helps the large language model generate more accurate and grounded answers.
03:40:35.020 | This powerful technique is called retrieval augmented generation or RAG in short.
03:40:40.020 | So you see, we need to build a RAG pipeline for our product search use case.
03:40:44.020 | We also need to make sure that our RAG pipeline is production ready and will not leak any sensitive data even if prompted.
03:40:52.020 | This security concern has been one of the primary concerns of enterprises when building Gen AI applications.
03:40:59.020 | Data driven applications have been around for a while.
03:41:04.020 | Then why are we talking about secure data retrieval all over again for Gen AI applications?
03:41:10.020 | Well, this is because we are seeing a paradigm shift in application development.
03:41:15.020 | With data driven applications, data is mostly constant and it is the application or the software that evolves for any different or new functionality.
03:41:25.020 | For example, product search on current e-commerce websites would pick constant data fields.
03:41:32.020 | Only the records or the results would change.
03:41:36.020 | While in context-driven or RAG application, the data is no longer a constant data packet and it needs to adapt to the dynamic needs of the user's natural language query.
03:41:50.020 | With natural language query, there is no structural limitations and it gives a scope for malicious attack.
03:41:59.020 | Good news, Hasura enables you to build secure data API over your multiple different data sources in no time.
03:42:06.020 | Hasura APIs are GraphQL APIs and hence they are dynamic in nature.
03:42:12.020 | So you get unified, dynamic, secure data API in no time.
03:42:17.020 | Just what we needed.
03:42:18.020 | So let's get started with building a RAG pipeline for our product search use case.
03:42:24.020 | Let us again look at what are the different queries that we that we can expect for our RAG applications.
03:42:31.020 | We can have semantic search where we are searching based on semantic similarity with product description from product vector DB.
03:42:40.020 | We can also have structured search where we are searching based on structured fields in the relation database.
03:42:47.020 | Like for example, price and category in Postgres.
03:42:52.020 | And this requires converting the natural language query into a structured query like SQL or GraphQL.
03:42:59.020 | Then we can also have hybrid queries.
03:43:02.020 | These searches have the elements of both semantic and structured queries.
03:43:06.020 | With Hasura, we don't need to build separate data APIs for each of them.
03:43:10.020 | We can build a unified data API for all three of them.
03:43:14.020 | So let's get started.
03:43:16.020 | We start by connecting our multiple different data sources with Hasura.
03:43:20.020 | And then we query it using a single GraphQL API.
03:43:24.020 | I've also built a streamlet application, which takes in the user input, calls the large language model, generates a GraphQL API query, which then gets executed on Hasura.
03:43:36.020 | So let's head over to Hasura console to get a feel of what it looks like.
03:43:41.020 | To start, we'll go to the data tab to connect all of our different data sources.
03:43:47.020 | I'm not going to do that because I have my product Postgres table and product vector table already integrated.
03:43:55.020 | As I mentioned before, you can use Hasura to query both your relational and vector DB and multiple data sources using a single GraphQL API.
03:44:05.020 | But for the sake of simplicity of this demo, I'm going to be using only the vector DB.
03:44:11.020 | So I'm using VV8 in this case where I have my vectors and I have also got my price and category structured fields here.
03:44:21.020 | One thing to note here is that I have used Hasura's event to auto vectorize my records into my vector DB, which means as and when a new record got inserted into my Postgres table, it got auto vectorized and saved in my vector DB.
03:44:37.020 | So let's go back to let's go to our API tab.
03:44:43.020 | This is where you will you can play around execute different queries and see the results.
03:44:49.020 | Nice.
03:44:51.020 | Now that we have gotten a fairly decent sense of what Hasura console is like, we can move to the streaming app that I have created.
03:45:01.020 | As you can see, there are a few configurations on the left hand side panel.
03:45:06.020 | So you have Hasura's endpoint and admin secret.
03:45:09.020 | This is required to connect with Hasura securely.
03:45:12.020 | And then I also have OpenAI's API key.
03:45:16.020 | This is required for the chat completion API that I'm using.
03:45:21.020 | So let's begin.
03:45:22.020 | Let's begin with querying the three different contexts that we were talking about that we want to fetch.
03:45:30.020 | So let's start with purely semantic one.
03:45:33.020 | Let's look at the different product descriptions that we have and pick something.
03:45:37.020 | Let us pick products on essential oils.
03:45:42.020 | So let me say, show me essential oils for relaxation.
03:45:58.020 | Great.
03:45:59.020 | So we've gotten the graph field query, which has identified essential oils for relaxation as the descriptive part of the query,
03:46:05.020 | which we want to find in our vector DB by doing a semantic search.
03:46:10.020 | And we can also see that we have gotten the results for this query.
03:46:17.020 | Nice.
03:46:18.020 | Let's go over and execute a structured query.
03:46:21.020 | Price is a good field to execute a structured query.
03:46:25.020 | So let's say, um, let's say, show me all products for less than 500 dollars.
03:46:43.020 | Wait.
03:46:44.020 | So it has rightly identified that there is a price filter with the less than condition.
03:46:48.020 | And it shows you all the different products with price less than 500.
03:46:51.020 | Nice.
03:46:52.020 | Let's execute a hybrid query.
03:46:53.020 | Now.
03:46:54.020 | Let's say looking for essential oil diffusers in the price range of 500 to 1000 dollars.
03:47:01.020 | Nice.
03:47:02.020 | So we got a graph field query where it identified amazing essential oil diffuser as the semantic search query and then the price filter, which is between 500 to 1000.
03:47:14.020 | And we received our results.
03:47:15.020 | Nice.
03:47:15.020 | So far we have executed only the happy flows.
03:47:15.020 | Um, we have not looked at any other query where of unhappy flows.
03:47:15.020 | But let's say I had an evil intent.
03:47:16.020 | Let's say I had an evil intent.
03:47:17.020 | So we have not looked at any other query where of unhappy flows.
03:47:18.020 | But let's say, I had an evil intent.
03:47:19.020 | So we got a graph field query where it identified amazing essential oil diffuser as the semantic search
03:47:22.020 | query and then the price filter, which is between 500 to 1000 and we received our results.
03:47:31.020 | Nice.
03:47:32.020 | So far we have executed only the happy flows.
03:47:37.020 | Um, we have not looked at any other query where of unhappy flows, but let's say I had an evil intent.
03:47:44.020 | And I wanted to execute a malicious query, which is not the typical queries that we just looked at.
03:47:51.020 | So I have a malicious query.
03:47:53.020 | Let's execute this.
03:47:55.020 | So this one is requesting to insert a product of hair, hair oil product, um, with the name special oil and price of $10,000.
03:48:10.020 | Category is form, fantastic share oil is the description.
03:48:14.020 | And let's also add the project ID and say this is 7,001.
03:48:19.020 | Okay, let's execute this.
03:48:22.020 | So as you can see, it has generated a graph field query of type insert mutation.
03:48:33.020 | So what we see is that it has also inserted the query.
03:48:37.020 | So let's go back to our table and console and look for product ID.
03:48:44.020 | So let's go back.

03:48:53.020 | Again, and this time we are going to be defining a new role with very restricted permissions.
03:48:54.020 | So that we.
03:48:55.020 | Only provide select permission and such that this does not happen again.
03:48:57.020 | So I'm going to create a new role.
03:48:58.020 | It's called, let's go back to our Hasura.
03:48:59.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:00.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:01.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:02.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.

03:49:05.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:06.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:07.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:08.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:09.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:10.020 | So, let's go back to our Hasura console.
03:49:11.020 | And this time, we are going to be defining a new role with very restricted permissions.
03:49:16.020 | So, that we only provide select permission and such that this does not happen again.
03:49:22.020 | So, I'm going to create a new role.
03:49:23.020 | Let's call it product search bot.
03:49:26.020 | And I'm going to provide only search permission.
03:49:30.020 | Let's go without any checks.
03:49:32.020 | I'm going to keep it really simple.
