03:49:40.020 | That's about it.
03:49:41.020 | Nice.
03:49:42.020 | So, the role has gotten inserted.
03:49:45.020 | Now, let's query the same thing with the new role.
03:49:48.020 | So, let's say product search bot.
03:49:51.020 | But this time, let me just modify this query a little bit and say 7000.
03:49:57.020 | Okay.
03:49:58.020 | So, let's execute this and see what happens.
03:50:02.020 | Nice.
03:50:03.020 | So, we got the same insert mutation query to be generated.
03:50:09.020 | But this time, there was an error executing this.
03:50:13.020 | Rightly so, because we have defined a role which does not have the permission for insert queries.
03:50:20.020 | Great.
03:50:21.020 | So, this is all from me.
03:50:22.020 | Thank you, everyone.
03:50:23.020 | Thank you once again.
03:50:25.020 | So, let us really quickly recap.
03:50:27.020 | In this demo, we learned how we can use Hasura to build hybrid query context for your sophisticated rag applications like product search.
03:50:37.020 | If you like the demo or would like to use Hasura for your rag application, please reach out to me.
03:50:42.020 | These are my contact details.
03:50:43.020 | And thank you so much once again.
03:50:45.020 | Hey, how's it going?
03:50:50.020 | I'm Dan.
03:50:51.020 | I'm co-founder of PromptHub, a prompt management tool designed for teams to make it easy to test, collaborate, and deploy prompts.
03:50:59.020 | Today, I want to talk to you a little bit about prompt engineering, including over three easy to implement tactics to get better and more accurate responses from LLMs.
03:51:09.020 | But first, why prompt engineering?
03:51:12.020 | Can't I just say what I want to the model and I get something pretty good back?
03:51:16.020 | And while for the most case, that's true, additional techniques can go a long ways in terms of making sure that your responses are always better.
03:51:24.020 | The non-deterministic nature of these models makes it really hard to predict.
03:51:28.020 | And I've seen that having little changes in a prompt can have outsized effect on the outputs.
03:51:34.020 | And this is especially important for anyone who's integrating AI into their product because one bad user experience or one time the model decides to go off the rails can result in disaster for your brand or your product, resulting in a loss of trust.
03:51:49.020 | Additionally, users, now that we all have access to ChatGPT and can really easily access these models, we have very high expectations when we're using AI features inside of products.
03:52:01.020 | We expect outputs to be crisp, exactly what we wanted.
03:52:04.020 | We should expect to never see hallucinations.
03:52:07.020 | And in general, it should be fast and accurate.
03:52:09.020 | And so I want to go over three easy to implement tactics to get better and safer responses.
03:52:17.020 | And like I said, these can be used in your everyday when you're just using ChatGPT, or if you're integrating AI into your product, these will help go a long way to making sure that your outputs are better and that users are happier.
03:52:28.020 | The first are called multi persona prompting.
03:52:31.020 | The first are called multi persona prompting.
03:52:32.020 | This comes out of a research study from the University of Illinois.
03:52:36.020 | Essentially what this method does is it calls on various agents to work on a specific task when you prompt it.
03:52:43.020 | And those agents are designed for that specific task.
03:52:46.020 | So for example, if I was to prompt a model to help me write a book, multi persona prompting would lead the model to get a publicist, an author, maybe the intended target audience of my book.
03:53:01.020 | And they would work hand in hand in kind of a brainstorm mechanism with the AI leading this brainstorm.
03:53:07.020 | They'd go back and forth, throwing ideas off the wall, collaborating until they came to a final answer.
03:53:12.020 | And this prompting method is really cool because you get to see the whole collaboration process.
03:53:17.020 | And so it's very helpful in cases where you have complex task at hand or requires additional logic.
03:53:23.020 | I personally like using it for generative tasks.
03:53:29.020 | Next up is the according to method.
03:53:31.020 | What this does is it grounds prompts to a specific source.
03:53:35.020 | So instead of just asking, you know, what part of the digestive tube do you expect starts to be digested?
03:53:41.020 | You can say that and then just add to the end according to Wikipedia.
03:53:45.020 | So adding according to specified source will increase the chance that the model goes to that specific source to retrieve the information.
03:53:53.020 | And this can help reduce hallucinations by up to 20%.
03:53:56.020 | So this is really good if you have a fine-tuned model or a general model that you know that you're reaching to a very consistent data source for your answers.
03:54:06.020 | This is out of Johns Hopkins University.
03:54:09.020 | It was published very recently.
03:54:11.020 | And last up and arguably my favorite is called the Motion Prompt.
03:54:16.020 | This was done by Microsoft and a few other universities.
03:54:19.020 | And what it basically looked at was how LLMs would react to emotional stimuli at the end of process.
03:54:26.020 | So for example, if your boss tells you that this product is really important for your career or for a big client, you're probably going to take it much more seriously.
03:54:36.020 | And this prompting method tries to tie into that cognitive behavior of humans.
03:54:41.020 | And it's really simple.
03:54:42.020 | All you have to do is add one of these emotional stimuli to the end of your normal prompt, and I'm sure you'll actually get better outputs.
03:54:47.020 | I've seen it done time and time again from everything from cover letters to generating change logs.
03:54:54.020 | The outputs just seem to get better and more accurate.
03:54:57.020 | And the experiments show that this can lead to anywhere from an 8% increase to 115% increase, depending on the task at hand.
03:55:04.020 | And so those are three really quick, easy-hit methods that you can use in ChatGBT or in the AI features in your product.
03:55:16.020 | We have all these available as templates in PromptHub.
03:55:19.020 | You can just go there and copy them.
03:55:21.020 | It's PromptHub.us.
03:55:22.020 | You can use them there, run them through our playground, share them with your team, or you can have them via the links.
03:55:29.020 | And so thanks for taking the time to watch this.
03:55:32.020 | I hope that you've walked away with a couple of new methods that you can try out in your everyday.
03:55:36.020 | If you have any questions, feel free to reach out and be happy to chat about this stuff.
03:55:39.020 | Thanks.
03:55:40.020 | Hi, everyone.
03:55:41.020 | I'm presenting Storyteller, an app for generating short audio stories for preschool kids.
03:55:46.020 | Storyteller is implemented using TypeScript and Model Fusion, an AI orchestration library that I've been developing.
03:55:54.020 | It generates audio stories that are about two minutes long, and all it needs is a voice input.
03:56:00.020 | Here's an example of the kind of story it generates to give you an idea.
03:56:05.020 | One day, while they were playing, Benny noticed something strange.
03:56:09.020 | The forest wasn't as vibrant as before.
03:56:11.020 | The leaves were turning brown, and the animals seemed less cheerful.
03:56:15.020 | Worried, Benny asked his friends what was wrong.
03:56:18.020 | Friends, why do the trees look so sad, and why are you all so quiet today?
03:56:22.020 | Benny, the forest is in trouble.
03:56:24.020 | The trees are dying, and we don't know what to do.
03:56:26.020 | How does this work?
03:56:27.020 | Let's dive into the details of the Storyteller application.
03:56:31.020 | Storyteller is a client server application.
03:56:34.020 | The client is written using React, and the server is a custom Fastify implementation.
03:56:39.020 | The main challenges were responsiveness, meaning getting results to the user as quickly as possible, quality, and consistency.
03:56:49.020 | So, when you start Storyteller, it's just a small screen that has a record topic button.
03:56:55.020 | And once you start pressing it, it starts recording.
03:56:58.020 | The audio, when you release, gets sent to the server as a buffer, and there we transcribe it.
03:57:05.020 | For transcription, I'm using OpenAI Whisper.
03:57:08.020 | It is really quick for a short topic, 1.5 seconds, and once it becomes available, an event goes back to the client.
03:57:18.020 | So, the client server communication works through an event stream, server sent events, that are being sent back.
03:57:27.020 | The event arrives on the client, and the React state updates, updating the screen.
03:57:34.020 | Okay, so then the user knows something is going on.
03:57:37.020 | In parallel, I start generating the Story Outline.
03:57:41.020 | For this, I use GPT-3 Turbo Instruct, which I found to be very fast.
03:57:45.020 | So, it can generate a Story Outline in about 4 seconds.
03:57:49.020 | And once we have that, we can start a bunch of other tasks in parallel.
03:57:54.020 | Generating the title, generating the image, and generating and narrating the audio story all happen in parallel.
03:58:03.020 | I'll go through those one by one now.
03:58:07.020 | First, the title is generated.
03:58:10.020 | For this, OpenAI GPT-3 Turbo Instruct is used again, giving a really quick result.
03:58:16.020 | Once the title is available, it's being sent to the client again as an event, and rendered there.
03:58:23.020 | In parallel, the image generation runs.
03:58:26.020 | First, there needs to be a prompt to actually generate the image.
03:58:31.020 | And here, consistency is important.
03:58:33.020 | So, we pass in the whole story into a GPT-4 prompt that then extracts relevant representative keywords
03:58:40.020 | for an image prompt from the story.
03:58:43.020 | That image prompt is passed into Stability AI Stable Diffusion Excel, where an image is generated.
03:58:52.020 | The generated image is stored as a virtual file in the server.
03:58:58.020 | And then, an event is sent to the client with a path to that file.
03:59:03.020 | The client can then, through a regular URL request, just retrieve the image as part of an image tag.
03:59:10.020 | And it shows up in the UI.
03:59:15.020 | Generating the full audio story is the most time-consuming piece of the puzzle.
03:59:20.020 | So, how can we do that?
03:59:21.020 | Here, we have a complex prompt that takes in the story and creates a structure with dialogue and speakers and extends the story.
03:59:32.020 | We use GPT-4 here with a low temperature to retain the story.
03:59:36.020 | And the problem is it takes one and a half minutes, which is unacceptably long for an interactive client.
03:59:42.020 | So, how can this be solved?
03:59:45.020 | The key idea is streaming the structure.
03:59:49.020 | But that's a little bit more difficult than just streaming characters token by token.
03:59:54.020 | We need to always partially parse the structure and then determine if there is a new passage that we can actually narrate and synthesize speech for.
04:00:07.020 | ModelFusion takes care of the partial parsing and returns an iterable over fragments of partially parsed results.
04:00:14.020 | But the application needs to decide what to do with them.
04:00:17.020 | Here, we determine which story part is finished so we can actually narrate it.
04:00:24.020 | So, we narrate each story part as it's getting finished.
04:00:28.020 | For each story part, we need to determine which voice we use to narrate it.
04:00:35.020 | The narrator has a predefined voice and for all the speakers where we already have voices, we can immediately proceed.
04:00:42.020 | However, when there's a new speaker, we need to figure out which voice to give it.
04:00:47.020 | The first step for this is to generate a voice description for the speaker.
04:00:53.020 | Here's a GPT-3-5 TurboPrompt that gives us a structured result with gender and a voice description.
04:01:00.020 | And we then use that for retrieval where we, beforehand, embedded all the voices based on their descriptions and now can just retrieve them filtered by gender.
04:01:12.020 | Then a voice is selected, making sure there are no speakers with the same voice.
04:01:17.020 | And finally, we can generate the audio.
04:01:20.020 | Here, for the speech synthesis, element and 11labs are supported.
04:01:26.020 | Based on the voices that have been chosen, one of those providers is picked and the audio is synthesized.
04:01:32.020 | Similar to the images, we generate an audio file and we store it virtually in the server and then send the path to the client which reconstructs the URL and just retrieves it as a media element.
04:01:46.020 | Once the first audio is completed, the client can then start playing.
04:01:52.020 | And while this is ongoing, in the background, you're listening and in the background, the server continues to generate more and more parts.
04:02:02.020 | And that's it. So let's recap how the main challenge of responsiveness is addressed here.
04:02:08.020 | We have a loading state that has multiple parts that are updated as more results become available.
04:02:14.020 | We use streaming and parallel processing in the backend to make results available as quickly as possible and you can start listening while the processing is still going on.
04:02:24.020 | And finally, models are being chosen such that the processing time for the generation, say, the story is minimized.
04:02:33.020 | Cool. I hope you enjoyed my talk.
04:02:36.020 | Thank you for listening.
04:02:37.020 | And if you want to find out more, you can find Storyteller and also Model Fusion on GitHub at GitHub.com L Grammar Storyteller and GitHub.com L Grammar Model Fusion.
04:02:46.020 | Hi, everyone. I'm Jeff Shoumei and I want to share with you an interesting generative AI project that I recently did.
04:02:59.020 | Not too long ago, I made a game with 100% AI-generated content.
04:03:06.020 | It's a simple game where you're wandering around lost in the forest and you go from scene to scene having encounters that impact your vigor and your courage.
04:03:18.020 | And the idea is that you want to find your home before you run out of courage.
04:03:24.020 | There's 16 scenes in a 4x4 grid.
04:03:28.020 | And so if you play a few times, you will have seen them all.
04:03:31.020 | Now, my favorite part of making this game was generating each scene and just seeing what AI would come up with.
04:03:40.020 | And I thought, wouldn't it be cool to share that experience with the player?
04:03:46.020 | What if every time they went to a new scene, it was generated fresh for them and every game would be unique and different this way?
04:03:56.020 | It would be a game of infinite exploration.
04:04:00.020 | That sounded so cool that I wanted to try to do it.
04:04:04.020 | Now, the first thing that I would need to do is to generate each scene and have a consistent way of doing that.
04:04:11.020 | My scene definitions are JSON objects that describe what the scene is when you first find it as well as when you come back to it later and how that impacts your stats.
04:04:24.020 | So I started out by using OpenAI's completion endpoint and doing some prompt engineering.
04:04:33.020 | This is the prompt that I used.
04:04:38.020 | This is a very detailed prompt.
04:04:40.020 | It's rather long, but it worked really well.
04:04:44.020 | Most of the time I would get scenes that had the right JSON format and the content was good.
04:04:52.020 | It was fitting.
04:04:53.020 | It was varied.
04:04:54.020 | It was interesting.
04:04:56.020 | So I was happy with this, but I wanted to make it even more reliable.
04:05:02.020 | And I decided to fine tune a model.
04:05:06.020 | I used OpenAI's fine tuning endpoint and they recommend 50 to 100 examples.
04:05:16.020 | I generated 50 examples just like these and use them to fine tune.
04:05:24.020 | Now, the key is I shortened the prompt.
04:05:28.020 | I simplified it.
04:05:31.020 | I took out any of the JSON and just generally described what I wanted, hoping that that information would be embedded in the training data.
04:05:44.020 | And I tried this out.
04:05:45.020 | I wasn't sure if it would work.
04:05:47.020 | And I tried it.
04:05:48.020 | It only cost about a dollar or two.
04:05:52.020 | That includes generating all the examples and doing the fine tuning.
04:05:57.020 | And when I tried it, I was very happy to find that it worked perfectly.
04:06:02.020 | Even though I didn't mention the JSON at all, it came out perfect because of what was in the examples.
04:06:11.020 | And that meant I had less tokens in the prompt, which is faster and cheaper and just easier to work with.
04:06:21.020 | So I was really pleased with how this worked.
04:06:24.020 | The next step was to make the images.
04:06:29.020 | Now, I used a tool called Leonardo.
04:06:32.020 | Leonardo not only lets you generate images, they also let you create your own image models.
04:06:39.020 | And this is great for a game because it means that you can have stylistically consistent images, which is exactly what I needed.
04:06:49.020 | So I spent a while using all the different parameters that Leonardo offers and working with the prompt to try and find an image that looks right and that I liked.
04:07:01.020 | So it turned out that using the description directly from the scene as the prompt made nice pictures, which I was surprised about since it had like second person and said things other than what was in there.
04:07:14.020 | But it worked out great.
04:07:16.020 | Now, the tricky part with fine tuning an image model is that you need consistent images that have like the parts that should be the same are the same in all of your training data.
04:07:31.020 | But the parts that you want to vary need to be varied.
04:07:34.020 | Otherwise, it will over fit and all of your images will look the same.
04:07:37.020 | But if you don't have that consistency between them, then it won't really know what you want and you won't get that good stylistic consistency.
04:07:47.020 | This was really tricky, especially in my case, I needed the perspective and the scale to be consistent from scene to scene.
04:07:56.020 | Obviously, I needed them all to be set in the forest and I wanted to have this overall tone and texture that looked the same.
04:08:04.020 | Some of my scenes have people in them, some have animals, some have buildings, some have nothing.
04:08:11.020 | And so it was hard to get that variety.
04:08:14.020 | I ended up having to train a couple of models with different parameters, different sets of images, but I eventually found one that worked out.
04:08:24.020 | And to test it out, I generated a lot of images.
04:08:29.020 | I mean, a whole bunch.
04:08:32.020 | You can see they all have similar features like the zigzag path down the middle.
04:08:39.020 | Obviously, the trees and the look and everything looks the same.
04:08:43.020 | And yet, there's plenty of variety.
04:08:47.020 | Each one is unique and different, but still feels cohesive, which I am very pleased about.
04:08:54.020 | So now I had everything I needed to put it together and make the game.
04:08:59.020 | I made a simple asset server that had an AI pipeline starting by requesting a new scene from OpenAI's endpoint using my custom model.
04:09:12.020 | Once I get that, I validate the JSON to make sure that it's got all the keys it needs.
04:09:18.020 | If it's good, I take the description and I send that to Leonardo.
04:09:23.020 | Leonardo makes an image from my custom model, gives it back to me.
04:09:27.020 | I put it all together and send it off.
04:09:30.020 | Now, did this work?
04:09:32.020 | Well, let me show you.
04:09:34.020 | Here is an example scene that was created.
04:09:39.020 | And I'm very happy with it.
04:09:42.020 | I made a simple preview server so that I could scroll through a bunch of these scenes that I generated to make sure they worked.
04:09:52.020 | And it looked good.
04:09:55.020 | So I made some changes to the game to request images each time the player went to a new scene.
04:10:05.020 | Now, there was a problem here.
04:10:08.020 | It takes 10, 20, sometimes 30 seconds to do this.
04:10:13.020 | And that wouldn't be good for the play experience.
04:10:17.020 | So what I did is I added some caching.
04:10:20.020 | I pre-fill a bunch of these scenes.
04:10:23.020 | And then as scenes are taken out of it, I fill it back up again once it gets below a certain threshold.
04:10:31.020 | And that way, there's always a scene that's ready to go.
04:10:36.020 | With that, the game was ready.
04:10:39.020 | And I'm going to share it with you right now.
04:10:41.020 | Now, keep in mind, everything that we see has never been seen before and will never be seen again.
04:10:48.020 | So this is the game.
04:10:53.020 | You always start out at this lamppost and you have to wander around and find your way home.
04:10:59.020 | Your stats are in the bottom left corner.
04:11:01.020 | As your vigor goes down, your speed goes down as well.
04:11:04.020 | And as the courage goes down, the viewport will get smaller and smaller.
04:11:09.020 | Let's look around and explore.
04:11:12.020 | We're going to move down.
04:11:13.020 | And here's the first generated scene.
04:11:18.020 | This looks really cool.
04:11:19.020 | This is like you encounter a soft blue pulsating light coming from the organic formation scattered around the glade.
04:11:27.020 | Your fear and tiredness lift and you feel rejuvenated and the vigor goes up, but I'm already at full.
04:11:33.020 | So that's really cool.
04:11:35.020 | Let's head off in this direction now.
04:11:37.020 | I won't read all of these, but this looks like a cool campfire scene, which is really neat.
04:11:43.020 | And I'm going to head down.
04:11:45.020 | And what have we got here?
04:11:50.020 | There's a large dark cave over here at the end of the path somewhere.
04:11:54.020 | And it's daunting, so my courage is going down.
04:11:57.020 | Let's head this way instead.
04:12:02.020 | Now we've gotten into some fog, foggy trees, and hard to see.
04:12:09.020 | Let's go back.
04:12:10.020 | This is like a really windy road that we're going through.
04:12:15.020 | Let's head down.
04:12:18.020 | Oh, I'm back where I started.
04:12:21.020 | Well, this is the game and it would continue on and on and on until you find your way home.
04:12:27.020 | And then you can just play again and it would be different every time.
04:12:30.020 | That's great.
04:12:32.020 | I just have a few closing thoughts.
04:12:34.020 | One thing is that these images are low resolution.
04:12:39.020 | They're 512 pixels and I could make them a higher resolution by adding an AI upscaler to my pipeline.
04:12:50.020 | It would add more time.
04:12:51.020 | So it's a trade off.
04:12:54.020 | Also, I could get more creative with adding something to the prompt to make a scene.
04:13:00.020 | For example, I could let the user select a theme or maybe even get the time of day or the current weather at the location of where the user is set.
04:13:13.020 | And then the scenes could be generated to match where they are for a very immersive experience.
04:13:18.020 | And of course, I can use this same process on other projects.
04:13:26.020 | That's all.
04:13:28.020 | I hope that you found this interesting and enjoyed watching it as much as I enjoyed putting it all together.
04:13:34.020 | Thank you so much.
04:13:36.020 | Thank you so much.
04:13:37.020 | Thank you.
04:13:38.020 | Thank you.
04:13:39.020 | Thank you.
04:13:39.020 | Thank you.
04:13:40.020 | Thank you.
04:13:40.020 | Thank you.
04:13:41.020 | Thank you.
04:13:42.020 | Thank you.
04:13:42.020 | Thank you.
04:13:43.020 | So I could find strength to divide us.
04:13:45.020 | Thank you.

04:18:15.880 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:16.380 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:16.880 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:17.880 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:18.880 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:19.380 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:20.380 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:21.380 | Sometimes we hold on to let go.
04:18:47.440 | Welcome back everyone.
04:18:48.440 | Please join me in welcoming our next speaker,
04:18:50.440 | of the TypeScript programming language,
04:18:52.740 | Daniel Rosenwasser.
04:18:55.480 | Good afternoon, my AI engineering friends.
04:19:07.320 | How are we all feeling today?
04:19:08.760 | Great.
04:19:10.060 | There we go.
04:19:10.600 | We got some energy even post-launch.
04:19:12.560 | All right, you heard.
04:19:14.060 | I'm Daniel Rosenwasser.
04:19:15.040 | I'm the program manager on TypeScript,
04:19:17.200 | as well as a new little experimental library
04:19:19.600 | I'm here to talk about today, called TypeChat.
04:19:22.400 | Now, this is an AI engineering conference.
04:19:25.440 | Everybody here has used something like ChatGPT, right?
04:19:28.480 | We use it for this continuous flow of information.
04:19:31.280 | We've been able to prototype things with it,
04:19:32.920 | just get useful answers, just by having
04:19:35.480 | this adorable little chat interface, right?
04:19:39.420 | But that's this one end of the spectrum.
04:19:41.060 | And on the other end of the spectrum,
04:19:42.360 | we have our traditional apps.
04:19:44.400 | These apps that are looking for this more precise sort of data
04:19:48.060 | to work with.
04:19:49.240 | So the question is, how do we make all of the new AI tools,
04:19:53.400 | all these language models that are so powerful,
04:19:55.340 | accessible to every engineer out there?
04:19:59.340 | And so just to start things off, what if we had this cute,
04:20:02.920 | you know, this little app right here.
04:20:04.140 | You have some basic user input at the very top,
04:20:07.160 | followed by these items, and each of these items
04:20:09.760 | has a venue name and a description.
04:20:11.840 | So this just helps me figure out what I need to do
04:20:14.100 | on a rainy day in Seattle, because this is every day
04:20:16.240 | in Seattle for me.
04:20:18.200 | A lot of weather apps at this conference.
04:20:20.200 | But the problem that you may find with trying to bridge together
04:20:25.880 | these language models and these traditional apps
04:20:29.620 | is that you find that you need to sort of massage the data,
04:20:32.460 | you need to sort of like really, really, really pamper the models
04:20:36.000 | to give you what you're looking for.
04:20:37.900 | And even after all that's said and done,
04:20:40.160 | by default, these apps will give you natural language,
04:20:45.040 | which is great for people, but it's not great for code.
04:20:49.180 | So if we just prototype this in, you know,
04:20:52.000 | something like a chat view,
04:20:53.340 | maybe you'd actually use the playground to do this,
04:20:55.320 | you'd find yourself saying certain things to pamper,
04:20:57.740 | like keep it short and do this and put everything
04:21:00.400 | on its different line and do whatever.
04:21:04.140 | You might find that you're starting to glom on to the patterns
04:21:07.880 | of what the language model gives you,
04:21:09.080 | because you've seen it in a certain way, right?
04:21:11.260 | And you've noticed, oh, well, it gives me this format.
04:21:13.380 | Each of these things is on its own line.
04:21:15.560 | Each of the lines has a leading number.
04:21:17.320 | They're always separating the venue name
04:21:19.000 | and the description by a colon.
04:21:21.200 | So I'll just do some basic parsing, split by new line,
04:21:24.460 | remove the leading numbers,
04:21:26.660 | and then split on the colon.
04:21:29.900 | That is a disaster waiting to happen,
04:21:32.540 | because you can't rely on the language model to always do this,
04:21:36.200 | and you can't know whether or not you're going to have something
04:21:40.100 | in the middle of that input
04:21:41.680 | that is going to just sort of wreck your parsing strategy, right?
04:21:44.920 | Parsing natural language is extremely hard,
04:21:47.820 | if not a fool's errand for most people.
04:21:51.460 | The thing that many people at this conference and elsewhere have discovered is you can say,
04:21:57.340 | "Pretty, pretty please give me some JSON," and it works pretty well, right?
04:22:03.220 | You know, just, "Here's an example of what I'm expecting, please respond with the answer."
04:22:09.100 | And, voila, it comes right back.
04:22:11.100 | But there's two issues with this.
04:22:12.760 | One is, just doing that on its own is not enough to guarantee that your app is actually going to get the data it's looking for,
04:22:19.100 | because maybe there's an extra property that doesn't seem to align.
04:22:24.680 | Maybe there's not enough data in the actual response,
04:22:26.980 | so you need to do some level of validation.
04:22:28.980 | But not just that, you can't comprehensively describe all of the things that you want, practically.
04:22:37.160 | In this case, I have a really, really simple schema, or a really, really simple example.
04:22:42.380 | All of the objects are uniform, they all have the same properties, end of story, right?
04:22:48.380 | But what if something is optional, what if something is required but needs to be null in some cases?
04:22:53.600 | What if this could be a string or a number, but never something else?
04:22:57.600 | I don't know.
04:22:59.200 | So you will not be able to get that far for more complex examples,
04:23:04.260 | because you end up with this combinatorial explosion.
04:23:06.980 | So what we found is that you can use types.
04:23:10.880 | Types are this great description to actually guide the model.
04:23:15.640 | Here, I'm just using type definitions and TypeScript, these are just plain interfaces.
04:23:20.000 | All I want is a thing with a list, and the list has these objects,
04:23:22.260 | and the objects have these two properties that are both strings on them.
04:23:26.160 | And the beauty of these type definitions is that the types can guide the model, right?
04:23:31.360 | So you can actually use these types to tell a model, hey, here is some user input, here is a user intent.
04:23:39.380 | Now use this with the types that I'm actually going to use in my application, throw it through your cool AI service, whatever that is,
04:23:48.500 | that may be OpenAI, Cohere, Anthropic, maybe it's a local model, maybe it's Lama code, I don't know.
04:23:54.500 | But the point is, what we found is that if you use a language model that is sufficiently trained on both human prose, natural language, and code, this actually bridges the two worlds together.
04:24:07.620 | But like I said, the guidance is only half of the problem, right?
04:24:12.740 | You need to be able to actually validate what you're getting.
04:24:16.740 | But the insight is that the types can also validate the results.
04:24:19.860 | And so what we found is, in our experience, you know, we're using TypeScript, TypeScript's great
04:24:25.860 | for JSON because it's a superset of JavaScript, which is a superset of JSON, which means that you can
04:24:30.660 | actually construct a miniature little program that underneath the hood, the TypeScript compiler is using to do that validation.
04:24:37.860 | And if that all goes well, then great, you have well-typed data from your language model.
04:24:45.300 | And if it doesn't go well, well, underneath the covers, what we actually end up with is an error message, right?
04:24:51.300 | Because it's actually using the TypeScript compiler under the hood.
04:24:53.700 | That error message can be used to perform a repair when you are reaching out to a language model to say,
04:25:00.580 | "No, no, no, no, no, that's not what I wanted. Try again."
04:25:04.820 | And so the key insight is types are all you need. Types can actually guide and validate,
04:25:11.700 | and it becomes a very powerful model because -- whoops. Well, yes, actually.
04:25:18.260 | That's the key insight that we have with TypeChat. It's a library on NPM right now. It's a TypeScript library
04:25:26.020 | at the moment. And basically, we've bundled this all together and make it easy to just guide a language
04:25:31.620 | model. Perform these queries and make sure you're actually getting well-typed data from the language
04:25:39.620 | models. And so you can actually use much more complex examples as well. You might say, like,
04:25:44.100 | I have a coffee shop, and the coffee shop has this schema, these types. You define them like this.
04:25:49.620 | And basically, you can use that to combine that with the user intent and input, and you get well-typed output.
04:25:57.860 | And I'll actually demo that right now. What I have here is my -- you know, the TypeChat repository cloned,
04:26:08.820 | NPM installed, everything's set up, and we have an examples directory. And I think if you're just
04:26:14.260 | curious to get started with TypeChat, the examples directory gets you started. We have a table -- if
04:26:20.740 | you look at the readme, we have a table of all of our examples. They kind of increase in complexity and
04:26:26.580 | difficulty. And the first one is like a sentiment thing where we say if something is positive, negative,
04:26:31.140 | or neutral. But that's so basic, it's like our hello world. I actually want to go back to that coffee
04:26:36.660 | shop example that I showed you just now. So we have this coffee shop schema. And this is just a bunch of
04:26:45.460 | types. Right? You probably have something similar in your preferred language as well. And what I can do
04:26:52.340 | here is I'm just going to run our entry points. And from the command prompt, I actually have a little
04:26:59.940 | prompt. And I can actually just make orders here. So I can say one latte with foam, please.
04:27:07.220 | Ta-da! Right? Yeah. So, you know, it's -- this is the key thing is that it's actually so simple. And it
04:27:21.700 | actually just works very well in a surprising way. Now, that's -- I could just tell you about that and I
04:27:30.020 | could walk off and that's not really good enough. I know. What happens if I say one latte and a medium
04:27:37.060 | purple gorilla named bonsai. So, what actually happened here is, technically, when we ran this
04:27:49.460 | prompt, this thing succeeded. But even though we got a successful result, we were able to do this
04:27:56.500 | sort of recovery here. We actually, in our app, are able to say, I didn't understand the following,
04:28:02.340 | a medium purple gorilla named bonsai. And that actually showed up in the JSON. And the
04:28:06.900 | reason that it did is because we have this thing called unknown text. So we've started to see these
04:28:12.260 | patterns in that, instead of doing this sort of prompt engineering, you're doing schema engineering.
04:28:17.540 | You're able to sort of thread through these results into your app. Because if you actually, you know,
04:28:23.620 | remove this stuff -- and let me show you what this actually looks like. If you look at the coffee shop
04:28:28.180 | example, this is under 40 lines of code, right? The magic here actually comes from we create a model, we infer
04:28:36.740 | it based on your environment settings. And then the actual magic is that we have this JSON translator.
04:28:42.580 | You give us the contents of your types, you select the type that you're expecting, and then every
04:28:47.300 | single time you need to translate a user intent, you just run this translate function. Now I'm getting
04:28:52.260 | type errors because I removed the type and it's telling me, like, this will never happen. Whoops!
04:28:56.100 | It's not that. So if I rerun this thing.
04:28:59.700 | And I say one cappuccino -- cappuccino, I can't spell anything today -- and a purple gorilla named Bonsai.
04:29:13.940 | I want to be precise here. So I got a bagel with butter because I asked for Bonsai. And the thing
04:29:25.540 | is that the -- what's going to happen is that the language model really doesn't want to disappoint you.
04:29:31.380 | It really wants to make sure you're getting what you want. So this is the thing, is you can actually
04:29:37.460 | define a schema that is rich enough to, you know, anticipate failure, gives you a chance to recover,
04:29:45.060 | show that to the user, say, I got this and this and this and that, it wasn't so clear on that.
04:29:49.540 | And that's kind of the beauty of this approach. It's very simple and it's really just about defining
04:29:55.620 | types, which you're going to use in your application anyway. Now, there's this other thing that we
04:30:02.500 | started encountering when we showed this off to teams internally. People said, well, that's all
04:30:08.980 | cool. You're turning coffee into code. I do too. How do I actually do something more rich like commands?
04:30:16.820 | What if I want to actually script my application in some way? Well, this approach that I just showed
04:30:23.940 | you actually works for very simple stuff as well, right? You can imagine something where you say,
04:30:29.700 | schedule an appointment for me and that turns into a specific command for a calendar app. In fact,
04:30:34.260 | in our examples, we actually have that. What if you want to string together multiple things?
04:30:40.180 | Hey, that's just a list of commands, right? Kind of. The problem with this is if I want these to kind
04:30:50.820 | of thread through to each other, this is a simple example. So it's just going input, you know, run the
04:30:56.180 | command, get the output, go to the input, etc, etc, etc, etc. What if you have something that expects
04:31:03.300 | multiple arguments? What if you want to reuse a result? Sure seems like you need variables and other
04:31:08.900 | things like that here. So we ask ourselves, is there a thing here where you can imagine you can just
04:31:16.180 | generate code and just take the same approach where types are all you need? So what if you could just
04:31:23.220 | define, here's all the methods that I want you to be able to call, come back with some code that only
04:31:28.100 | calls those methods, and then generates a program like this? The problem is that you really want to
04:31:37.460 | have some sort of sandboxing and safety constraints in place, right? And so you might start saying,
04:31:42.180 | I need availability. I can't just endlessly loop here. So I'm not going to allow loops. I'm not going to allow
04:31:48.500 | the lambdas and whatever. The problem is that even if you decide I'm going to pick a subset of a
04:31:53.460 | language like JavaScript or Python or whatever you have, the language models have seen so much of that
04:31:59.380 | code that they're going to draw outside the lines. And then you'll hit this failure case and then you
04:32:04.420 | just won't get a result. You won't get a bad result. You just won't get a result that conforms to what you're
04:32:08.580 | expecting. And then you still have to worry about sandboxing and then there's all these questions
04:32:13.300 | about synchronous versus asynchronous APIs and all this other stuff, too, that language models don't
04:32:18.500 | tend to understand because I guess most people don't either.
04:32:20.660 | So what we actually have been trying is we generate a fake language. We have the language models,
04:32:28.980 | generate a fake language still based on the types, but it's in the form of JSON, actually. And so you
04:32:35.700 | have things like refs, and refs are just references to prior results. And if you're familiar with,
04:32:41.700 | like, if you're a compiler, this may look like SSA, it may look like an AST, whatever. But we use that
04:32:50.020 | to construct a fake TypeScript program in memory as well and use that to make sure that not just are you
04:32:57.140 | calling only the methods that are available to you, that you can only do certain actions, but also that
04:33:03.380 | the inputs from prior steps matches up with the types that you're defining from your API. And so that kind
04:33:11.540 | of comes back to types are all you need. We have another really simple example for we have a math
04:33:19.060 | schema. This is basically a calculator in sheep's clothing. So if you go back and we run this here,
04:33:26.820 | we have another prompt. That's an abacus. That's the closest thing to a calculator I could get.
04:33:33.460 | If we could say something like add one to 41 and then divide by seven.
04:33:38.340 | Now,
04:33:41.380 | basically, what happened here is we made a language model good at math.
04:33:49.780 | So we've also solved a whole other set of problems, right?
04:33:53.620 | Yeah. More seriously, though.
04:33:57.780 | So at each of these steps, we're actually performing -- having the language model call a method,
04:34:02.340 | perform an operation. And if you actually look at the code here -- math main -- this is all under
04:34:11.220 | 50 lines of code. We are able to do the same sort of translation. We have a separate thing called a
04:34:15.940 | program translator. And in that program translator, when you are successfully able to validate your
04:34:22.740 | results, you say, if this thing is a success -- or not a success, just jump out. Otherwise, do some
04:34:28.900 | stuff with it. We have this evaluate function. And this evaluate function takes a callback. And that
04:34:33.300 | callback is just sort of like this instruction interpreter. And so you can do this with objects,
04:34:39.380 | you can do this with a function, with a switch case or whatever. But the point is that this actually
04:34:44.500 | allows you to do some richer tasks. Now, there are other approaches for many of these things,
04:34:52.420 | and they overlap with what Type Chat does. But the cool thing is that Type Chat is able to actually
04:34:56.740 | give you this level of validation for both JSON and programs. And it's something that we're also
04:35:02.500 | experimenting with with other languages, too. So, for example, people at this conference have been
04:35:08.980 | saying, yeah, TypeScript is very cool, and I agree with them because I work on TypeScript. But how
04:35:15.620 | would I make this work with Python? And so we have been experimenting with this, and we've been getting
04:35:20.020 | fairly good results. I'm able to do something like the coffee shop with a very similar approach using
04:35:26.260 | types. I'm able to do something similar with the calculator app, just defining methods on a class
04:35:34.260 | with comments and all this other stuff that helps the model do a little bit better. And it works really
04:35:39.540 | well. We can even do more complex examples, too, like we have this CSV example. Maybe I want to be able
04:35:47.860 | to -- well, I'm not going to get into -- oh, the demo gods are going to kill me here.
04:36:00.740 | That. Brutal. Okay. I can just create a program that does this now. I have this entire API that grabs
04:36:14.740 | columns and is able to perform certain operations and then do joins that do filtering and joining and
04:36:20.020 | all this other stuff as well because it just sort of does this selection based on Booleans. So read a CSV,
04:36:26.020 | find all the values that equal na, and then drop the rows. And so this becomes this sort of powerful
04:36:30.820 | approach. And this is just a prototype of the Python stuff that we've been working on as well.
04:36:34.740 | It's not prime time. And if you want to talk to me about it, I'm definitely game.
04:36:39.380 | So what I want from you all is to try type chat out. Reach out. What I'm here at this conference for is to
04:36:50.740 | learn about what you're all trying to build, trying to help bridge the gap as well between what we're
04:36:56.020 | all learning on the cutting edge and making that more accessible to everyday engineers who have been
04:37:00.660 | at this more precise end of the spectrum, bringing the power of these language models that are so rich
04:37:05.140 | to the traditional apps. Thank you very much. Come see me at the Microsoft booth. I'll be hanging out for a
04:37:10.180 | little bit. And thank you.
04:37:30.820 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry and an O'Reilly author.
04:37:38.260 | Please welcome to the stage, Abby Arion.
04:37:45.700 | Thank you.

04:38:28.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.

04:39:14.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
