04:39:17.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:18.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:19.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:20.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:21.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:22.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:23.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:39.980 | She's a machine learning engineer with over seven years of experience in the industry.
04:39:44.980 | The second is basically you don't want to collect new data for every single domain.
04:40:01.980 | One of the best things that has happened with large language models, I would say, is the ability
04:40:07.980 | of these models to be able to transition to a new domain.
04:40:11.980 | So here's one paper that I would reference.
04:40:15.980 | So one quick example, I would say, is before, let's say, transformer models, or even while
04:40:22.980 | we were having transformer models, to be able to train a model to learn a new language, we
04:40:28.980 | needed to collect the data for that particular language and then to be able to do whatever tasks
04:40:35.980 | that we want to do in that language.
04:40:38.980 | One of the best things that has happened is now, because the models are learning by embeddings,
04:40:45.980 | they're able to learn on a new language that they've previously not seen as well, because
04:40:50.980 | they're essentially learning the structure of the languages instead of, like, what is the
04:40:55.980 | taxonomy of the language, which means there are some languages which are semantically similar.
04:41:01.980 | So, for example, English is very semantically similar to Latin.
04:41:05.980 | I'm not entirely sure there are a couple of languages that do fall into, like, that one
04:41:10.980 | domain, which is, oh, these languages are similar.
04:41:13.980 | They have semantic similarities.
04:41:15.980 | There are other set of languages that have semantic similarities.
04:41:18.980 | So it's very easy to be able to transition between those languages without ever having seen
04:41:23.980 | any data or any examples in those languages.
04:41:26.980 | The third is basically you want the models to be able to be accessible to a wide range of
04:41:32.980 | users.
04:41:33.980 | And what I mean by that is more so like all the work that was happening along in personalisation.
04:41:40.980 | So, simple reasons, this is something almost everybody is aware of.
04:41:46.980 | What is fine-tuning?
04:41:47.980 | Fine-tuning is almost a way of us teaching the model to be able to learn something for which
04:41:59.980 | it hasn't already been trained before.
04:42:01.980 | So, improving the performance of a pre-trained model.
04:42:05.980 | One of the ways we're doing that is by updating the parameters.
04:42:10.980 | Right?
04:42:11.980 | You take some inputs.
04:42:12.980 | You have a hidden layer in which you're calculating the weights, you're calculating the biases,
04:42:17.980 | and then you have an output layer.
04:42:19.980 | That all stuff, I think, is obvious to almost everybody.
04:42:22.980 | You've seen what a transformer model for people who don't know what the structure of a transformer
04:42:27.980 | model is.
04:42:28.980 | There's an encoder.
04:42:29.980 | There's a decoder.
04:42:30.980 | The reason I'm referencing this is we'll go a little bit more into details.
04:42:34.980 | of these while we're talking about different fine-tuning methods itself.
04:42:39.980 | So, there's an encoder.
04:42:40.980 | There's a decoder.
04:42:41.980 | It has a feed-forward network.
04:42:44.980 | It has an attention network.
04:42:45.980 | Same for the decoder one.
04:42:48.980 | Now, this is how we were looking at transformer models the way they are.
04:42:55.980 | And this is storing the weights and the biases right now.
04:43:00.980 | But now let's talk about making these models better.
04:43:05.980 | So, there are a couple of ways that we can fine-tune our methods.
04:43:08.980 | We can update all the model weights or we can update some of the weights.
04:43:13.980 | If we update all the model weights, that falls into the category of some of the models that
04:43:18.980 | you've seen earlier, which is all the research work that was between 2018, 2016, all those
04:43:25.980 | years, which is more around transfer learning cross-distillation models in which you have
04:43:30.980 | a teacher model and a student model.
04:43:32.980 | The student model is learning from the teacher model.
04:43:35.980 | And that's the way you're sort of updating all the weights.
04:43:40.980 | But it is very expensive to do that.
04:43:42.980 | And it is computationally -- it takes more storage as well.
04:43:47.980 | The second option that we're now looking at, the reason we're having this discussion today,
04:43:53.980 | is how can we update our models?
04:43:57.980 | Because the parameters have gone so big, we cannot keep updating all the weights.
04:44:02.980 | So, how about we update just some of the weights without making sure -- while making sure that
04:44:09.980 | we're able to get equivalent performance.
04:44:12.980 | And I would put an estrus on, you know, like, equivalent performance because we may not be
04:44:20.980 | able to get the chat GPT performance, and that is something we'll talk about eventually.
04:44:24.980 | So, in terms of if we update some of the weights, you can break it down into three categories.
04:44:30.980 | To be honest, more like five categories, but there are three main ones, which is adaptive
04:44:34.980 | tuning.
04:44:35.980 | There's prefix tuning and there's parameter efficient tuning.
04:44:38.980 | There's instruction tuning, which is basically giving a couple of examples.
04:44:43.980 | This is something you've seen a lot at a couple of -- so many examples throughout this
04:44:48.980 | conference, and the one that was prior to my talk as well, where we were doing instruction
04:44:52.980 | tuning, are relative -- obviously not super relevant to most of us, which is we would -- it's
04:44:59.980 | too expensive to have real human beings to be able to fine tune your parameters for you.
04:45:06.980 | Or to be able to provide your examples and say, this is wrong, this is right.
04:45:10.980 | So we are only left with three techniques, which is adapter tuning, prefix tuning, and parameter
04:45:17.980 | efficient fine tuning.
04:45:18.980 | We'll go a little bit more into detail of what these are, why are we using these ones, and
04:45:25.980 | when do they do well.
04:45:27.980 | So the first one, this is basically adapter-based tuning.
04:45:31.980 | The thing that really happens in adapter-based tuning is it's really good.
04:45:36.980 | What it does is it adds a small number of parameters to the existing model.
04:45:42.980 | Those parameters are basically stored in the adapter components that you're seeing over there.
04:45:48.980 | This is -- the entire model of the transformer remains the same, but we are adding two new components
04:45:54.980 | to it that contains the extra weights.
04:45:57.980 | So what this does is this exposes the model to the new information, and according to -- according
04:46:03.980 | to the original paper that came out, you know, it is able to improve the performance of the
04:46:09.980 | model, or you could say it matches the performance of the model with only 0.15% of the parameters.
04:46:16.980 | Where is it good?
04:46:18.980 | Where -- in which cases would we use something like this?
04:46:22.980 | So adapter fine-tuning, or adaptive fine-tuning, both are the same things.
04:46:28.980 | Ideally, you use it when you're trying to learn a new domain itself, which is if you're trying
04:46:35.980 | to fine-tune your model for, like, a very different domain, let's say biochemical engineering,
04:46:41.980 | that's more so where you would use adapter-based fine-tuning.
04:46:45.980 | The second is prefix-based fine-tuning.
04:46:47.980 | So prefix-based fine-tuning, what it does is it introduces some prefixes where we are storing
04:46:54.980 | the model weights, and what they are able to do is they are able to mimic the behavior of
04:47:00.980 | the prefix that we are giving it, which is the couple of weights that we are adding in front
04:47:04.980 | of the attention model.
04:47:06.980 | So in very simple words, what it does, it adds an embedding layer at the front of the
04:47:15.980 | attention layer to mimic that behavior.
04:47:19.980 | One very simple example to understand this a little bit better is, you know, all of the
04:47:25.980 | water that we get comes out of a tank, right?
04:47:27.980 | But the way we are able to access it is using a tap, and water takes the form of a tap, which
04:47:35.980 | is it comes out in this quantity.
04:47:38.980 | So that's very much like how prefix-tuning works, which is it's not changing the behavior of the
04:47:43.980 | model, but it's just mimicking or adding a masking layer on top of the existing weights
04:47:50.980 | or on top of the existing model that there is.
04:47:54.980 | The third and the final one, which is the parameter-efficient fine-tuning method.
04:48:01.980 | So this one, the one example that you're seeing is basically the LoRa one.
04:48:05.980 | There are two commonly known parameter-efficient fine-tuning methods that are out there, LoRa and
04:48:12.980 | Q LoRa.
04:48:13.980 | The way LoRa really works, it really is basically low-rank adaptation method, where you use
04:48:19.980 | it.
04:48:20.980 | Any sort of parameter-efficient fine-tuning method is sort of used where you want to compress
04:48:25.980 | the model sizes, or you want to run it on low-resource devices.
04:48:30.980 | So, very ideal for large language models.
04:48:33.980 | Biggest reason is because we have massive parameters that we are trying to run on very small devices,
04:48:39.980 | which could be our laptops, and even smaller devices, which is basically the HTML devices,
04:48:44.980 | the audrenos and all of that stuff.
04:48:47.980 | So that's one reason the entire community has been talking more so about LoRa and Q LoRa,
04:48:52.980 | because, again, we are looking for efficiency.
04:48:55.980 | The way it works under the hood is all of the weights are usually stored as what is basically
04:49:02.980 | a matrix, right?
04:49:04.980 | So, most of these weights, there are a lot of layers in these weights that aren't unique.
04:49:14.980 | And what LoRa usually does is it identifies the linearly independent layers in terms of the
04:49:24.980 | weight matrix itself.
04:49:26.980 | So, in the matrix, you're looking at all the linearly independent lines or the columns.
04:49:32.980 | And you're picking and choosing only those ones.
04:49:35.980 | So, what it does is if two things are very similar or two things are almost like you could transform one easily
04:49:42.980 | through a mathematical function as, like, a multiplier of the other one, then storing that one extra layer,
04:49:49.980 | which is a copy of the original one, doesn't really make sense, right?
04:49:52.980 | So, that's how LoRa works under the hood, which is we are reducing the size of the matrix,
04:49:58.980 | which is the size of the weight matrix, essentially.
04:50:02.980 | So, practical benefits.
04:50:03.980 | Obviously, you know, you're able to decrease the size of the model.
04:50:10.980 | And you're also -- you can also -- you can also -- you're also using less memory right now.
04:50:20.980 | The second method that we are looking at is basically called Q LoRa, which is quantized LoRa method.
04:50:28.980 | The way it works is it changes the model weights to 4-bit precision.
04:50:33.980 | The way it usually works is you start with the pre-trained models.
04:50:38.980 | You collect a data set with labelled data.
04:50:43.980 | And you train adaptation matrix and multiply it with the main weight matrix.
04:50:50.980 | And what you're essentially trying to do is you're trying to decrease the distance between the predicted outputs
04:50:57.980 | of the source domain and the target domain.
04:51:00.980 | That's what's essentially going on in Q LoRa.
04:51:04.980 | One quick comparison.
04:51:06.980 | Obviously, I mean, in terms of, like, the people who are saying, okay, Q LoRa is great.
04:51:12.980 | Should we use LoRa or Q LoRa?
04:51:14.980 | One quick thing I'll say on that one is while Q LoRa works really good on the original data set that I was trained on,
04:51:23.980 | but to be able to get to perform really well requires a library, bits and bytes libraries.
04:51:29.980 | And some other things which are not available on all the devices, not a lot of testing has really happened for Q LoRa's efficiency on all of the models.
04:51:39.980 | So I would probably say maybe still sticking with LoRa and being able to optimize the performance with the LoRa model is ideally like the better way to go at least at this current point in time.
04:51:50.980 | So to very quickly summarize, which is, again, we have three different methods to be able to do domain adaptation.
04:52:01.980 | We have prompting.
04:52:02.980 | We have rags.
04:52:03.980 | We have fine-tuning.
04:52:04.980 | For prompting, you can sort of prompt your models, again, with no examples, with one example, with a couple of examples.
04:52:12.980 | When it comes to a couple of examples, I think a good answer would be about 10, which is what chartGPT says, where, obviously, the performance is better, the more examples you're able to give it.
04:52:23.980 | Where it works is in the domains that you're looking for more generalizable models, but usually that's just demos, not real-world examples.
04:52:32.980 | Requires less training data, it's cheaper, obviously, but it is not as performant as fine-tuning.
04:52:38.980 | On fine-tuning, you're looking at three different methods, which is, like, adaptive fine-tuning, you're looking at behavioral fine-tuning, and parameter-efficient fine-tuning.
04:52:47.980 | On each of these ones, you don't need to pick one of these three techniques.
04:52:54.980 | You can also combine them with prompt engineering and combine them with rags as well, or you can do both of those things, which is you can do adaptive as well as behavioral fine-tuning.
04:53:04.980 | The key difference between all those three methods is adaptive fine-tuning really works well on when you have a target domain that you're trying to optimize for.
04:53:14.980 | So, for example, if you have multiple tasks within a single domain, let's say you have a legal company, and you're trying to build a model that works really well on five different or ten different tasks within just the legal domain itself, adaptive fine-tuning works great.
04:53:30.980 | Behavioral fine-tuning is basically where you're trying to optimize the model performance on a target task only.
04:53:37.980 | So, you're not really optimizing for the entire domain, you're optimizing for just one particular task.
04:53:43.980 | The way it really works is you're optimizing for the label space and the prior probability distribution.
04:53:50.980 | So, very helpful when you're trying to get to show some sort of, like, inference and reasoning capabilities.
04:54:00.980 | You could also -- a good analogy on behavioral fine-tuning is it's very similar to LAN chain functions, if you've used LAN chain functions.
04:54:10.980 | And parameter efficient fine-tuning is like the standard fine-tuning where we're freezing some of the parameters and we're only updating a very small amount of parameters using the techniques LoRa, Q LoRa, and so on.
04:54:25.980 | But coming to, you know, are these techniques going to really work?
04:54:30.980 | Sure, we have all of this available.
04:54:32.980 | It would only work depending on how good your data is, which is -- it depends on how you're collecting your data, how you're tokenizing your data, how you're cleaning and normalizing your data.
04:54:44.980 | Are you removing the noise and sort of sanitizing your models?
04:54:48.980 | Are you doing data duplication as well to be able to remove the duplicate entries?
04:54:53.980 | So, there was another research that was published, which was basically, like, the memorization which happens in models is mainly because of data deduplication.
04:55:04.980 | If we're removing the duplicate entries, that reduces the probability of a model to be able to memorize certain tasks.
04:55:12.980 | So, it's actually creating sort of bias towards those things, and it's naturally outputting those very quickly.
04:55:25.980 | And the last one being data augmentation.
04:55:28.980 | Now, let's say you've done all of this.
04:55:32.980 | Let's say you've picked the right model.
04:55:34.980 | Let's say you've done your data collection thing perfectly.
04:55:37.980 | You've got the best data out there.
04:55:38.980 | What are still the things that you can't think of while optimizing the performance of your model?
04:55:43.980 | So, the first thing is do not try to compare whether GPT-4 or GPT-5.
04:55:48.980 | It's not going to work comparatively, especially for more complex tasks.
04:55:53.980 | It's not a generalized model.
04:55:55.980 | While it may be able to capture the nuances of your actual data, but it may not be able to capture the nuances of your actual data.
04:56:03.980 | Or in newer domains that it hasn't seen before.
04:56:09.980 | So, that's one thing which I've seen a lot of companies are trying to sort of in a dilemma with.
04:56:16.980 | Which is, oh, we've fine-tuned our model, but it's not working as good as GPT-4.
04:56:21.980 | The second one is basically using in-context learning with dynamic examples.
04:56:28.980 | And one of the big reasons for that is the big problem that we see with the drift in the model, with the data drift in the models.
04:56:38.980 | So, using in-context learning with dynamic example loading allows you to be able to deal with that particular problem.
04:56:47.980 | While also making sure that you are able to do cost management as well.
04:56:53.980 | The third thing that also one needs to think of is breaking down this task into smaller tasks.
04:57:00.980 | So, for example, like if we are working with any sort of language, then instead of trying to train the model for like the entire language, can we break it down into like very specific tasks?
04:57:09.980 | So, that's another thing which people need to think of.
04:57:16.980 | The final thing I would say is implementing some sort of gradient checkpointing.
04:57:21.980 | So, what gradient checkpointing essentially does, it reduces the memory usage.
04:57:28.980 | What it essentially does is it retrains the model and recomputes the weights during the backward pass.
04:57:38.980 | While it may look like, you know, it's not the smartest choice to make, but, you know, while the computation is higher, which is, yes, the weights will need to be recomputed.
04:57:53.980 | But the downsides are easily weighed by the memory consumption.
04:57:58.980 | So, the memory consumption is very, very less if we are implementing some sort of gradient checkpointing.
04:58:03.980 | So, another cost-effect, cost-management thing.
04:58:08.980 | Now, a few more considerations and limitations, which is, let's talk about the hyperparameters.
04:58:15.980 | Now, choosing a batch size.
04:58:17.980 | Ideally, we go with a batch size of 32 or 64.
04:58:20.980 | Choosing the number of training epochs.
04:58:23.980 | Again, one of the questions I often get is what's the right number of epochs that we should be training with.
04:58:30.980 | If you're doing a simple test, which is if you're running something in a Google CoLab for fun thing, maybe having epoch 1 is nice.
04:58:41.980 | But if you are working with a good model, and if you're trying to optimize for, like, a particular domain, then choosing to go with 100 epochs as, like, the starting point is probably, like, the ideal choice.
04:58:55.980 | Choosing an optimizer, there are different optimizers that are out there.
04:58:58.980 | Atom optimizer is the standard choice because it's general purpose.
04:59:03.980 | And it works really well with different domains as well.
04:59:08.980 | Implementing some sort of regularization, early stopping.
04:59:11.980 | Again, one of the things is basically, like, in terms of -- if you're looking at the models that have been trained until now, there's not a lot of implementation on optimizing those performances.
04:59:25.980 | While there are bigger models that we're seeing every single day with more and more parameters, they're not essentially squeezing all the performance out of those models.
04:59:36.980 | So one of the easy ways to be able to do that is using some sort of early stopping, which is making sure that you're only working with the data that is most efficient.
04:59:46.980 | If the model performance is declining, then you need to reconsider your batch and look into that batch, consider your embeddings.
04:59:54.980 | Now, let's say, if you fine-tune the models, the next part, which is the hardest part of the process, is, you know, how do we evaluate our models?
05:00:05.980 | There are so many benchmarks out there.
05:00:09.980 | There are so many libraries out there.
05:00:11.980 | So there's every array.
05:00:13.980 | There's libraries by NVIDIA.
05:00:16.980 | But what you're essentially looking for mostly is the law security and perplexity, but that doesn't really paint the full picture.
05:00:27.980 | So while I say, you know, it is the hardest part, which is there needs to be some sort of adaptation for every single business and every single use case, which is -- we need to be looking at evaluation from four different perspectives or four different components.
05:00:41.980 | The first is doing some sort of metric-based evaluation, which is something like blue score, rogue score that we were considering before.
05:00:49.980 | Doing some sort of tool-based evaluation.
05:00:51.980 | So I think weights and biases does have a library for doing that particularly, which is their auto-evaluate -- the debugger one.
05:00:58.980 | And then there's another one, auto-evaluator.
05:01:00.980 | So that is able to catch the compilation errors very quickly.
05:01:05.980 | The third one is using some sort of model-based evaluation, which is using a smaller model to be able to evaluate the other model.
05:01:13.980 | So while this is something which is -- I have not seen a lot of performance with this one, because, again, it's hard to do.
05:01:23.980 | But it has a lot of potential, which is it does standardize the process eventually, and it automates the process.
05:01:29.980 | And the final one is basically human in the loop, which is something I feel like -- you know, this is something that everybody is doing, but not the most efficient.
05:01:39.980 | So let's just ignore human in the loop.
05:01:41.980 | Maybe let's let OpenAI talk about this.
05:01:48.980 | The final thing that I wanted to say on this one for this particular presentation is while fine-tuning is great, yes, you -- but you also need to think about the entire pipeline, which is how you're thinking about the data collection, how you're thinking about the storage management, how you're choosing a base model.
05:02:07.980 | So optimizing the performance of your model doesn't really depend on just one feature.
05:02:12.980 | While it may work perfectly for, like, a single one-off demo, but to be able to put a robust application that does sustain the test of time -- obviously, I'm not saying, you know, what would be an ideal time that you should be testing on.
05:02:29.980 | But in the case, the goal is to be able to get the optimal performance of the model and to be able to deal with all the data drift and the prompt drift and all of those things, while also making sure that we're catching a few things early and we're not exposing the enterprise to, like, reputational risk, compliance risk, and all of those things.
05:02:48.980 | The entire thing has to be thought of.
05:02:51.980 | So it is a big-picture decision that I would say that needs to be taken.
05:02:56.980 | So that's all my presentation for today.
05:02:59.980 | I hope everybody learned something new.
05:03:02.980 | If there is something you would like to go with me in detail, then we can do that after the presentation.
05:03:07.980 | But thank you so much.
05:03:21.980 | Ladies and gentlemen, our next speaker is the co-founder of Chroma.
05:03:25.980 | Please welcome Anton Choynikov.
05:03:28.980 | All right.
05:03:41.980 | Hopefully, this works.
05:03:43.980 | It does.
05:03:44.980 | Fantastic.
05:03:45.980 | Hi, everybody.
05:03:46.980 | As Dave said as I walked up, I'm Anton.
05:03:47.980 | I'm the co-founder of Chroma.
05:03:49.980 | I'm here to talk to you about retrieval augmented generation in the wild and what it is that Chroma is building for beyond just vector.
05:03:57.980 | search.
05:03:58.980 | By now, you've all seen versions of this probably a half dozen times throughout this conference.
05:04:04.980 | This is the basic retrieval loop that one would use in a RAG application.
05:04:09.980 | You have some corpus of documents.
05:04:12.980 | You embed them in your favorite vector store, which is Chroma.
05:04:15.980 | I mean, check the lanyards, man.
05:04:20.980 | You embed your corpus of documents.
05:04:22.980 | You have an embedding model for your queries.
05:04:25.980 | You find the nearest neighbor vectors for those embeddings.
05:04:28.980 | You return the associated documents, which, along with the query, you then put into the LLM's context window and return some result.
05:04:34.980 | Now, this is the basic RAG loop, but I think of this as more like the open loop retrieval augmented generation application.
05:04:42.980 | My purpose in showing you all this is to show you that you need a lot more than simple vector search to build some of the more powerful, more promising applications that take RAG in the future.
05:04:52.980 | Let's get into what some of those might be.
05:04:54.980 | The first piece to this, of course, is incorporating human feedback into this loop.
05:04:58.980 | Previously, without human feedback, it isn't possible to adapt the data, the embeddings model itself, to the specific task, to the model, and to the user.
05:05:08.980 | Human feedback is required to actually return better results for particular queries on your specific data on the specific tasks that you want to perform.
05:05:16.980 | Generally, embedding models are trained in a general context, and you actually want to update them for your specific tasks.
05:05:22.980 | Basically, the memory that you're using for your RAG application needs to be able to support this sort of human feedback.
05:05:28.980 | Now, the other piece that we've seen, and these are currently in the early stages, but they're emerging as something like a capable machine.
05:05:35.980 | And I think that one of the ways to make agents actually capable is a better RAG system, a better memory for AI.
05:05:41.980 | And that means that your retrieval system, your memory, needs to support self-updates from the agent itself out of the box.
05:05:49.980 | All in all, what this means is you have a constantly dynamically updating data set.
05:05:53.980 | Something that's built as a search index out of the box is not going to be able to support these types of capabilities.
05:05:59.980 | Next, of course, we're talking about agents with world models.
05:06:01.980 | So, in other words, the agent needs to be able to store its interaction with the world and update the data that it's working with based on that interaction.
05:06:09.980 | And finally, you need to be able to tie all of these together.
05:06:12.980 | Now, this sounds like a very complex system that's frontier research, and it is currently research grade, but we're seeing some of the first applications of this in the wild already today.
05:06:22.980 | This is an animation from, I'm sure some of you are familiar with this paper.
05:06:26.980 | This is the famous Voyager paper out of Nvidia, where they trained an agent to play Minecraft, to learn how to play it, by learning skills in a particular environment,
05:06:35.980 | and then recognizing when it's in the same context and recalling that skill.
05:06:39.980 | Now, the other interesting piece to this is several of the more complex skills were learned through human demonstration,
05:06:44.980 | and then retrained in the retrieval system, which, of course, was Cormo.
05:06:48.980 | My point in showing this to you is that the simple rag loop might be the bread and butter of most of the applications being developed today,
05:06:57.980 | but the most powerful things that you'll be able to build with AI in the future require a much more capable retrieval system than one that only supports a search index.
05:07:08.980 | Now, of course, in retrieval itself, there are plenty of challenges.
05:07:12.980 | Information retrieval is kind of a classic task, and the setting in which it's been found previously has been in recommender systems and in search systems.
05:07:21.980 | Now that we're all using this in production for AI applications in completely different ways, there's a lot of open questions that haven't really been asked quite in the same way or with quite the same intensity.
05:07:31.980 | A key piece of how retrieval needs to function for AI, and anyone who's built one of these is aware of this, is you need to be able to return not just all relevant information, but also no irrelevant information.
05:07:42.980 | It's common knowledge by now, and this is supported by empirical research, that distractors in the model context cause the performance of the entire AI-based application to fall off a cliff if those distractors are present.
05:07:53.980 | So what does it mean to actually retrieve relevant info and no irrelevant info?
05:07:57.980 | You need to know which embedding model you need to be using at all in the first place, and we've all seen the claims from the different API and embedding model providers.
05:08:04.980 | This one is best for code, this one is best for English language, this one is best for multilingual data sets.
05:08:09.980 | But the reality is the only way to find out which is best for your data set is to have an effective way to figure that out.
05:08:15.980 | The next question, of course, is how do I chunk up the data?
05:08:18.980 | Chunking determines what results are available to the model at all, and it's obvious that different types of chunking produce different relevancy in the return results.
05:08:29.980 | And finally, how do we even determine whether a given retrieved result is actually relevant to the task or to the user?
05:08:35.980 | So let's dive into some of these in a little bit more depth.
05:08:38.980 | So the bad news is, again, nobody really has the answers.
05:08:41.980 | Despite the fact that information retrieval is a long study problem, there isn't a great solution to these problems today.
05:08:46.980 | But the good news is that these are important problems and increasingly important problems.
05:08:50.980 | And we see much more production data rather than sort of academic benchmarks that we can work from to solve some of these for the first time.
05:08:58.980 | So first, the question of which embedding models we would be using.
05:09:01.980 | Of course, there are existing academic benchmarks.
05:09:03.980 | And for now, these appear to be mostly saturated.
05:09:07.980 | The reason for that is these are synthetic benchmarks designed specifically for the information retrieval problem and don't necessarily reflect how retrieval systems are used in AI use cases.
05:09:17.980 | So what can you do about that?
05:09:18.980 | You can take some of the open source tooling built to build these benchmarks in the first place and apply it to your data sets and your use cases.
05:09:26.980 | You can use human feedback on relevance by adding a simple relevance feedback endpoint.
05:09:31.980 | And this is something that Chroma is building to support in the very near future.
05:09:34.980 | You can construct your own data sets because you're viewing your data in production.
05:09:38.980 | You know what actually matters to you.
05:09:40.980 | And then you need a way to effectively evaluate the performance of particular embedding models.
05:09:46.980 | Of course, there are great evaluation tools coming onto the market now from several vendors.
05:09:49.980 | Which of these is best, we don't know, but we intend to support all of these with Chroma.
05:09:55.980 | One interesting part about embedding models, and this is, again, this is something that's been well-known in the research community for a while but has been empirically tested recently.
05:10:03.980 | Embedding models with the same training objective, with roughly the same data, tend to learn very similar representations up to an affine linear transform, which suggests that it's possible to project one model's embedding space into another model's embedding space by using a simple linear transform.
05:10:18.980 | So the choice of which embedding model you actually want to use might not end up being so important if you're actually able to sort of apply and figure out those transform from your own data set.
05:10:29.980 | So the question is how to chunk.
05:10:31.980 | Of course, there's a few things to consider.
05:10:33.980 | Chunking in part exists because we have bounded context lengths for our LLMs.
05:10:38.980 | So we want to make sure that the retrieved results can actually fit in that context.
05:10:41.980 | We want to make sure that we retain the semantic content of the data we're aiming to retrieve.
05:10:49.980 | And then we want to make sure that we retain the relevant semantic content of that data rather than just semantic content in general.
05:11:00.980 | We also want to make sure that we're respecting the natural structure of the data because often, especially textual data, was generated for humans to read and understand in the first place.
05:11:08.980 | So this inherent structure of that data provides cues about where the semantic boundaries might be.
05:11:13.980 | Of course, there are tools for chunking.
05:11:15.980 | There's NLTK.
05:11:16.980 | There's LangChain.
05:11:17.980 | LamaIndex also supports many forms of chunking.
05:11:19.980 | But there are experimental ideas here which we're particularly interested in trying.
05:11:24.980 | One interesting thought that we've had and we're experimenting with lightweight open source language models to achieve these is using the model prediction perplexity for the next actual token in the document based on a sliding window of previous tokens.
05:11:37.980 | In other words, you can see when the model mispredicts or has a very low probability for the next actual piece of text as a determinator of where a semantic boundary in the text might be.
05:11:48.980 | And that might be natural for chunking.
05:11:49.980 | And what that also means is because you have a model actually predicting chunk boundaries, you can then fine tune that model to make sure the chunk boundaries are relevant to your application.
05:11:58.980 | So this is something that we're actively exploring.
05:12:00.980 | We can use information hierarchies.
05:12:02.980 | Again, tools like LamaIndex support information hierarchies out of the box and multiple data sources and signals to re-ranking.
05:12:08.980 | And we can also try to use embedding continuity.
05:12:10.980 | This is something that we're experimenting with as well where essentially you take a sliding window across your documents, embed that sliding window, and look for discontinuities in the resulting time series.
05:12:20.980 | So this is an important question, and I'll give you a demonstration about why retrieval results -- being able to compute retrieval result relevance is actually very important in your application.
05:12:33.980 | Imagine in your application you've gone and you've embedded every English language Wikipedia page about birds, and that's what's in your corpus.
05:12:40.980 | And in your traditional retrieval augmented generation system, what you're doing for each query is just returning the five nearest neighbors and then stuffing them into the model's context window.
05:12:48.980 | Now, one day a user's query comes along, and that query is about fish and not birds.
05:12:53.980 | You're guaranteed to return some five nearest neighbors, but you're also guaranteed to not have a single relevant result among them.
05:13:00.980 | How can you, as an application developer, make that determination?
05:13:04.980 | So there's a few possibilities here.
05:13:06.980 | The first, of course, is human feedback around relevancy signal.
05:13:10.980 | The traditional approach in information retrieval is using an auxiliary re-ranking model.
05:13:14.980 | In other words, you take other signals in sort of the query chain.
05:13:18.980 | So what else was the user looking at at the time?
05:13:21.980 | What things has the user found to be useful in the past?
05:13:24.980 | And use those as additional signal around the relevancy.
05:13:27.980 | And we can also, of course, do augmented retrieval, which Chroma does out of the box.
05:13:31.980 | We have keyword-based search, and we have metadata-based filtering.
05:13:34.980 | So you can scope the search if you have those additional signals beforehand.
05:13:39.980 | Now, to me, the most interesting approach here is actually an algorithmic one.
05:13:44.980 | So what I mean by that is conditional on the dataset that you have available and conditional on what we know about the task that the user is trying to perform.
05:13:53.980 | It should be possible to generate a conditional relevancy signal per user, per task, per model, and per instance of that task.
05:14:00.980 | But this requires a model which can understand the semantics of the query as well as the content of the dataset very well.
05:14:07.980 | This is something that we're experimenting with, and this is another place where we think open-source, lightweight language models have actually a lot to offer, even at the data layer.
05:14:16.980 | So to talk a little bit about what we're building, this is the advertising portion of my talk.
05:14:22.980 | In core engineering, we're, of course, building our horizontally scalable cluster version.
05:14:26.980 | Single-node Chroma works great.
05:14:27.980 | Many of you have probably already tried it by now.
05:14:29.980 | It's time to actually make it work across multiple nodes.
05:14:31.980 | By December, we'll have a database-as-a-service technical preview up and ready so you guys can try Chroma Cloud.
05:14:36.980 | In January, we'll have our hybrid deployments available if you want to run Chroma in your enterprise cluster.
05:14:41.980 | And along the way, we're building to support multimodal data.
05:14:45.980 | We know that GPT Vision's API is coming very soon, probably at OpenAI's developer day.
05:14:52.980 | Gemini will also have image understanding and voice.
05:14:56.980 | That means that you'll be able to use multimodal data in your retrieval applications for the first time.
05:15:01.980 | So we're no longer just talking about text.
05:15:03.980 | So these questions about relevancy in other types of data become even more important, right?
05:15:07.980 | Because now you start having questions about relevancy, aesthetic quality, all of these other pieces which you need to make these multimodal retrieval augmented systems work.
05:15:16.980 | And finally, we're working on model selection.
05:15:18.980 | Basically, Chroma wants to do everything in the data layer for you so that just like a modern DBMS, just like you use Postgres in a web application,
05:15:29.980 | everything in the data layer for you as an application developer should just work.
05:15:33.980 | Your focus should be on the application logic and making your application actually run correctly.
05:15:37.980 | And that's what Chroma is building for in AI.
05:15:39.980 | And that's it.
05:15:40.980 | Thank you very much.
05:15:41.980 | Female Speaker: He's the co-founder and CEO of Llama Index.
05:16:02.980 | Hey, everyone.
05:16:03.980 | My name is Jerry, co-founder and CEO of Llama Index.
05:16:21.980 | And today we'll be talking about how to build production-ready RAG applications.
05:16:25.980 | I think there's still time for a raffle for the bucket hat, so if you guys stop by our booth, please fill out the Google form.
05:16:30.980 | Okay.
05:16:31.980 | Let's get started.
05:16:32.980 | So everybody knows that there's been a ton of amazing use cases in Gen AI recently.
05:16:37.980 | You know, knowledge search and QA, conversational agents, workflow automation, document processing.
05:16:43.980 | These are all things that you can build, especially using the reasoning capabilities of LLMs, over your data.
05:16:50.980 | So if we just do a quick refresher, in terms of, like, paradigms for how do you actually get language models to understand data that hasn't been trained over,
05:16:59.980 | there's really, like, two main paradigms.
05:17:01.980 | One is retrieval augmentation, where you, like, fix the model and you basically create a data pipeline to put context into the prompt from some data source into the input prompt of the language model.
05:17:12.980 | So, like, a vector database, you know, like unstructured text, SQL database, et cetera.
05:17:18.980 | The next paradigm here is fine-tuning.
05:17:21.980 | How can we bake knowledge into the weights of the network by actually updating the weights of the model itself, some adapter on top of the model,
05:17:28.980 | but basically some sort of training process over some new data to actually incorporate knowledge.
05:17:33.980 | We'll probably talk a little bit more about retrieval augmentation, but this is just, like, to help you get started in really understanding the mission statement of the company.
05:17:42.980 | OK, let's talk about RAG, retrieval augmented generation.
05:17:48.980 | It's become kind of a buzzword recently, but we'll first walk through the current RAG stack for building a QA system.
05:17:54.980 | This really consists of two main components, data ingestion, as well as data querying, which contains retrieval and synthesis.
05:18:01.980 | If you're just getting started in Lama index, you can basically do this in around, like, five-ish lines of code, so you don't really need to think about it.
05:18:08.980 | But if you do want to learn some of the lower-level components, and I do encourage, like, every engineer, AI engineer, to basically just, like, learn how these components work under the hood,
05:18:16.980 | I would encourage you to check out some of our docs to really understand how do you actually do data ingestion and data querying?
05:18:22.980 | Like, how do you actually retrieve from a vector database, and how do you synthesize that with an L1?
05:18:28.980 | So that's basically the key stack that's kind of emerging these days.
05:18:32.980 | Like, for every sort of chatbot, like, you know, chat over your PDF, like, over your unstructured data,
05:18:38.980 | a lot of these things are basically using the same principles of, like, how do you actually load data from some data source and actually, you know, retrieve inquiry over it.
05:18:48.980 | But I think as developers are actually developing these applications, they're realizing that this isn't quite enough.
05:18:55.980 | Like, there's certain issues that you're running into that are blockers for actually being able to productionize these applications.
05:19:01.980 | And so what are these challenges with NaiveRag?
05:19:04.980 | One aspect here is just, like, the response, and this is the key thing that we're focused on, like, the response quality is not very good.
05:19:12.980 | You run into, for instance, like, bad retrieval issues, like, during the retrieval stage from your vector database.
05:19:17.980 | If you're not actually returning the relevant chunks from your vector database, you're not going to be able to have the correct context actually put into the LLM.
05:19:25.980 | So this includes certain issues like low precision, not all chunks in the retrieve set are relevant.
05:19:30.980 | This leads to, like, hallucination, like, loss in the middle problems, you have a lot of fluff in the return response.
05:19:35.980 | This could mean low recall, like your top K isn't high enough, or basically, like, the set of, like, information that you need to actually answer the question is just not there.
05:19:43.980 | And, of course, there's other issues too, like outdated information.
05:19:46.980 | And many of you who are building apps these days might be familiar with some, like, key concepts of, like, just why the LLM isn't always, you know, guaranteed to give you a correct answer.
05:19:56.980 | There's hallucination, irrelevance, like toxicity bias, there's a lot of issues on the LLM side as well.
05:20:01.980 | So what can we do?
05:20:04.980 | What can we actually do to try to improve the performance of a retrieval augmented generation application?
05:20:10.980 | And for many of you, like, you might be running into certain issues, and it really runs the gamut across, like, the entire pipeline.
05:20:17.980 | There's stuff you can do on the data, like, can we store additional information beyond just, like, the raw text chunks, right, that you're putting in the vector database?
05:20:25.980 | Can you optimize that data pipeline somehow, play around with chunk sizes, that type of thing?
05:20:29.980 | Can you optimize the embedding representation itself?
05:20:32.980 | A lot of times when you're using a pre-trained embedding model, it's not really optimal for giving you the best performance.
05:20:37.980 | There's the retrieval algorithm.
05:20:40.980 | You know, the default thing you do is just look up the top K most similar elements from your vector database to return to the LLM.
05:20:47.980 | Many times that's not enough.
05:20:48.980 | And what are kind of, like, both simple things you can do as well as hard things?
05:20:52.980 | And there's also synthesis.
05:20:53.980 | Like, why is there -- yeah, there's, like, a V in the -- anyway, so can we use LLMs for more than generation?
05:20:59.980 | And so basically, like, you can use the LLM to actually help you with, like, reasoning as opposed to just, like, pure -- just, like, just pure generation, right?
05:21:10.980 | You can actually use it to try to reason over, given a question, can you break it down into simpler questions, route to different data sources,
05:21:17.980 | and kind of, like, have a more sophisticated way of, like, querying your data?
05:21:23.980 | Of course, like, if you've kind of been around some of my recent talks, like, I always say, before you actually try any of these techniques,
05:21:29.980 | you need to be pretty task-specific and make sure that you need a way to -- that you actually have a way to measure performance.
05:21:35.980 | So I'll probably spend, like, two minutes talking about evaluation.
05:21:38.980 | Simon, my co-founder, just ran a workshop yesterday on really just, like, how do you evaluate -- build a dataset, evaluate RAG systems, and help iterate on that.
05:21:46.980 | If you missed the workshop, don't worry, we'll have the slides and materials available online so that you can take a look.
05:21:53.980 | At a very high level, in terms of evaluation, it's important because you basically need to define a benchmark for your system to understand how are you going to iterate on and improve it.
05:22:02.980 | And there's, like, a few different ways you can try to do evaluation, right?
05:22:05.980 | I think Anton from Chroma was just saying some of this, but, like, you basically need a way to evaluate both the end-to-end solution -- like, you have your input query as well as the output response --
05:22:15.980 | you also want to probably be able to evaluate, like, specific components.
05:22:19.980 | Like, if you've diagnosed that the retrieval is, like, the portion that needs improving, you need, like, retrieval metrics to really understand how can you improve your retrieval system.
05:22:28.980 | So there's retrieval and there's synthesis.
05:22:31.980 | Let's talk a little bit -- just, like, 30 seconds on each one.
05:22:34.980 | Evaluation on retrieval -- what does this look like?
05:22:38.980 | You basically want to make sure that the stuff that's returned actually answers the query and that you're kind of, you know, not returning a bunch of fluff and that the stuff that you returned is relevant to the question.
05:22:48.980 | So, first, you need an evaluation data set.
05:22:51.980 | A lot of people have, like, human-labeled data sets.
05:22:54.980 | If you're in building stuff in prod, you might have, like, user feedback as well.
05:22:58.980 | If not, you can synthetically generate a data set.
05:23:00.980 | This data set is input, like, query, and output -- the IDs of, like, the returned documents -- are relevant to the query.
05:23:06.980 | So you need that somehow.
05:23:08.980 | Once you have that, you can measure stuff with ranking metrics, right?
05:23:11.980 | You can measure stuff like success rate, hit rate, MRR, NDCG, a variety of these things.
05:23:16.980 | And so, like, once you are able to evaluate this -- like, this really isn't kind of, like, an LLM problem.
05:23:22.980 | This is, like, an IR problem.
05:23:24.980 | And this has been around for at least, like, a decade or two.
05:23:27.980 | But a lot of this is becoming -- like, you know, it's still very relevant in the face of actually building these LLM apps.
05:23:34.980 | The next piece here is there's a retrieve portion, right?
05:23:38.980 | But then you generate a response from it.
05:23:40.980 | And then how do you actually evaluate the whole thing end-to-end?
05:23:42.980 | So evaluation of the final response given the input.
05:23:46.980 | You still want to generate some sort of data set.
05:23:48.980 | So you could do that through, like, human annotations, user feedback.
05:23:51.980 | You could have, like, ground truth reference answers given the query that really indicates, like, hey, this is the proper answer to this question.
05:23:57.980 | And you can also just, like, you know, synthetically generate it with, like, GPT-4.
05:24:01.980 | You run this through the full RAG pipeline that you built, the retrieval and synthesis.
05:24:05.980 | And you can run, like, LLM-based evals.
05:24:07.980 | So label-free evals, with-label evals.
05:24:10.980 | There's a lot of projects these days going on about how do you actually properly evaluate the outputs, predicted outputs of a language model.
05:24:17.980 | Once you've defined your eval benchmark, now you want to think about how do you actually optimize your RAG systems.
05:24:24.980 | So I sent a teaser on the slide, like, yesterday.
05:24:28.980 | But the way I think about this is that when you want to actually improve your system, there's, like, a million things that you can do to try to actually improve your RAG system.
05:24:37.980 | And, like, you probably don't want to start with the hard stuff first, just because, like, you know, part of the value of language models is how it's kind of democratized access to every developer.
05:24:46.980 | It's really just made it easy for people to get up and running.
05:24:49.980 | And so if, for instance, you're running into some performance issues with RAG, I'd probably start with the basics.
05:24:53.980 | Like, I call it, like, table stakes RAG techniques.
05:24:56.980 | Better parsing so that you don't just split by even chunks.
05:24:59.980 | Like, adjusting your chunk sizes, trying out stuff that's already integrated with a vector database, like hybrid search, as well as, like, metadata filters.
05:25:07.980 | There's also, like, advanced retrieval methods that you could try.
05:25:11.980 | This is, like, a little bit more advanced.
05:25:12.980 | Some of it pulls from, like, traditional IR.
05:25:14.980 | Some of it's more, like, kind of really, like, new in this age of, like, LLM-based apps.
05:25:20.980 | There's, like, re-ranking.
05:25:21.980 | That's a traditional concept.
05:25:23.980 | There's also concepts in Lama Index, like recursive retrieval, like dealing with embedded tables, like small-to-big retrieval, and a lot of other stuff that we have that help you potentially improve the performance of your application.
05:25:34.980 | And then the last bit, like, this kind of gets into more expressive stuff that might be harder to implement, might incur a higher latency and cost, but is potentially more powerful.
05:25:42.980 | And forward-looking is, like, agents.
05:25:44.980 | Like, how do you incorporate agents towards better, like, RAG pipelines to better answer different types of questions and synthesize information?
05:25:51.980 | And how do you actually fine-tune stuff?
05:25:53.980 | Let's talk a little bit about the table stakes first.
05:25:57.980 | So, chunk sizes.
05:25:58.980 | Tuning your chunk size can have outsized impacts on performance, right?
05:26:01.980 | If you've kind of, like, played around with RAG systems, this may or may not be obvious to you.
05:26:06.980 | What's interesting, though, is that, like, more retrieved tokens does not always equate to higher performance.
05:26:11.980 | And that if you do, like, re-ranking of your retrieved tokens, it doesn't necessarily mean that your final generation response is gonna be better.
05:26:18.980 | And this is, again, due to stuff like lost-in-the-middle problems, where stuff in the middle of the LLM context window tends to get lost, whereas stuff at the end tends to be a little bit more well-remembered by the LLM.
05:26:28.980 | And so, I think we did a workshop with, like, Arise a week ago where basically we showed, you know, there is kind of, like, an optimal chunk size given your dataset.
05:26:38.980 | And a lot of times when you try out stuff like re-ranking, it actually increases your error metrics.
05:26:44.980 | Metadata filtering.
05:26:45.980 | This is another, like, very table stakes thing that I think everybody should look into.
05:26:49.980 | And I think vector databases, like, you know, Chroma, Pinecone, Reviate, like, these vector databases are all implementing these capabilities under the hood.
05:26:57.980 | Metadata filtering is basically just, like, how can you add structured context to your chunks, like, your text chunks?
05:27:04.980 | And you can use this for both, like, embeddings as well as synthesis, but it also integrates with, like, the metadata filter capabilities of a vector database.
05:27:12.980 | So, metadata is just, like, again, structured JSON dictionary.
05:27:15.980 | It could be, like, page number.
05:27:16.980 | It could be the document title.
05:27:18.980 | It could be the summary of adjacent chunks.
05:27:19.980 | You can get creative with it, too.
05:27:20.980 | You could hallucinate, like, questions that the chunk answers.
05:27:23.980 | And it can help retrieval.
05:27:25.980 | It can help augment your response quality.
05:27:27.980 | It also integrates with the vector database filters.
05:27:30.980 | So, as an example, let's say the question is over, like, the SEC, like, 10Q document.
05:27:36.980 | And, like, can you tell me the risk factors in 2021?
05:27:39.980 | If you just do raw semantic search, typically it's very low precision.
05:27:42.980 | You're going to return a bunch of stuff that may or may not match this.
05:27:45.980 | You might even return stuff from, like, other years if you have a bunch of documents from different years in the same vector collection.
05:27:51.980 | And so, like, you're kind of, like, rolling the dice a little bit.
05:27:54.980 | But one idea here is basically, you know, if you have access to the metadata of the documents,
05:28:02.980 | and you ask a question like this, you basically combine structured query capabilities by inferring the metadata filters,
05:28:08.980 | like a where clause in a SQL statement, like a year equals 2021,
05:28:11.980 | and you combine that with semantic search to return the most relevant candidates given your query.
05:28:15.980 | And this improves the precision of your results.
05:28:22.980 | Moving on to stuff that's maybe a bit more advanced, like advanced retrieval is one thing that we found generally helps is this idea of, like, small to big retrieval.
05:28:30.980 | So what does that mean?
05:28:31.980 | Basically, right now, when you embed a big text chunk, you also synthesize over that text chunk.
05:28:37.980 | And so it's a little suboptimal because what if, like, the embedding representation is, like, biased?
05:28:41.980 | Because, you know, there's a bunch of fluff in that text chunk that contains a bunch of irrelevant information.
05:28:45.980 | You're not actually optimizing your retrieval quality.
05:28:48.980 | So embedding a big text chunk sometimes feels a little suboptimal.
05:28:52.980 | One thing that you could do is basically embed text at the sentence level or on a smaller level and then expand that window during synthesis time.
05:28:59.980 | And so this is contained in a variety of, like, Lama index abstractions.
05:29:03.980 | But the idea is that you return -- you retrieve on more granular pieces of information, so smaller chunks.
05:29:08.980 | This makes it so that these chunks are more likely to be retrieved when you actually ask a query over these specific pieces of context.
05:29:14.980 | But then you want to make sure that the LLM actually has access to more information to actually synthesize a proper result.
05:29:21.980 | So this leads to, like, more precise retrieval, right?
05:29:24.980 | So we tried this out.
05:29:26.980 | It helps avoid, like, some loss-in-the-middle problems.
05:29:29.980 | You can set a smaller top K value, like K equals 2.
05:29:32.980 | Whereas, like, over this dataset, if you set, like, K equals 5 for naive retrieval over big text chunks,
05:29:38.980 | you basically start returning a lot of context.
05:29:40.980 | And that kind of leads into issues where, you know, maybe the relevant context is in the middle, but you're not able to find out.
05:29:46.980 | Or, like, the LLM is not able to kind of synthesize over that information.
05:29:55.980 | A very related idea here is just, like, embedding a reference to the parent chunk as opposed to the actual text chunk itself.
05:30:03.980 | So, for instance, if you want to embed, like, not just the raw text chunk or not the text chunk,
05:30:07.980 | but actually, like, a smaller chunk or a summary or questions that answer the chunk,
05:30:11.980 | we have found that that actually helps to improve retrieval performance a decent amount.
05:30:16.980 | And it kind of, again, goes along with this idea, like, a lot of times you want to embed something that's more amenable for embedding-based retrieval,
05:30:23.980 | but then you want to return enough context so that the LLM can actually synthesize over that information.
05:30:28.980 | The next bit here is actually kind of even more advanced stuff, right?
05:30:37.980 | This goes on into agents, and this goes on into that last pillar that I mentioned, which is how can you use LLMs for reasoning as opposed to just synthesis?
05:30:46.980 | The intuition here is that, like, for a lot of RAG, if you're just using the LLM at the end, you're, one, constrained by the quality of your retriever,
05:30:52.980 | and you're really only able to do stuff like question answering.
05:30:56.980 | And there's certain types of questions and more advanced analysis that you might want to launch that, like, top KRAG can't really answer.
05:31:02.980 | It's not necessarily just a one-off question.
05:31:04.980 | You might need to have, like, an entire sequence of reasoning steps to actually pull together a piece of information,
05:31:09.980 | or you might want to, like, summarize a document and compare it with, like, other documents.
05:31:13.980 | So one kind of architecture we're exploring right now is this idea of, like, multi-document agents.
05:31:18.980 | What if, like, instead of just, like, RAG, we moved a little bit more into agent territory?
05:31:23.980 | We modeled each document not just as a sequence of text chunks, but actually as a set of tools
05:31:28.980 | that contains the ability to both, like, summarize that document as well as to do QA over that document over specific facts.
05:31:35.980 | And, of course, if you want to scale to, like, you know, hundreds or thousands or millions of documents,
05:31:40.980 | typically an agent can only have access to a limited window of tools.
05:31:44.980 | So you probably want to do some sort of retrieval on these tools similar to how you want to retrieve, like, text chunks from a document.
05:31:51.980 | The main difference is that because these are tools, you actually want to act upon them.
05:31:54.980 | You want to use them as opposed to just, like, taking the raw text and plugging it into the context window.
05:31:59.980 | So blending this combination of, like, kind of embedding-based retrieval or any sort of retrieval,
05:32:05.980 | as well as, like, agent tool use is a very interesting paradigm that I think is really only possible with this age of LMs
05:32:11.980 | and hasn't really existed before this.
05:32:17.980 | Another kind of advanced concept is this idea of fine-tuning.
05:32:20.980 | And so fine-tuning, you know, some other presenters have talked about this as well,
05:32:25.980 | but the idea of, like, fine-tuning in a RAG system is that it really optimizes specific pieces of this RAG pipeline
05:32:32.980 | for you to kind of better, like, improve the performance of either retriever or synthesis capabilities.
05:32:38.980 | So one thing you can do is fine-tune your embeddings.
05:32:41.980 | I think Anton was talking about this as well.
05:32:43.980 | Like, if you just use a pre-trained model, the embedding representations are not going to be optimized over your specific data,
05:32:48.980 | so sometimes you're just going to retrieve the wrong information.
05:32:51.980 | if you can somehow tune these embeddings so that given any sort of, like, relevant question that the user might ask,
05:32:58.980 | that you're actually returning the relevant response, then you're going to have, like, better performance.
05:33:02.980 | So an idea here, right, is to generate a synthetic query dataset from raw text chunks using LLMs and use this to fine-tune an embedding model.
05:33:10.980 | And you can do this, like, if we go back really quick, actually, you can do this by basically kind of fine-tuning the base model itself.
05:33:19.980 | You can also fine-tune an adapter on top of the model.
05:33:22.980 | And fine-tuning an adapter on top of the model has a few advantages in that you don't require the base model's weights to actually fine-tune stuff.
05:33:29.980 | And if you just fine-tune the query, you don't have to re-index your entire document corpus.
05:33:33.980 | There's also fine-tuning LLMs, which, of course, like, a lot of people are very interested in doing these days.
05:33:41.980 | An intuition here specifically for RAG is that if you have a weaker LLM, like 3.5 Turbo, like Llama 2, 7B,
05:33:48.980 | like, these weaker LLMs are bad -- are not bad at, like -- wait, yeah.
05:33:54.980 | Weaker LLMs are maybe a little bit worse at, like, response synthesis, reasoning, structured outputs, et cetera,
05:34:00.980 | compared to, like, bigger models.
05:34:02.980 | So the solution here is what if you can generate a synthetic dataset using a bigger model, like GPT-4,
05:34:07.980 | that's something we're exploring, and actually distill that into 3.5 Turbo.
05:34:11.980 | So it gets better at chain of thought, longer response quality, better structured outputs,
05:34:16.980 | and a lot of other possibilities as well.
05:34:18.980 | So all these things are in our docs.
05:34:20.980 | There's production rag, there's fine-tuning, and I have two seconds left.
05:34:23.980 | So thank you very much.
05:34:25.980 | All right, all right.
05:34:33.980 | Thank you so much, Jerry.
05:34:34.980 | Thank you to all of our speakers.
05:34:35.980 | One more round of applause for all of our speakers, please.
05:34:37.980 | Very briefly, because I know we want to take a break, which is coming up.
05:34:46.980 | So I just feel like we're getting such an incredible education.
05:34:51.980 | Is anyone learning anything at this conference?
05:34:57.980 | So SWIX, you have, SWIX has the Latent, no, the, what is it called?
05:35:02.980 | Not the Latent Space University.
05:35:03.980 | The, is it the Latent Space University?
05:35:06.980 | Or AI Engineering University?
05:35:07.980 | It's LSU.
05:35:08.980 | It's LSU, okay.
05:35:09.980 | Shows you how close I am to his other projects.
05:35:12.980 | So he has his own Latent Space University.
05:35:15.980 | I just feel like we could just post all these videos in order, and that could be it.
05:35:19.980 | Like, I'm learning so much here.
05:35:21.980 | So we have a break coming up.
05:35:23.980 | And then at 4:00 p.m. we have Mithun Hunsar and Shreya Rajpal.
05:35:29.980 | And then we have a closing keynote from the one and only Simon Willison,
05:35:34.980 | who's going to talk about open questions for AI engineering.
05:35:37.980 | So we talked a lot about, you know, things that we're doing,
05:35:40.980 | things that we're being productive in.

06:20:09.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:10.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:11.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:12.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:13.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:14.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:15.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:16.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:17.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:18.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:19.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:20.020 | We catch our breath in the middle of it all.
06:20:21.020 | Next, let's talk about speed and capacity.
06:20:36.020 | Cloud models run on specialized hardware with special configuration.
06:20:39.020 | Local models run on whatever hardware you can scrounge up, including rented hardware.
06:20:44.020 | The further up the axis you go, the more speed and/or parallel inference you can do,
06:20:48.020 | but the more inaccessible it becomes.
06:20:50.020 | This end, a few hundred dollars.
06:20:52.020 | That end, a few hundred million dollars.
06:20:57.020 | Next up, latency.
06:20:59.020 | Cloud models need the full prompt before they can start inference, and you have to wait for
06:21:03.020 | the message back and forth.
06:21:05.020 | Local models can give you a response immediately.
06:21:08.020 | You can feed the prompt as you go along.
06:21:10.020 | This is very important for conversations where you want the model to be able to process what
06:21:14.020 | you're saying as you say it.
06:21:16.020 | And, of course, you can't escape talking about cost.
06:21:19.020 | The cloud vendors will charge you a per token price.
06:21:23.020 | When running locally, it's entirely up to you how much it costs you to run the machine.
06:21:28.020 | If the running cost of your model is less than the cost of running your workload through the
06:21:32.020 | cloud, you're going to make a profit.
06:21:34.020 | And if you're running on a machine you already own, well, that's basically free, right?
06:21:38.020 | With the cloud, you have to use the models they offer you.
06:21:43.020 | Some vendors offer fine-tuning, but they often charge more than just using the regular model,
06:21:49.020 | and they often charge you for the process of fine-tuning.
06:21:51.020 | This means it's not often cost-effective to actually do that.
06:21:55.020 | With local models, the sky's the limit.
06:21:58.020 | There are hundreds, potentially thousands of custom models that can suit any need you have.
06:22:03.020 | Knowledge retrieval, storytelling, conversation, tool use, you name it, someone's probably already
06:22:08.020 | done it.
06:22:09.020 | And if they haven't, fine-tuning the existing model for your own use is easy enough.
06:22:14.020 | And, of course, privacy.
06:22:24.020 | There are some questions you don't want to ask the internet.
06:22:27.020 | Local models let you privately embarrass yourself.
06:22:31.020 | Now, you might be wondering how it's actually possible to run these models locally.
06:22:35.020 | That, my friends, is possible with the power of quantization.
06:22:39.020 | If each model is billions of parameters, and those parameters are like individual numbers,
06:22:44.020 | how could you possibly run them on consumer hardware when there's only so much memory
06:22:48.020 | available for a given performance level?
06:22:51.020 | Well, we can use quantization.
06:22:53.020 | Quantization lets you loss of the compressor model while maintaining the majority of its maths.
06:22:57.020 | We can take the original model, here in blue, and squish it down to something much smaller
06:23:01.020 | using one of these green formats.
06:23:03.020 | This is a secret sauce that makes it viable to run models locally.
06:23:08.020 | Small models aren't just easier to store.
06:23:10.020 | They can also run faster as a computer can process more of the model at any given moment.
06:23:18.020 | But that's enough about local models.
06:23:20.020 | You've probably already heard much there already.
06:23:22.020 | Let's talk about the actual library.
06:23:25.020 | It all started with this man who built something you may have heard of.
06:23:29.020 | Of course, I'm referring to Lama CPP, and that's what it looked like on day one.
06:23:33.020 | Look at the mere 98 stars.
06:23:34.020 | How pedestrian compared to today, where it's 42,000 stars.
06:23:38.020 | But let's go back to March, when I first saw it.
06:23:41.020 | When I saw it, I had but one idea.
06:23:44.020 | It's time to reroute it in Rust.
06:23:46.020 | For both the meme and because I wanted to use it for other things.
06:23:50.020 | Well, I wanted to say it.
06:23:51.020 | Well, I said I wanted to do it, and I did.
06:23:54.020 | But to the right here, set to 22 was also working on the same problem.
06:23:58.020 | And, well, there was just one catch.
06:24:00.020 | He beat me to it.
06:24:02.020 | He beat me to it.
06:24:03.020 | Completely beat me to it.
06:24:04.020 | I'm not afraid to admit it.
06:24:05.020 | Luckily, we came together, managed our projects, and I ended up as the maintainer of the resulting
06:24:11.020 | project, and that's how LLM was born.
06:24:14.020 | So, you might be wondering why.
06:24:17.020 | If Lama CPP exists, why use LMRS?
06:24:21.020 | Well, with LLM.RS, I had six principles in mind.
06:24:24.020 | It must be a library.
06:24:26.020 | When I first started in March, Lama CPP was not a library.
06:24:29.020 | It was an application, and that made it impossible to reuse.
06:24:33.020 | It must not be coupled to an application.
06:24:35.020 | You must be able to customize this behavior.
06:24:37.020 | You must be able to go in and change every little bit of it to make it work for your application,
06:24:42.020 | and we shouldn't make any assumptions about how it's going to be used.
06:24:46.020 | It should support a multitude of model architectures.
06:24:48.020 | Of course, Lama CPP supports Lama and Falcon, but clearly there are more out there.
06:24:54.020 | Next up, it should be Rust native.
06:24:56.020 | It should feel like using a Rust library.
06:24:58.020 | It should work how you expect a Rust library to work.
06:25:03.020 | Next up, backends.
06:25:05.020 | It should support all possible kinds of backends.
06:25:08.020 | You can write it on your CPU, your GPU, or your ML-powered toaster.
06:25:11.020 | I'm sure that's going to be a thing.
06:25:13.020 | We were going to see it coming, I swear.
06:25:15.020 | And finally, platforms.
06:25:17.020 | It should work the same whether it's in Windows, Linux, Mac OS, or something else.
06:25:22.020 | You shouldn't have to change it significantly to make it work, because deployment has always been an issue.
06:25:27.020 | Today, I'm proud to say we support a myriad of architectures, including the darlings of the movement, Lama and Falcon.
06:25:36.020 | These architectures all use the same interface, so you don't have to worry about changing your code to use a different model.
06:25:41.020 | This is made possible by the concerted effort by my co-contributors, Lucas and Dan, who couldn't have done this without, as well as many others.
06:25:51.020 | Here's some sample code for the library.
06:25:53.020 | I won't go too much into it, because it's quite dense.
06:25:56.020 | But the idea is that you load a model right there at the top, because it's actually quite small.
06:26:00.020 | And with that model, you create sessions which track an ongoing use of the model.
06:26:04.020 | You can have as many of these as you would like, but they do have a memory cost, so you want to be careful.
06:26:08.020 | Once you have a session, you can pass a prompt in and infer with the model to determine what comes next.
06:26:14.020 | You can keep reusing the same session, which is very useful for conversation.
06:26:18.020 | You don't need to keep refeeding the context.
06:26:20.020 | The last argument of the function is the callback.
06:26:24.020 | That's where you actually get the tokens out.
06:26:26.020 | It's worth noting that the function itself is actually a helper.
06:26:30.020 | All it does is call the model in a loop with some boundary conditions.
06:26:34.020 | If you want to change the logic in some significant way, you can.
06:26:37.020 | We're not going to start from doing that.
06:26:39.020 | One last thing about this, though.
06:26:41.020 | You see all the calls to default there?
06:26:43.020 | Those are all customisation points.
06:26:45.020 | You can change pretty much anything about this.
06:26:46.020 | You can change how the model is loaded.
06:26:48.020 | You can change how it will do the inference.
06:26:50.020 | You can change how it will sample.
06:26:51.020 | The entire point is you have the control you need to make the thing you need to work.
06:26:57.020 | Here's a quick demo of the library working with Lama 7 billion on my MacBook CPU.
06:27:04.020 | It's reasonably fast, but it could be faster, right?
06:27:08.020 | Well, thanks to the power of GPU acceleration, we have something that's much more usable.
06:27:17.020 | Believe me, it's even faster than NVIDIA GPUs.
06:27:20.020 | AMD and Intel are pending.
06:27:24.020 | Let's talk about what you can actually do with the library.
06:27:27.020 | Let's start with three community projects to begin with.
06:27:29.020 | Local AI is a simple app that you can install to do inference locally.
06:27:35.020 | There's nothing magical about it.
06:27:37.020 | It's just exactly what it says.
06:27:39.020 | I think that's really wonderful.
06:27:40.020 | It means anyone can download this app and be able to use local models without having to think about it.
06:27:47.020 | It's a language.
06:27:48.020 | Next up, LM chain.
06:27:49.020 | It's a lang chain, but for Rust.
06:27:51.020 | And, of course, it supports inference with the library.
06:27:53.020 | And, finally, we have Flonium, which is a flowchart-based application where you can build your own workflows.
06:27:58.020 | I think we've seen a few of those at this conference.
06:28:00.020 | And you can combine and create nodes to build the workflow you need.
06:28:05.020 | And, of course, it supports the library as an inference engine.
06:28:08.020 | Now, I wouldn't be a very good library author if I didn't actually test my own library.
06:28:14.020 | So, I'm going to go through three applications.
06:28:16.020 | The first two are proofs of concept.
06:28:18.020 | The first is LM code.
06:28:19.020 | It's a Discord bot.
06:28:22.020 | You can see it's exactly what you'd expect.
06:28:24.020 | You give it a prompt.
06:28:26.020 | It will give you a response.
06:28:28.020 | Any hitches you see come from Discord limits, not from the actual inference itself.
06:28:32.020 | You can see...
06:28:33.020 | Bam!
06:28:34.020 | All there.
06:28:36.020 | When an issue is a request for generation, it goes through this process here where the
06:28:42.020 | request goes through a generation thread with a channel.
06:28:45.020 | That channel is then used to create a response task.
06:28:49.020 | And then that response task is responsible for sending the responses to the user.
06:28:55.020 | Now, the interesting thing is the sessions are created and thrown away immediately with each
06:29:00.020 | query.
06:29:01.020 | But you don't need to do that.
06:29:02.020 | If you keep them around, you can actually use them for conversation.
06:29:05.020 | And just to illustrate, this is just like the request response workflow you would use for
06:29:10.020 | anything.
06:29:11.020 | If I just take what I had there and drop the Discord bit and add in HTTP, you can see request,
06:29:17.020 | generation, response.
06:29:18.020 | Easy.
06:29:19.020 | Next up.
06:29:20.020 | Next up.
06:29:21.020 | Alpa.
06:29:22.020 | I love using GitHub co-pilot.
06:29:23.020 | But it's only available in my code editor and it requires an internet connection.
06:29:27.020 | Alpa is my attempt to solve this.
06:29:29.020 | It is autocomplete anywhere in your system just by taking what's left of your cursor and passing
06:29:36.020 | to a model to type in.
06:29:38.020 | Alpa is also quite simple.
06:29:39.020 | In fact, it's so simple I don't really need to cover it.
06:29:48.020 | Listen for input.
06:29:49.020 | Copy the input into a prompt.
06:29:52.020 | Start generating.
06:29:53.020 | Type out response.
06:29:54.020 | Easy.
06:29:55.020 | Okay.
06:29:56.020 | Now, the first two examples are pretty simple.
06:29:58.020 | They are proofs of concept.
06:29:59.020 | But now I want to talk about an actual use case.
06:30:01.020 | This is a real-world data extraction task.
06:30:04.020 | Over the last few years, I've been working on a project to make a timeline from the dates
06:30:08.020 | of Wikipedia because there are millions of pages and they all have dates and you can build
06:30:11.020 | a world history from it.
06:30:13.020 | So, that's why, as is the theme of this conference, I threw a large language model at it.
06:30:32.020 | However, GPT 3 and 4 aren't perfect.
06:30:34.020 | Even after rounds of prompt engineering, you can see I tried here.
06:30:38.020 | Handling millions of dates is too expensive and slow.
06:30:41.020 | So, I decided I'd fine-tune my own model.
06:30:44.020 | I generated a representative data set using GPT 3, built a tool to go through the data set,
06:30:49.020 | pick out any data point, fix it up, and then correct the errors, build a new data set,
